functions.description: Resets the Game Object.This moves the Game Object to the given x/y world coordinates and sets `fresh`, `exists`, `visible` and `renderable` to true.If this Game Object has the LifeSpan component it will also set `alive` to true and `health` to the given value.If this Game Object has a Physics Body it will reset the Body.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object if it has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: checkTransform
functions.description: Adjust scaling limits, if set, to this Game Object.

parameters.name: wt
parameters.description: The updated worldTransform matrix.

functions.name: setScaleMinMax
functions.description: Sets the scaleMin and scaleMax values. These values are used to limit how far this Game Object will scale based on its parent.For example if this Game Object has a `minScale` value of 1 and its parent has a `scale` value of 0.5, the 0.5 will be ignored and the scale value of 1 will be used, as the parents scale is lower than the minimum scale this Game Object should adhere to.By setting these values you can carefully control how Game Objects deal with responsive scaling.If only one parameter is given then that value will be used for both scaleMin and scaleMax:`setScaleMinMax(1)` = scaleMin.x, scaleMin.y, scaleMax.x and scaleMax.y all = 1If only two parameters are given the first is set as scaleMin.x and y and the second as scaleMax.x and y:`setScaleMinMax(0.5, 2)` = scaleMin.x and y = 0.5 and scaleMax.x and y = 2If you wish to set `scaleMin` with different values for x and y then either modify Game Object.scaleMin directly, or pass `null` for the `maxX` and `maxY` parameters.Call `setScaleMinMax(null)` to clear all previously set values.

parameters.name: minX
parameters.description: The minimum horizontal scale value this Game Object can scale down to.

parameters.name: minY
parameters.description: The minimum vertical scale value this Game Object can scale down to.

parameters.name: maxX
parameters.description: The maximum horizontal scale value this Game Object can scale up to.

parameters.name: maxY
parameters.description: The maximum vertical scale value this Game Object can scale up to.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: physicsType
members.description: The const physics body type of this object.

members.name: anchor
members.description:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

members.name: texture
members.description: The texture that the sprite is using

members.name: _width
members.description: The width of the sprite (this is initially set by the texture)

members.name: _height
members.description: The height of the sprite (this is initially set by the texture)

members.name: tint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: cachedTint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: tintedTexture
members.description: A canvas that contains the tinted version of the Sprite (in Canvas mode, WebGL doesn't populate this)

members.name: blendMode
members.description:
The blend mode to be applied to the sprite. Set to PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to remove any blend mode.

Warning: You cannot have a blend mode and a filter active on the same Sprite. Doing so will render the sprite invisible.

members.name: shader
members.description:
The shader that will be used to render this Sprite.
Set to null to remove a current shader.

members.name: exists
members.description: Controls if this Sprite is processed by the core Phaser game loops and Group loops.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: height
members.description: The height of the sprite, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: children
members.description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

members.name: ignoreChildInput
members.description:
If `ignoreChildInput`  is `false` it will allow this objects _children_ to be considered as valid for Input events.

If this property is `true` then the children will _not_ be considered as valid for Input events.

Note that this property isn't recursive: only immediate children are influenced, it doesn't scan further down.

members.name: position
members.description:
The coordinates, in pixels, of this DisplayObject, relative to its parent container.

The value of this property does not reflect any positioning happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldPosition` property.

members.name: scale
members.description:
The scale of this DisplayObject. A scale of 1:1 represents the DisplayObject
at its default size. A value of 0.5 would scale this DisplayObject by half, and so on.

The value of this property does not reflect any scaling happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldScale` property.

members.name: pivot
members.description:
The pivot point of this DisplayObject that it rotates around. The values are expressed
in pixel values.

members.name: rotation
members.description:
The rotation of this DisplayObject. The value is given, and expressed, in radians, and is based on
a right-handed orientation.

The value of this property does not reflect any rotation happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldRotation` property.

members.name: alpha
members.description:
The alpha value of this DisplayObject. A value of 1 is fully opaque. A value of 0 is transparent.
Please note that an object with an alpha value of 0 is skipped during the render pass.

The value of this property does not reflect any alpha values set further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldAlpha` property.

members.name: visible
members.description:
The visibility of this DisplayObject. A value of `false` makes the object invisible.
A value of `true` makes it visible. Please note that an object with a visible value of
`false` is skipped during the render pass. Equally a DisplayObject with visible false will
not render any of its children.

The value of this property does not reflect any visible values set further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldVisible` property.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: renderable
members.description:
Should this DisplayObject be rendered by the renderer? An object with a renderable value of
`false` is skipped during the render pass.

members.name: parent
members.description:
The parent DisplayObjectContainer that this DisplayObject is a child of.
All DisplayObjects must belong to a parent in order to be rendered.
The root parent is the Stage object. This property is set automatically when the
DisplayObject is added to, or removed from, a DisplayObjectContainer.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description:
The multiplied alpha value of this DisplayObject. A value of 1 is fully opaque. A value of 0 is transparent.
This value is the calculated total, based on the alpha values of all parents of this DisplayObjects 
in the display list.

To obtain, and set, the local alpha value, see the `alpha` property.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldTransform
members.description:
The current transform of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the transforms of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldPosition
members.description:
The coordinates, in pixels, of this DisplayObject within the world.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the positions of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldScale
members.description:
The global scale of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the scales of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldRotation
members.description:
The rotation, in radians, of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the rotations of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: filterArea
members.description: The rectangular area used by filters when rendering a shader for this DisplayObject.

members.name: x
members.description:
The horizontal position of the DisplayObject, in pixels, relative to its parent.
If you need the world position of the DisplayObject, use `DisplayObject.worldPosition` instead.

members.name: y
members.description:
The vertical position of the DisplayObject, in pixels, relative to its parent.
If you need the world position of the DisplayObject, use `DisplayObject.worldPosition` instead.

members.name: worldVisible
members.description: Indicates if this DisplayObject is visible, based on it, and all of its parents, `visible` property values.

members.name: mask
members.description:
Sets a mask for this DisplayObject. A mask is an instance of a Graphics object.
When applied it limits the visible area of this DisplayObject to the shape of the mask.
Under a Canvas renderer it uses shape clipping. Under a WebGL renderer it uses a Stencil Buffer.
To remove a mask, set this property to `null`.

members.name: filters
members.description:
Sets the filters for this DisplayObject. This is a WebGL only feature, and is ignored by the Canvas
Renderer. A filter is a shader applied to this DisplayObject. You can modify the placement of the filter
using `DisplayObject.filterArea`.

To remove filters, set this property to `null`.

Note: You cannot have a filter set, and a MULTIPLY Blend Mode active, at the same time. Setting a 
filter will reset this DisplayObjects blend mode to NORMAL.

members.name: cacheAsBitmap
members.description:
Sets if this DisplayObject should be cached as a bitmap.

When invoked it will take a snapshot of the DisplayObject, as it is at that moment, and store it 
in a RenderTexture. This is then used whenever this DisplayObject is rendered. It can provide a
performance benefit for complex, but static, DisplayObjects. I.e. those with lots of children.

Cached Bitmaps do not track their parents. If you update a property of this DisplayObject, it will not
re-generate the cached bitmap automatically. To do that you need to call `DisplayObject.updateCache`.

To remove a cached bitmap, set this property to `null`.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running Game.

members.name: name
members.description: A user defined name given to this Game Object.This value isn't ever used internally by Phaser, it is meant as a game level property.

members.name: data
members.description: An empty Object that belongs to this Game Object.This value isn't ever used internally by Phaser, but may be used by your own code, orby Phaser Plugins, to store data that needs to be associated with the Game Object,without polluting the Game Object directly.

members.name: components
members.description: The components this Game Object has installed.

members.name: z
members.description: The z depth of this Game Object within its parent Group.No two objects in a Group can have the same z value.This value is adjusted automatically whenever the Group hierarchy changes.If you wish to re-order the layering of a Game Object then see methods like Group.moveUp or Group.bringToTop.

members.name: events
members.description: All Phaser Game Objects have an Events class which contains all of the events that are dispatched when certain things happen to thisGame Object, or any of its components.

members.name: animations
members.description: If the Game Object is enabled for animation (such as a Phaser.Sprite) this is a reference to its AnimationManager instance.Through it you can create, play, pause and stop animations.

members.name: key
members.description: The key of the image or texture used by this Game Object during rendering.If it is a string it's the string used to retrieve the texture from the Phaser Image Cache.It can also be an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.If a Game Object is created without a key it is automatically assigned the key `__default` which is a 32x32 transparent PNG stored within the Cache.If a Game Object is given a key which doesn't exist in the Image Cache it is re-assigned the key `__missing` which is a 32x32 PNG of a green box with a line through it.

members.name: world
members.description: The world coordinates of this Game Object in pixels.Depending on where in the display list this Game Object is placed this value can differ from `position`, which contains the x/y coordinates relative to the Game Objects parent.

members.name: debug
members.description: A debug flag designed for use with `Game.enableStep`.

members.name: previousPosition
members.description: The position the Game Object was located in the previous frame.

members.name: previousRotation
members.description: The rotation the Game Object was in set to in the previous frame. Value is in radians.

members.name: renderOrderID
members.description: The render order ID is used internally by the renderer and Input Manager and should not be modified.This property is mostly used internally by the renderers, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: fresh
members.description: A Game Object is considered `fresh` if it has just been created or reset and is yet to receive a renderer transform update.This property is mostly used internally by the physics systems, but is exposed for the use of plugins.

members.name: pendingDestroy
members.description: A Game Object is that is pendingDestroy is flagged to have its destroy method called on the next logic update.You can set it directly to allow you to flag an object to be destroyed on its next update.This is extremely useful if you wish to destroy an object from within one of its own callbacks such as with Buttons or other Input events.

members.name: _exists
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle property is the rotation of the Game Object in *degrees* from its original orientation.Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.Values outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement player.angle = 450 is the same as player.angle = 90.If you wish to work in radians instead of degrees you can use the property `rotation` instead. Working in radians is slightly faster as it doesn't have to perform any calculations.

members.name: autoCull
members.description: A Game Object with `autoCull` set to true will check its bounds against the World Camera every frame.If it is not intersecting the Camera bounds at any point then it has its `renderable` property set to `false`.This keeps the Game Object alive and still processing updates, but forces it to skip the render step entirely.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: inCamera
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds intersect with the Game Camera bounds.Returns `true` if they do, otherwise `false` if fully outside of the Cameras bounds.

members.name: offsetX
members.description: The amount the Game Object is visually offset from its x coordinate.This is the same as `width * anchor.x`.It will only be > 0 if anchor.x is not equal to zero.

members.name: offsetY
members.description: The amount the Game Object is visually offset from its y coordinate.This is the same as `height * anchor.y`.It will only be > 0 if anchor.y is not equal to zero.

members.name: centerX
members.description: The center x coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `(x - offsetX) + (width / 2)`.

members.name: centerY
members.description: The center y coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `(y - offsetY) + (height / 2)`.

members.name: left
members.description: The left coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `x - offsetX`.

members.name: right
members.description: The right coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `x + width - offsetX`.

members.name: top
members.description: The y coordinate of the Game Object.This is the same as `y - offsetY`.

members.name: bottom
members.description: The sum of the y and height properties.This is the same as `y + height - offsetY`.

members.name: cropRect
members.description: The Rectangle used to crop the texture this Game Object uses.Set this property via `crop`. If you modify this property directly you must call `updateCrop` in order to have the change take effect.

members.name: _crop
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: deltaX
members.description: Returns the delta x value. The difference between world.x now and in the previous frame.The value will be positive if the Game Object has moved to the right or negative if to the left.

members.name: deltaY
members.description: Returns the delta y value. The difference between world.y now and in the previous frame.The value will be positive if the Game Object has moved down or negative if up.

members.name: deltaZ
members.description: Returns the delta z value. The difference between rotation now and in the previous frame. The delta value.

members.name: destroyPhase
members.description: As a Game Object runs through its destroy method this flag is set to true, and can be checked in any sub-systems or plugins it is being destroyed from.

members.name: fixedToCamera
members.description: A Game Object that is "fixed" to the camera is rendered at a given x/y offsets from the top left of the camera. The offsets are stored in the `cameraOffset` property, which is initialized with the current object coordinates. The values are adjusted at the rendering stage, overriding the Game Objects actual world position.The end result is that the Game Object will appear to be 'fixed' to the camera, regardless of where in the game worldthe camera is viewing. This is useful if for example this Game Object is a UI item that you wish to be visible at all times regardless where in the world the camera is.Note that the `cameraOffset` values are in addition to any parent of this Game Object on the display list.Be careful not to set `fixedToCamera` on Game Objects which are in Groups that already have `fixedToCamera` enabled on them.

members.name: cameraOffset
members.description: The x/y coordinate offset applied to the top-left of the camera that this Game Object will be drawn at if `fixedToCamera` is true.The values are relative to the top-left of the camera view and in addition to any parent of the Game Object on the display list.

members.name: health
members.description: The Game Objects health value. This is a handy property for setting and manipulating health on a Game Object.It can be used in combination with the `damage` method or modified directly.

members.name: maxHealth
members.description: The Game Objects maximum health value. This works in combination with the `heal` method to ensurethe health value never exceeds the maximum.

members.name: damage
members.description: Damages the Game Object. This removes the given amount of health from the `health` property.If health is taken below or is equal to zero then the `kill` method is called.

members.name: setHealth
members.description: Sets the health property of the Game Object to the given amount.Will never exceed the `maxHealth` value.

members.name: heal
members.description: Heal the Game Object. This adds the given amount of health to the `health` property.

members.name: input
members.description: The Input Handler for this Game Object.By default it is disabled. If you wish this Game Object to process input events you should enable it with: `inputEnabled = true`.After you have done this, this property will be a reference to the Phaser InputHandler.

members.name: inputEnabled
members.description: By default a Game Object won't process any input events. By setting `inputEnabled` to true a Phaser.InputHandler is createdfor this Game Object and it will then start to process click / touch events and more.You can then access the Input Handler via `this.input`.Note that Input related events are dispatched from `this.events`, i.e.: `events.onInputDown`.If you set this property to false it will stop the Input Handler from processing any more input events.If you want to _temporarily_ disable input for a Game Object, then it's better to set`input.enabled = false`, as it won't reset any of the Input Handlers internal properties.You can then toggle this back on as needed.

members.name: checkWorldBounds
members.description: If this is set to `true` the Game Object checks if it is within the World bounds each frame. When it is no longer intersecting the world bounds it dispatches the `onOutOfBounds` event.If it was *previously* out of bounds but is now intersecting the world bounds again it dispatches the `onEnterBounds` event.It also optionally kills the Game Object if `outOfBoundsKill` is `true`.When `checkWorldBounds` is enabled it forces the Game Object to calculate its full bounds every frame.This is a relatively expensive operation, especially if enabled on hundreds of Game Objects. So enable it only if you know it's required,or you have tested performance and find it acceptable.

members.name: outOfBoundsKill
members.description: If this and the `checkWorldBounds` property are both set to `true` then the `kill` method is called as soon as `inWorld` returns false.

members.name: outOfCameraBoundsKill
members.description: If this and the `autoCull` property are both set to `true`, then the `kill` methodis called as soon as the Game Object leaves the camera bounds.

members.name: _outOfBoundsFired
members.description: Internal state var.

members.name: inWorld
members.description: Checks if the Game Objects bounds are within, or intersect at any point with the Game World bounds.

members.name: alive
members.description: A useful flag to control if the Game Object is alive or dead.This is set automatically by the Health components `damage` method should the object run out of health.Or you can toggle it via your game code.This property is mostly just provided to be used by your game - it doesn't effect rendering or logic updates.However you can use `Group.getFirstAlive` in conjunction with this property for fast object pooling and recycling.

members.name: lifespan
members.description: The lifespan allows you to give a Game Object a lifespan in milliseconds.Once the Game Object is 'born' you can set this to a positive value.It is automatically decremented by the millisecond equivalent of `game.time.physicsElapsed` each frame.When it reaches zero it will call the `kill` method.Very handy for particles, bullets, collectibles, or any other short-lived entity.

members.name: customRender
members.description: Does this texture require a custom render call? (as set by BitmapData, Video, etc)

members.name: _frame
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: frame
members.description: Gets or sets the current frame index of the texture being used to render this Game Object.To change the frame set `frame` to the index of the new frame in the sprite sheet you wish this Game Object to use,for example: `player.frame = 4`.If the frame index given doesn't exist it will revert to the first frame found in the texture.If you are using a texture atlas then you should use the `frameName` property instead.If you wish to fully replace the texture being used see `loadTexture`.

members.name: frameName
members.description: Gets or sets the current frame name of the texture being used to render this Game Object.To change the frame set `frameName` to the name of the new frame in the texture atlas you wish this Game Object to use, for example: `player.frameName = "idle"`.If the frame name given doesn't exist it will revert to the first frame found in the texture and throw a console warning.If you are using a sprite sheet then you should use the `frame` property instead.If you wish to fully replace the texture being used see `loadTexture`.

members.name: body
members.description: `body` is the Game Objects physics body. Once a Game Object is enabled for physics you access all associated properties and methods via it.By default Game Objects won't add themselves to any physics system and their `body` property will be `null`.To enable this Game Object for physics you need to call `game.physics.enable(object, system)` where `object` is this objectand `system` is the Physics system you are using. If none is given it defaults to `Phaser.Physics.Arcade`.You can alternatively call `game.physics.arcade.enable(object)`, or add this Game Object to a physics enabled Group.Important: Enabling a Game Object for P2 or Ninja physics will automatically set its `anchor` property to 0.5, so the physics body is centered on the Game Object.If you need a different result then adjust or re-create the Body shape offsets manually or reset the anchor after enabling physics.

members.name: transformCallback
members.description: The callback that will apply any scale limiting to the worldTransform.

members.name: transformCallbackContext
members.description: The context under which `transformCallback` is called.

members.name: scaleMin
members.description: The minimum scale this Game Object will scale down to.It allows you to prevent a parent from scaling this Game Object lower than the given value.Set it to `null` to remove the limit.

members.name: scaleMax
members.description: The maximum scale this Game Object will scale up to. It allows you to prevent a parent from scaling this Game Object higher than the given value.Set it to `null` to remove the limit.

members.name: smoothed
members.description: Enable or disable texture smoothing for this Game Object.It only takes effect if the Game Object is using an image based texture.Smoothing is enabled by default.

classes.name: Phaser.SpriteBatch
classes.description: The SpriteBatch class is a really fast version of the DisplayObjectContainer built purely for speed, so use when you need a lot of sprites or particles.It's worth mentioning that by default sprite batches are used through-out the renderer, so you only really need to use a SpriteBatch if you have over1000 sprites that all share the same texture (or texture atlas). It's also useful if running in Canvas mode and you have a lot of un-rotated or un-scaledSprites as it skips all of the Canvas setTransform calls, which helps performance, especially on mobile devices.Please note that any Sprite that is part of a SpriteBatch will not have its bounds updated, so will fail checks such as outOfBounds.

constructor.name: SpriteBatch
constructor.description: The SpriteBatch class is a really fast version of the DisplayObjectContainer built purely for speed, so use when you need a lot of sprites or particles.It's worth mentioning that by default sprite batches are used through-out the renderer, so you only really need to use a SpriteBatch if you have over1000 sprites that all share the same texture (or texture atlas). It's also useful if running in Canvas mode and you have a lot of un-rotated or un-scaledSprites as it skips all of the Canvas setTransform calls, which helps performance, especially on mobile devices.Please note that any Sprite that is part of a SpriteBatch will not have its bounds updated, so will fail checks such as outOfBounds.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: A reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The parent Group, DisplayObject or DisplayObjectContainer that this Group will be added to. If `undefined` or `null` it will use game.world.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: A name for this Group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.

parameters.name: addToStage
parameters.description: If set to true this Group will be added directly to the Game.Stage instead of Game.World.

functions.name: _renderWebGL
functions.description: Renders the Sprite Batch using the WebGL renderer.

functions.name: _renderCanvas
functions.description: Renders the Sprite Batch using the Canvas renderer.

functions.name: add
functions.description: Adds an existing object as the top child in this group.The child is automatically added to the top of the group, and is displayed above every previous child.Or if the _optional_ index is specified, the child is added at the location specified by the index value, this allows you to control child ordering.If the child was already in this Group, it is simply returned, and nothing else happens to it.If `Group.enableBody` is set, then a physics body will be created on the object, so long as one does not already exist.If `Group.inputEnableChildren` is set, then an Input Handler will be created on the object, so long as one does not already exist.Use {@link Phaser.Group#addAt addAt} to control where a child is added. Use {@link Phaser.Group#create create} to create and add a new child.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The display object to add as a child.

parameters.name: silent
parameters.description: If true the child will not dispatch the `onAddedToGroup` event.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index within the group to insert the child to. Where 0 is the bottom of the Group.

returns.description: The child that was added to the group.

functions.name: addAt
functions.description: Adds an existing object to this group.The child is added to the group at the location specified by the index value, this allows you to control child ordering.If `Group.enableBody` is set, then a physics body will be created on the object, so long as one does not already exist.If `Group.inputEnableChildren` is set, then an Input Handler will be created on the object, so long as one does not already exist.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The display object to add as a child.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index within the group to insert the child to.

parameters.name: silent
parameters.description: If true the child will not dispatch the `onAddedToGroup` event.

returns.description: The child that was added to the group.

functions.name: addToHash
functions.description: Adds a child of this Group into the hash array.This call will return false if the child is not a child of this Group, or is already in the hash.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The display object to add to this Groups hash. Must be a member of this Group already and not present in the hash.

returns.description: True if the child was successfully added to the hash, otherwise false.

functions.name: removeFromHash
functions.description: Removes a child of this Group from the hash array.This call will return false if the child is not in the hash.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The display object to remove from this Groups hash. Must be a member of this Group and in the hash.

returns.description: True if the child was successfully removed from the hash, otherwise false.

functions.name: addMultiple
functions.description: Adds an array of existing Display Objects to this Group.The Display Objects are automatically added to the top of this Group, and will render on-top of everything already in this Group.As well as an array you can also pass another Group as the first argument. In this case all of the children from thatGroup will be removed from it and added into this Group.If `Group.enableBody` is set, then a physics body will be created on the objects, so long as one does not already exist.If `Group.inputEnableChildren` is set, then an Input Handler will be created on the objects, so long as one does not already exist.

parameters.name: children
parameters.description: An array of display objects or a Phaser.Group. If a Group is given then *all* children will be moved from it.

parameters.name: silent
parameters.description: If true the children will not dispatch the `onAddedToGroup` event.

returns.description: The array of children or Group of children that were added to this Group.

functions.name: getAt
functions.description: Returns the child found at the given index within this group.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to return the child from.

returns.description: The child that was found at the given index, or -1 for an invalid index.

functions.name: create
functions.description: Creates a new Phaser.Sprite object and adds it to the top of this group.Use {@link Phaser.Group#classType classType} to change the type of object created.The child is automatically added to the top of the group, and is displayed above every previous child.Or if the _optional_ index is specified, the child is added at the location specified by the index value, this allows you to control child ordering.If `Group.enableBody` is set, then a physics body will be created on the object, so long as one does not already exist.If `Group.inputEnableChildren` is set, then an Input Handler will be created on the object, so long as one does not already exist.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to display the newly created Sprite at. The value is in relation to the group.x point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to display the newly created Sprite at. The value is in relation to the group.y point.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

parameters.name: exists
parameters.description: The default exists state of the Sprite.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index within the group to insert the child to. Where 0 is the bottom of the Group.

returns.description: The child that was created: will be a {@link Phaser.Sprite} unless {@link #classType} has been changed.

functions.name: createMultiple
functions.description: Creates multiple Phaser.Sprite objects and adds them to the top of this Group.This method is useful if you need to quickly generate a pool of sprites, such as bullets.Use {@link Phaser.Group#classType classType} to change the type of object created.You can provide an array as the `key` and / or `frame` arguments. When you do thisit will create `quantity` Sprites for every key (and frame) in the arrays.For example:`createMultiple(25, ['ball', 'carrot'])`In the above code there are 2 keys (ball and carrot) which means that 50 sprites will becreated in total, 25 of each. You can also have the `frame` as an array:`createMultiple(5, 'bricks', [0, 1, 2, 3])`In the above there is one key (bricks), which is a sprite sheet. The frames array tellsthis method to use frames 0, 1, 2 and 3. So in total it will create 20 sprites, becausethe quantity was set to 5, so that is 5 brick sprites of frame 0, 5 brick sprites withframe 1, and so on.If you set both the key and frame arguments to be arrays then understand it will createa total quantity of sprites equal to the size of both arrays times each other. I.e.:`createMultiple(20, ['diamonds', 'balls'], [0, 1, 2])`The above will create 20 'diamonds' of frame 0, 20 with frame 1 and 20 with frame 2.It will then create 20 'balls' of frame 0, 20 with frame 1 and 20 with frame 2.In total it will have created 120 sprites.By default the Sprites will have their `exists` property set to `false`, and they will be positioned at 0x0, relative to the `Group.x / y` values.If `Group.enableBody` is set, then a physics body will be created on the objects, so long as one does not already exist.If `Group.inputEnableChildren` is set, then an Input Handler will be created on the objects, so long as one does not already exist.

parameters.name: quantity
parameters.description: The number of Sprites to create.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The Cache key of the image that the Sprites will use. Or an Array of keys. See the description for details on how the quantity applies when arrays are used.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If the Sprite image contains multiple frames you can specify which one to use here. Or an Array of frames. See the description for details on how the quantity applies when arrays are used.

parameters.name: exists
parameters.description: The default exists state of the Sprite.

returns.description: An array containing all of the Sprites that were created.

functions.name: updateZ
functions.description: Internal method that re-applies all of the children's Z values.This must be called whenever children ordering is altered so that their `z` indices are correctly updated.

functions.name: align
functions.description: This method iterates through all children in the Group (regardless if they are visible or exist)and then changes their position so they are arranged in a Grid formation. Children must havethe `alignTo` method in order to be positioned by this call. All default Phaser Game Objects havethis.The grid dimensions are determined by the first four arguments. The `width` and `height` argumentsrelate to the width and height of the grid respectively.For example if the Group had 100 children in it:`Group.align(10, 10, 32, 32)`This will align all of the children into a grid formation of 10x10, using 32 pixels pergrid cell. If you want a wider grid, you could do:`Group.align(25, 4, 32, 32)`This will align the children into a grid of 25x4, again using 32 pixels per grid cell.You can choose to set _either_ the `width` or `height` value to -1. Doing so tells the methodto keep on aligning children until there are no children left. For example if this Group had48 children in it, the following:`Group.align(-1, 8, 32, 32)`... will align the children so that there are 8 children vertically (the second argument), and each row will contain 6 sprites, except the last one, which will contain 5 (totaling 48)You can also do:`Group.align(10, -1, 32, 32)`In this case it will create a grid 10 wide, and as tall as it needs to be in order to fitall of the children in.The `position` property allows you to control where in each grid cell the child is positioned.This is a constant and can be one of `Phaser.TOP_LEFT` (default), `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` or `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.The final argument; `offset` lets you start the alignment from a specific child index.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the grid in items (not pixels). Set to -1 for a dynamic width. If -1 then you must set an explicit height value.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the grid in items (not pixels). Set to -1 for a dynamic height. If -1 then you must set an explicit width value.

parameters.name: cellWidth
parameters.description: The width of each grid cell, in pixels.

parameters.name: cellHeight
parameters.description: The height of each grid cell, in pixels.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The position constant. One of `Phaser.TOP_LEFT` (default), `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` or `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.

parameters.name: offset
parameters.description: Optional index to start the alignment from. Defaults to zero, the first child in the Group, but can be set to any valid child index value.

returns.description: True if the Group children were aligned, otherwise false.

functions.name: resetCursor
functions.description: Sets the group cursor to the first child in the group.If the optional index parameter is given it sets the cursor to the object at that index instead.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: Set the cursor to point to a specific index.

returns.description: The child the cursor now points to.

functions.name: next
functions.description: Advances the group cursor to the next (higher) object in the group.If the cursor is at the end of the group (top child) it is moved the start of the group (bottom child).

returns.description: The child the cursor now points to.

functions.name: previous
functions.description: Moves the group cursor to the previous (lower) child in the group.If the cursor is at the start of the group (bottom child) it is moved to the end (top child).

returns.description: The child the cursor now points to.

functions.name: swap
functions.description: Swaps the position of two children in this group.Both children must be in this group, a child cannot be swapped with itself, and unparented children cannot be swapped.

parameters.name: child1
parameters.description: The first child to swap.

parameters.name: child2
parameters.description: The second child to swap.

functions.name: bringToTop
functions.description: Brings the given child to the top of this group so it renders above all other children.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to bring to the top of this group.

returns.description: The child that was moved.

functions.name: sendToBack
functions.description: Sends the given child to the bottom of this group so it renders below all other children.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to send to the bottom of this group.

returns.description: The child that was moved.

functions.name: moveUp
functions.description: Moves the given child up one place in this group unless it's already at the top.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to move up in the group.

returns.description: The child that was moved.

functions.name: moveDown
functions.description: Moves the given child down one place in this group unless it's already at the bottom.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to move down in the group.

returns.description: The child that was moved.

functions.name: xy
functions.description: Positions the child found at the given index within this group to the given x and y coordinates.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index of the child in the group to set the position of.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x position of the child.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y position of the child.

functions.name: reverse
functions.description: Reverses all children in this group.This operation applies only to immediate children and does not propagate to subgroups.

functions.name: getIndex
functions.description: Get the index position of the given child in this group, which should match the child's `z` property.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to get the index for.

returns.description: The index of the child or -1 if it's not a member of this group.

functions.name: getByName
functions.description: Searches the Group for the first instance of a child with the `name`property matching the given argument. Should more than one child havethe same name only the first instance is returned.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name to search for.

returns.description: The first child with a matching name, or null if none were found.

functions.name: replace
functions.description: Replaces a child of this Group with the given newChild. The newChild cannot be a member of this Group.If `Group.enableBody` is set, then a physics body will be created on the object, so long as one does not already exist.If `Group.inputEnableChildren` is set, then an Input Handler will be created on the object, so long as one does not already exist.

parameters.name: oldChild
parameters.description: The child in this group that will be replaced.

parameters.name: newChild
parameters.description: The child to be inserted into this group.

returns.description: Returns the oldChild that was replaced within this group.

functions.name: hasProperty
functions.description: Checks if the child has the given property.Will scan up to 4 levels deep only.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to check for the existence of the property on.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: An array of strings that make up the property.

returns.description: True if the child has the property, otherwise false.

functions.name: setProperty
functions.description: Sets a property to the given value on the child. The operation parameter controls how the value is set.The operations are:- 0: set the existing value to the given value; if force is `true` a new property will be created if needed- 1: will add the given value to the value already present.- 2: will subtract the given value from the value already present.- 3: will multiply the value already present by the given value.- 4: will divide the value already present by the given value.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to set the property value on.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: An array of strings that make up the property that will be set.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value that will be set.

parameters.name: operation
parameters.description: Controls how the value is assigned. A value of 0 replaces the value with the new one. A value of 1 adds it, 2 subtracts it, 3 multiplies it and 4 divides it.

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: If `force` is true then the property will be set on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If false and the property doesn't exist, nothing will be set.

returns.description: True if the property was set, false if not.

functions.name: checkProperty
functions.description: Checks a property for the given value on the child.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to check the property value on.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: An array of strings that make up the property that will be set.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value that will be checked.

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: If `force` is true then the property will be checked on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If true and the property doesn't exist, false will be returned.

returns.description: True if the property was was equal to value, false if not.

functions.name: set
functions.description: Quickly set a property on a single child of this group to a new value.The operation parameter controls how the new value is assigned to the property, from simple replacement to addition and multiplication.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to set the property on.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The property, as a string, to be set. For example: 'body.velocity.x'

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value that will be set.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.description: If set then the child will only be updated if alive=true.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.description: If set then the child will only be updated if visible=true.

parameters.name: operation
parameters.description: Controls how the value is assigned. A value of 0 replaces the value with the new one. A value of 1 adds it, 2 subtracts it, 3 multiplies it and 4 divides it.

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: If `force` is true then the property will be set on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If false and the property doesn't exist, nothing will be set.

returns.description: True if the property was set, false if not.

functions.name: setAll
functions.description: Quickly set the same property across all children of this group to a new value.This call doesn't descend down children, so if you have a Group inside of this group, the property will be set on the group but not its children.If you need that ability please see `Group.setAllChildren`.The operation parameter controls how the new value is assigned to the property, from simple replacement to addition and multiplication.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The property, as a string, to be set. For example: 'body.velocity.x'

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value that will be set.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.description: If set then only children with alive=true will be updated. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.description: If set then only children with visible=true will be updated. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: operation
parameters.description: Controls how the value is assigned. A value of 0 replaces the value with the new one. A value of 1 adds it, 2 subtracts it, 3 multiplies it and 4 divides it.

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: If `force` is true then the property will be set on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If false and the property doesn't exist, nothing will be set.

functions.name: setAllChildren
functions.description: Quickly set the same property across all children of this group, and any child Groups, to a new value.If this group contains other Groups then the same property is set across their children as well, iterating down until it reaches the bottom.Unlike with `setAll` the property is NOT set on child Groups itself.The operation parameter controls how the new value is assigned to the property, from simple replacement to addition and multiplication.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The property, as a string, to be set. For example: 'body.velocity.x'

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value that will be set.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.description: If set then only children with alive=true will be updated. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.description: If set then only children with visible=true will be updated. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: operation
parameters.description: Controls how the value is assigned. A value of 0 replaces the value with the new one. A value of 1 adds it, 2 subtracts it, 3 multiplies it and 4 divides it.

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: If `force` is true then the property will be set on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If false and the property doesn't exist, nothing will be set.

functions.name: checkAll
functions.description: Quickly check that the same property across all children of this group is equal to the given value.This call doesn't descend down children, so if you have a Group inside of this group, the property will be checked on the group but not its children.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The property, as a string, to be set. For example: 'body.velocity.x'

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: The value that will be checked.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.description: If set then only children with alive=true will be checked. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.description: If set then only children with visible=true will be checked. This includes any Groups that are children.

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: If `force` is true then the property will be checked on the child regardless if it already exists or not. If true and the property doesn't exist, false will be returned.

functions.name: addAll
functions.description: Adds the amount to the given property on all children in this group.`Group.addAll('x', 10)` will add 10 to the child.x value for each child.

parameters.name: property
parameters.description: The property to increment, for example 'body.velocity.x' or 'angle'.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The amount to increment the property by. If child.x = 10 then addAll('x', 40) would make child.x = 50.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.description: If true the property will only be changed if the child is alive.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.description: If true the property will only be changed if the child is visible.

functions.name: subAll
functions.description: Subtracts the amount from the given property on all children in this group.`Group.subAll('x', 10)` will minus 10 from the child.x value for each child.

parameters.name: property
parameters.description: The property to decrement, for example 'body.velocity.x' or 'angle'.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The amount to subtract from the property. If child.x = 50 then subAll('x', 40) would make child.x = 10.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.description: If true the property will only be changed if the child is alive.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.description: If true the property will only be changed if the child is visible.

functions.name: multiplyAll
functions.description: Multiplies the given property by the amount on all children in this group.`Group.multiplyAll('x', 2)` will x2 the child.x value for each child.

parameters.name: property
parameters.description: The property to multiply, for example 'body.velocity.x' or 'angle'.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The amount to multiply the property by. If child.x = 10 then multiplyAll('x', 2) would make child.x = 20.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.description: If true the property will only be changed if the child is alive.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.description: If true the property will only be changed if the child is visible.

functions.name: divideAll
functions.description: Divides the given property by the amount on all children in this group.`Group.divideAll('x', 2)` will half the child.x value for each child.

parameters.name: property
parameters.description: The property to divide, for example 'body.velocity.x' or 'angle'.

parameters.name: amount
parameters.description: The amount to divide the property by. If child.x = 100 then divideAll('x', 2) would make child.x = 50.

parameters.name: checkAlive
parameters.description: If true the property will only be changed if the child is alive.

parameters.name: checkVisible
parameters.description: If true the property will only be changed if the child is visible.

functions.name: callAllExists
functions.description: Calls a function, specified by name, on all children in the group who exist (or do not exist).After the existsValue parameter you can add as many parameters as you like, which will all be passed to the child callback.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: Name of the function on the children to call.

parameters.name: existsValue
parameters.description: Only children with exists=existsValue will be called.

parameters.name: parameter
parameters.description: Additional parameters that will be passed to the callback.

functions.name: callbackFromArray
functions.description: Returns a reference to a function that exists on a child of the group based on the given callback array.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The object to inspect.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The array of function names.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: The size of the array (pre-calculated in callAll).

functions.name: callAll
functions.description: Calls a function, specified by name, on all on children.The function is called for all children regardless if they are dead or alive (see callAllExists for different options).After the method parameter and context you can add as many extra parameters as you like, which will all be passed to the child.

parameters.name: method
parameters.description: Name of the function on the child to call. Deep property lookup is supported.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: A string containing the context under which the method will be executed. Set to null to default to the child.

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: Additional parameters that will be passed to the method.

functions.name: preUpdate
functions.description: The core preUpdate - as called by World.

functions.name: update
functions.description: The core update - as called by World.

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: The core postUpdate - as called by World.

functions.name: filter
functions.description: Find children matching a certain predicate.For example:    var healthyList = Group.filter(function(child, index, children) {        return child.health > 10 ? true : false;    }, true);    healthyList.callAll('attack');Note: Currently this will skip any children which are Groups themselves.

parameters.name: predicate
parameters.description: The function that each child will be evaluated against. Each child of the group will be passed to it as its first parameter, the index as the second, and the entire child array as the third

parameters.name: checkExists
parameters.description: If true, only existing can be selected; otherwise all children can be selected and will be passed to the predicate.

returns.description: Returns an array list containing all the children that the predicate returned true for

functions.name: forEach
functions.description: Call a function on each child in this group.Additional arguments for the callback can be specified after the `checkExists` parameter. For example,    Group.forEach(awardBonusGold, this, true, 100, 500)would invoke `awardBonusGold` function with the parameters `(child, 100, 500)`.Note: This check will skip any children which are Groups themselves.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The function that will be called for each applicable child. The child will be passed as the first argument.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the function should be called (usually 'this').

parameters.name: checkExists
parameters.description: If set only children matching for which `exists` is true will be passed to the callback, otherwise all children will be passed.

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: Additional arguments to pass to the callback function, after the child item.

functions.name: forEachExists
functions.description: Call a function on each existing child in this group.See {@link Phaser.Group#forEach forEach} for details.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The function that will be called for each applicable child. The child will be passed as the first argument.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the function should be called (usually 'this').

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: Additional arguments to pass to the callback function, after the child item.

functions.name: forEachAlive
functions.description: Call a function on each alive child in this group.See {@link Phaser.Group#forEach forEach} for details.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The function that will be called for each applicable child. The child will be passed as the first argument.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the function should be called (usually 'this').

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: Additional arguments to pass to the callback function, after the child item.

functions.name: forEachDead
functions.description: Call a function on each dead child in this group.See {@link Phaser.Group#forEach forEach} for details.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The function that will be called for each applicable child. The child will be passed as the first argument.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the function should be called (usually 'this').

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: Additional arguments to pass to the callback function, after the child item.

functions.name: sort
functions.description: Sort the children in the group according to a particular key and ordering.Call this function to sort the group according to a particular key value and order.For example to depth sort Sprites for Zelda-style game you might call `group.sort('y', Phaser.Group.SORT_ASCENDING)` at the bottom of your `State.update()`.Internally this uses a standard JavaScript Array sort, so everything that applies there also applies here, includingalphabetical sorting, mixing strings and numbers, and Unicode sorting. See MDN for more details.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The name of the property to sort on. Defaults to the objects z-depth value.

parameters.name: order
parameters.description: Order ascending ({@link Phaser.Group.SORT_ASCENDING SORT_ASCENDING}) or descending ({@link Phaser.Group.SORT_DESCENDING SORT_DESCENDING}).

functions.name: customSort
functions.description: Sort the children in the group according to custom sort function.The `sortHandler` is provided the two parameters: the two children involved in the comparison (a and b).It should return -1 if `a > b`, 1 if `a < b` or 0 if `a === b`.

parameters.name: sortHandler
parameters.description: The custom sort function.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: The context in which the sortHandler is called.

functions.name: ascendingSortHandler
functions.description: An internal helper function for the sort process.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first object being sorted.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second object being sorted.

functions.name: descendingSortHandler
functions.description: An internal helper function for the sort process.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first object being sorted.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second object being sorted.

functions.name: iterate
functions.description: Iterates over the children of the group performing one of several actions for matched children.A child is considered a match when it has a property, named `key`, whose value is equal to `value`according to a strict equality comparison.The result depends on the `returnType`:- {@link Phaser.Group.RETURN_TOTAL RETURN_TOTAL}:    The callback, if any, is applied to all matching children. The number of matched children is returned.- {@link Phaser.Group.RETURN_NONE RETURN_NONE}:    The callback, if any, is applied to all matching children. No value is returned.- {@link Phaser.Group.RETURN_CHILD RETURN_CHILD}:    The callback, if any, is applied to the *first* matching child and the *first* matched child is returned.    If there is no matching child then null is returned.If `args` is specified it must be an array. The matched child will be assigned to the firstelement and the entire array will be applied to the callback function.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The child property to check, i.e. 'exists', 'alive', 'health'

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: A child matches if `child[key] === value` is true.

parameters.name: returnType
parameters.description: How to iterate the children and what to return.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: Optional function that will be called on each matching child. The matched child is supplied as the first argument.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the function should be called (usually 'this').

parameters.name: args
parameters.description: The arguments supplied to to the callback; the first array index (argument) will be replaced with the matched child.

returns.description: Returns either an integer (for RETURN_TOTAL), the first matched child (for RETURN_CHILD), or null.

functions.name: getFirstExists
functions.description: Get the first display object that exists, or doesn't exist.You can use the optional argument `createIfNull` to create a new Game Object if none matching your exists argument were found in this Group.It works by calling `Group.create` passing it the parameters given to this method, and returning the new child.If a child *was* found , `createIfNull` is `false` and you provided the additional arguments then the childwill be reset and/or have a new texture loaded on it. This is handled by `Group.resetChild`.

parameters.name: exists
parameters.description: If true, find the first existing child; otherwise find the first non-existing child.

parameters.name: createIfNull
parameters.description: If `true` and no alive children are found a new one is created.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to reset the child to. The value is in relation to the group.x point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to reset the child to. The value is in relation to the group.y point.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

returns.description: The first child, or `null` if none found and `createIfNull` was false.

functions.name: getFirstAlive
functions.description: Get the first child that is alive (`child.alive === true`).This is handy for choosing a squad leader, etc.You can use the optional argument `createIfNull` to create a new Game Object if no alive ones were found in this Group.It works by calling `Group.create` passing it the parameters given to this method, and returning the new child.If a child *was* found , `createIfNull` is `false` and you provided the additional arguments then the childwill be reset and/or have a new texture loaded on it. This is handled by `Group.resetChild`.

parameters.name: createIfNull
parameters.description: If `true` and no alive children are found a new one is created.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to reset the child to. The value is in relation to the group.x point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to reset the child to. The value is in relation to the group.y point.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

returns.description: The alive dead child, or `null` if none found and `createIfNull` was false.

functions.name: getFirstDead
functions.description: Get the first child that is dead (`child.alive === false`).This is handy for checking if everything has been wiped out and adding to the pool as needed.You can use the optional argument `createIfNull` to create a new Game Object if no dead ones were found in this Group.It works by calling `Group.create` passing it the parameters given to this method, and returning the new child.If a child *was* found , `createIfNull` is `false` and you provided the additional arguments then the childwill be reset and/or have a new texture loaded on it. This is handled by `Group.resetChild`.

parameters.name: createIfNull
parameters.description: If `true` and no dead children are found a new one is created.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to reset the child to. The value is in relation to the group.x point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to reset the child to. The value is in relation to the group.y point.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

returns.description: The first dead child, or `null` if none found and `createIfNull` was false.

functions.name: resetChild
functions.description: Takes a child and if the `x` and `y` arguments are given it calls `child.reset(x, y)` on it.If the `key` and optionally the `frame` arguments are given, it calls `child.loadTexture(key, frame)` on it.The two operations are separate. For example if you just wish to load a new texture then pass `null` as the x and y values.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to reset and/or load the texture on.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to reset the child to. The value is in relation to the group.x point.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to reset the child to. The value is in relation to the group.y point.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

returns.description: The child that was reset: usually a {@link Phaser.Sprite}.

functions.name: getTop
functions.description: Return the child at the top of this group.The top child is the child displayed (rendered) above every other child.

returns.description: The child at the top of the Group.

functions.name: getBottom
functions.description: Returns the child at the bottom of this group.The bottom child the child being displayed (rendered) below every other child.

returns.description: The child at the bottom of the Group.

functions.name: getClosestTo
functions.description: Get the closest child to given Object, with optional callback to filter children.This can be a Sprite, Group, Image or any object with public x and y properties.'close' is determined by the distance from the objects `x` and `y` properties compared to the childs `x` and `y` properties.You can use the optional `callback` argument to apply your own filter to the distance checks.If the child is closer then the previous child, it will be sent to `callback` as the first argument,with the distance as the second. The callback should return `true` if it passes your filtering criteria, otherwise it should return `false`.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The object used to determine the distance. This can be a Sprite, Group, Image or any object with public x and y properties.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The function that each child will be evaluated against. Each child of the group will be passed to it as its first parameter, with the distance as the second. It should return `true` if the child passes the matching criteria.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the function should be called (usually 'this').

returns.description: The child closest to given object, or `null` if no child was found.

functions.name: getFurthestFrom
functions.description: Get the child furthest away from the given Object, with optional callback to filter children.This can be a Sprite, Group, Image or any object with public x and y properties.'furthest away' is determined by the distance from the objects `x` and `y` properties compared to the childs `x` and `y` properties.You can use the optional `callback` argument to apply your own filter to the distance checks.If the child is closer then the previous child, it will be sent to `callback` as the first argument,with the distance as the second. The callback should return `true` if it passes your filtering criteria, otherwise it should return `false`.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The object used to determine the distance. This can be a Sprite, Group, Image or any object with public x and y properties.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The function that each child will be evaluated against. Each child of the group will be passed to it as its first parameter, with the distance as the second. It should return `true` if the child passes the matching criteria.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which the function should be called (usually 'this').

returns.description: The child furthest from the given object, or `null` if no child was found.

functions.name: countLiving
functions.description: Get the number of living children in this group.

returns.description: The number of children flagged as alive.

functions.name: countDead
functions.description: Get the number of dead children in this group.

returns.description: The number of children flagged as dead.

functions.name: getRandom
functions.description: Returns a random child from the group.

parameters.name: startIndex
parameters.description: Offset from the front of the group (lowest child).

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: Restriction on the number of values you want to randomly select from.

returns.description: A random child of this Group.

functions.name: getRandomExists
functions.description: Returns a random child from the Group that has `exists` set to `true`.Optionally you can specify a start and end index. For example if this Group had 100 children,and you set `startIndex` to 0 and `endIndex` to 50, it would return a random child from onlythe first 50 children in the Group.

parameters.name: startIndex
parameters.description: The first child index to start the search from.

parameters.name: endIndex
parameters.description: The last child index to search up to.

returns.description: A random child of this Group that exists.

functions.name: getAll
functions.description: Returns all children in this Group.You can optionally specify a matching criteria using the `property` and `value` arguments.For example: `getAll('exists', true)` would return only children that have their exists property set.Optionally you can specify a start and end index. For example if this Group had 100 children,and you set `startIndex` to 0 and `endIndex` to 50, it would return a random child from onlythe first 50 children in the Group.

parameters.name: property
parameters.description: An optional property to test against the value argument.

parameters.name: value
parameters.description: If property is set then Child.property must strictly equal this value to be included in the results.

parameters.name: startIndex
parameters.description: The first child index to start the search from.

parameters.name: endIndex
parameters.description: The last child index to search up until.

returns.description: A random existing child of this Group.

functions.name: remove
functions.description: Removes the given child from this group.This will dispatch an `onRemovedFromGroup` event from the child (if it has one), and optionally destroy the child.If the group cursor was referring to the removed child it is updated to refer to the next child.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to remove.

parameters.name: destroy
parameters.description: If true `destroy` will be invoked on the removed child.

parameters.name: silent
parameters.description: If true the the child will not dispatch the `onRemovedFromGroup` event.

returns.description: true if the child was removed from this group, otherwise false.

functions.name: moveAll
functions.description: Moves all children from this Group to the Group given.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The new Group to which the children will be moved to.

parameters.name: silent
parameters.description: If true the children will not dispatch the `onAddedToGroup` event for the new Group.

returns.description: The Group to which all the children were moved.

functions.name: removeAll
functions.description: Removes all children from this Group, but does not remove the group from its parent.The children can be optionally destroyed as they are removed.You can also optionally also destroy the BaseTexture the Child is using. Be careful if you'vemore than one Game Object sharing the same BaseTexture.

parameters.name: destroy
parameters.description: If true `destroy` will be invoked on each removed child.

parameters.name: silent
parameters.description: If true the children will not dispatch their `onRemovedFromGroup` events.

parameters.name: destroyTexture
