parameters.description: If true, and if the `destroy` argument is also true, the BaseTexture belonging to the Child is also destroyed. Note that if another Game Object is sharing the same BaseTexture it will invalidate it.

functions.name: removeBetween
functions.description: Removes all children from this group whose index falls beteen the given startIndex and endIndex values.

parameters.name: startIndex
parameters.description: The index to start removing children from.

parameters.name: endIndex
parameters.description: The index to stop removing children at. Must be higher than startIndex. If undefined this method will remove all children between startIndex and the end of the group.

parameters.name: destroy
parameters.description: If true `destroy` will be invoked on each removed child.

parameters.name: silent
parameters.description: If true the children will not dispatch their `onRemovedFromGroup` events.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys this group.Removes all children, then removes this group from its parent and nulls references.

parameters.name: destroyChildren
parameters.description: If true `destroy` will be invoked on each removed child.

parameters.name: soft
parameters.description: A 'soft destroy' (set to true) doesn't remove this group from its parent or null the game reference. Set to false and it does.

functions.name: alignIn
functions.description: Aligns this Group within another Game Object, or Rectangle, known as the'container', to one of 9 possible positions.The container must be a Game Object, or Phaser.Rectangle object. This can include propertiessuch as `World.bounds` or `Camera.view`, for aligning Groups within the world and camera bounds. Or it can include other Sprites, Images, Text objects, BitmapText,TileSprites or Buttons.Please note that aligning a Group to another Game Object does **not** make it a child ofthe container. It simply modifies its position coordinates so it aligns with it.The position constants you can use are:`Phaser.TOP_LEFT`, `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` and `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.Groups are placed in such a way that their _bounds_ align with thecontainer, taking into consideration rotation and scale of its children.This allows you to neatly align Groups, irrespective of their position value.The optional `offsetX` and `offsetY` arguments allow you to apply extra spacing to the finalaligned position of the Group. For example:`group.alignIn(background, Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT, -20, -20)`Would align the `group` to the bottom-right, but moved 20 pixels in from the corner.Think of the offsets as applying an adjustment to the containers bounds before the alignment takes place.So providing a negative offset will 'shrink' the container bounds by that amount, and providing a positiveone expands it.

parameters.name: container
parameters.description: The Game Object or Rectangle with which to align this Group to. Can also include properties such as `World.bounds` or `Camera.view`.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The position constant. One of `Phaser.TOP_LEFT` (default), `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` or `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: A horizontal adjustment of the Containers bounds, applied to the aligned position of the Game Object. Use a negative value to shrink the bounds, positive to increase it.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: A vertical adjustment of the Containers bounds, applied to the aligned position of the Game Object. Use a negative value to shrink the bounds, positive to increase it.

returns.description: This Group.

functions.name: alignTo
functions.description: Aligns this Group to the side of another Game Object, or Rectangle, known as the'parent', in one of 11 possible positions.The parent must be a Game Object, or Phaser.Rectangle object. This can include propertiessuch as `World.bounds` or `Camera.view`, for aligning Groups within the world and camera bounds. Or it can include other Sprites, Images, Text objects, BitmapText,TileSprites or Buttons.Please note that aligning a Group to another Game Object does **not** make it a child ofthe parent. It simply modifies its position coordinates so it aligns with it.The position constants you can use are:`Phaser.TOP_LEFT` (default), `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_TOP`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.LEFT_BOTTOM`, `Phaser.RIGHT_TOP`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_BOTTOM`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` and `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.Groups are placed in such a way that their _bounds_ align with theparent, taking into consideration rotation and scale of the children.This allows you to neatly align Groups, irrespective of their position value.The optional `offsetX` and `offsetY` arguments allow you to apply extra spacing to the finalaligned position of the Group. For example:`group.alignTo(background, Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT, -20, -20)`Would align the `group` to the bottom-right, but moved 20 pixels in from the corner.Think of the offsets as applying an adjustment to the parents bounds before the alignment takes place.So providing a negative offset will 'shrink' the parent bounds by that amount, and providing a positiveone expands it.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The Game Object or Rectangle with which to align this Group to. Can also include properties such as `World.bounds` or `Camera.view`.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The position constant. One of `Phaser.TOP_LEFT`, `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_TOP`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.LEFT_BOTTOM`, `Phaser.RIGHT_TOP`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_BOTTOM`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` or `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: A horizontal adjustment of the Containers bounds, applied to the aligned position of the Game Object. Use a negative value to shrink the bounds, positive to increase it.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: A vertical adjustment of the Containers bounds, applied to the aligned position of the Game Object. Use a negative value to shrink the bounds, positive to increase it.

returns.description: This Group.

functions.name: addChild
functions.description: Adds a child to the container.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to add to the container

returns.description: The child that was added.

functions.name: addChildAt

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to place the child in

returns.description: The child that was added.

functions.name: getChildIndex
functions.description: Returns the index position of a child DisplayObject instance

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject instance to identify

returns.description: The index position of the child display object to identify

functions.name: setChildIndex
functions.description: Changes the position of an existing child in the display object container

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child DisplayObject instance for which you want to change the index number

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The resulting index number for the child display object

functions.name: getChildAt
functions.description: Returns the child at the specified index

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to get the child from

returns.description: The child at the given index, if any.

functions.name: removeChild
functions.description: Removes a child from the container.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to remove

returns.description: The child that was removed.

functions.name: removeChildAt
functions.description: Removes a child from the specified index position.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to get the child from

returns.description: The child that was removed.

functions.name: removeChildren
functions.description: Removes all children from this container that are within the begin and end indexes.

parameters.name: beginIndex
parameters.description: The beginning position. Default value is 0.

parameters.name: endIndex
parameters.description: The ending position. Default value is size of the container.

functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: Retrieves the global bounds of the displayObjectContainer as a rectangle. The bounds calculation takes all visible children into consideration.

parameters.name: targetCoordinateSpace
parameters.description: Returns a rectangle that defines the area of the display object relative to the coordinate system of the targetCoordinateSpace object.

returns.description: The rectangular bounding area

functions.name: getLocalBounds
functions.description: Retrieves the non-global local bounds of the displayObjectContainer as a rectangle without any transformations. The calculation takes all visible children into consideration.

returns.description: The rectangular bounding area

functions.name: contains
functions.description: Determines whether the specified display object is a child of the DisplayObjectContainer instance or the instance itself.

members.name: type
members.description: Internal Phaser Type value.

members.name: fastSpriteBatch
members.description: WebGL Batch Shader.

members.name: ready
members.description: Internal flag.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running Game.

members.name: name
members.description: A name for this group. Not used internally but useful for debugging.

members.name: z
members.description: The z-depth value of this object within its parent container/Group - the World is a Group as well.This value must be unique for each child in a Group.

members.name: physicsType
members.description: The const physics body type of this object.

members.name: alive
members.description: The alive property is useful for Groups that are children of other Groups and need to be included/excluded in checks like forEachAlive.

members.name: exists
members.description: If exists is false the group will be excluded from collision checks and filters such as {@link forEachExists}. The group will not call `preUpdate` and `postUpdate` on its children and the children will not receive physics updates or camera/world boundary checks. The group will still be {@link Phaser.Group#visible visible} and will still call `update` on its children.

members.name: ignoreDestroy
members.description: A group with `ignoreDestroy` set to `true` ignores all calls to its `destroy` method.

members.name: pendingDestroy
members.description: A Group is that has `pendingDestroy` set to `true` is flagged to have its destroy methodcalled on the next logic update.You can set it directly to flag the Group to be destroyed on its next update.This is extremely useful if you wish to destroy a Group from within one of its own callbacksor a callback of one of its children.

members.name: classType
members.description: The type of objects that will be created when using {@link Phaser.Group#create create} or {@link Phaser.Group#createMultiple createMultiple}.Any object may be used but it should extend either Sprite or Image and accept the same constructor arguments:when a new object is created it is passed the following parameters to its constructor: `(game, x, y, key, frame)`.

members.name: cursor
members.description: The current display object that the group cursor is pointing to, if any. (Can be set manually.)The cursor is a way to iterate through the children in a Group using {@link Phaser.Group#next next} and {@link Phaser.Group#previous previous}.

members.name: inputEnableChildren
members.description: A Group with `inputEnableChildren` set to `true` will automatically call `inputEnabled = true` on any children _added_ to, or _created by_, this Group.If there are children already in the Group at the time you set this property, they are not changed.

members.name: onChildInputDown
members.description: This Signal is dispatched whenever a child of this Group emits an onInputDown signal as a resultof having been interacted with by a Pointer. You can bind functions to this Signal instead of toevery child Sprite.This Signal is sent 2 arguments: A reference to the Sprite that triggered the signal, anda reference to the Pointer that caused it.

members.name: onChildInputUp
members.description: This Signal is dispatched whenever a child of this Group emits an onInputUp signal as a resultof having been interacted with by a Pointer. You can bind functions to this Signal instead of toevery child Sprite.This Signal is sent 3 arguments: A reference to the Sprite that triggered the signal, a reference to the Pointer that caused it, and a boolean value `isOver` that tells you if the Pointeris still over the Sprite or not.

members.name: onChildInputOver
members.description: This Signal is dispatched whenever a child of this Group emits an onInputOver signal as a resultof having been interacted with by a Pointer. You can bind functions to this Signal instead of toevery child Sprite.This Signal is sent 2 arguments: A reference to the Sprite that triggered the signal, anda reference to the Pointer that caused it.

members.name: onChildInputOut
members.description: This Signal is dispatched whenever a child of this Group emits an onInputOut signal as a resultof having been interacted with by a Pointer. You can bind functions to this Signal instead of toevery child Sprite.This Signal is sent 2 arguments: A reference to the Sprite that triggered the signal, anda reference to the Pointer that caused it.

members.name: enableBody
members.description: If true all Sprites created by, or added to this group, will have a physics body enabled on them.If there are children already in the Group at the time you set this property, they are not changed.The default body type is controlled with {@link Phaser.Group#physicsBodyType physicsBodyType}.

members.name: enableBodyDebug
members.description: If true when a physics body is created (via {@link Phaser.Group#enableBody enableBody}) it will create a physics debug object as well.This only works for P2 bodies.

members.name: physicsBodyType
members.description: If {@link Phaser.Group#enableBody enableBody} is true this is the type of physics body that is created on new Sprites.The valid values are {@link Phaser.Physics.ARCADE}, {@link Phaser.Physics.P2JS}, {@link Phaser.Physics.NINJA}, etc.

members.name: physicsSortDirection
members.description: If this Group contains Arcade Physics Sprites you can set a custom sort direction via this property.It should be set to one of the Phaser.Physics.Arcade sort direction constants: Phaser.Physics.Arcade.SORT_NONEPhaser.Physics.Arcade.LEFT_RIGHTPhaser.Physics.Arcade.RIGHT_LEFTPhaser.Physics.Arcade.TOP_BOTTOMPhaser.Physics.Arcade.BOTTOM_TOPIf set to `null` the Group will use whatever Phaser.Physics.Arcade.sortDirection is set to. This is the default behavior.

members.name: onDestroy
members.description: This signal is dispatched when the group is destroyed.

members.name: cursorIndex
members.description: The current index of the Group cursor. Advance it with Group.next.

members.name: fixedToCamera
members.description: A Group that is fixed to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera. These are stored in Group.cameraOffset.Note that the cameraOffset values are in addition to any parent in the display list.So if this Group was in a Group that has x: 200, then this will be added to the cameraOffset.x

members.name: cameraOffset
members.description: If this object is {@link Phaser.Group#fixedToCamera fixedToCamera} then this stores the x/y position offset relative to the top-left of the camera view.If the parent of this Group is also `fixedToCamera` then the offset here is in addition to that and should typically be disabled.

members.name: hash
members.description: The hash array is an array belonging to this Group into which you can add any of its children via Group.addToHash and Group.removeFromHash.Only children of this Group can be added to and removed from the hash.This hash is used automatically by Phaser Arcade Physics in order to perform non z-index based destructive sorting.However if you don't use Arcade Physics, or this isn't a physics enabled Group, then you can use the hash to perform your ownsorting and filtering of Group children without touching their z-index (and therefore display draw order)

members.name: _sortProperty
members.description: The property on which children are sorted.

members.name: total
members.description: Total number of existing children in the group.

members.name: length
members.description: Total number of children in this group, regardless of exists/alive status.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle of rotation of the group container, in degrees.This adjusts the group itself by modifying its local rotation transform.This has no impact on the rotation/angle properties of the children, but it will update their worldTransformand on-screen orientation and position.

members.name: centerX
members.description: The center x coordinate of this Group.It is derived by calling `getBounds`, calculating the Groups dimensions based on itsvisible children.

members.name: centerY
members.description: The center y coordinate of this Group.It is derived by calling `getBounds`, calculating the Groups dimensions based on itsvisible children.

members.name: left
members.description: The left coordinate of this Group.It is derived by calling `getBounds`, calculating the Groups dimensions based on itsvisible children.

members.name: right
members.description: The right coordinate of this Group.It is derived by calling `getBounds`, calculating the Groups dimensions based on itsvisible children.

members.name: top
members.description: The top coordinate of this Group.It is derived by calling `getBounds`, calculating the Groups dimensions based on itsvisible children.

members.name: bottom
members.description: The bottom coordinate of this Group.It is derived by calling `getBounds`, calculating the Groups dimensions based on itsvisible children.

members.name: x
members.description: The x coordinate of the group container.You can adjust the group container itself by modifying its coordinates.This will have no impact on the x/y coordinates of its children, but it will update their worldTransform and on-screen position.

members.name: y
members.description: The y coordinate of the group container.You can adjust the group container itself by modifying its coordinates.This will have no impact on the x/y coordinates of its children, but it will update their worldTransform and on-screen position.

members.name: rotation
members.description: The angle of rotation of the group container, in radians.This will adjust the group container itself by modifying its rotation.This will have no impact on the rotation value of its children, but it will update their worldTransform and on-screen position.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visible state of the group. Non-visible Groups and all of their children are not rendered.

members.name: alpha
members.description: The alpha value of the group container.

members.name: children
members.description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

members.name: ignoreChildInput
members.description:
If `ignoreChildInput`  is `false` it will allow this objects _children_ to be considered as valid for Input events.

If this property is `true` then the children will _not_ be considered as valid for Input events.

Note that this property isn't recursive: only immediate children are influenced, it doesn't scan further down.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of the displayObjectContainer, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: height
members.description: The height of the displayObjectContainer, setting this will actually modify the scale to achieve the value set

members.name: position
members.description:
The coordinates, in pixels, of this DisplayObject, relative to its parent container.

The value of this property does not reflect any positioning happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldPosition` property.

members.name: scale
members.description:
The scale of this DisplayObject. A scale of 1:1 represents the DisplayObject
at its default size. A value of 0.5 would scale this DisplayObject by half, and so on.

The value of this property does not reflect any scaling happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldScale` property.

members.name: pivot
members.description:
The pivot point of this DisplayObject that it rotates around. The values are expressed
in pixel values.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: renderable
members.description:
Should this DisplayObject be rendered by the renderer? An object with a renderable value of
`false` is skipped during the render pass.

members.name: parent
members.description:
The parent DisplayObjectContainer that this DisplayObject is a child of.
All DisplayObjects must belong to a parent in order to be rendered.
The root parent is the Stage object. This property is set automatically when the
DisplayObject is added to, or removed from, a DisplayObjectContainer.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description:
The multiplied alpha value of this DisplayObject. A value of 1 is fully opaque. A value of 0 is transparent.
This value is the calculated total, based on the alpha values of all parents of this DisplayObjects 
in the display list.

To obtain, and set, the local alpha value, see the `alpha` property.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldTransform
members.description:
The current transform of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the transforms of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldPosition
members.description:
The coordinates, in pixels, of this DisplayObject within the world.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the positions of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldScale
members.description:
The global scale of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the scales of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldRotation
members.description:
The rotation, in radians, of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the rotations of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: filterArea
members.description: The rectangular area used by filters when rendering a shader for this DisplayObject.

members.name: worldVisible
members.description: Indicates if this DisplayObject is visible, based on it, and all of its parents, `visible` property values.

members.name: mask
members.description:
Sets a mask for this DisplayObject. A mask is an instance of a Graphics object.
When applied it limits the visible area of this DisplayObject to the shape of the mask.
Under a Canvas renderer it uses shape clipping. Under a WebGL renderer it uses a Stencil Buffer.
To remove a mask, set this property to `null`.

members.name: filters
members.description:
Sets the filters for this DisplayObject. This is a WebGL only feature, and is ignored by the Canvas
Renderer. A filter is a shader applied to this DisplayObject. You can modify the placement of the filter
using `DisplayObject.filterArea`.

To remove filters, set this property to `null`.

Note: You cannot have a filter set, and a MULTIPLY Blend Mode active, at the same time. Setting a 
filter will reset this DisplayObjects blend mode to NORMAL.

members.name: cacheAsBitmap
members.description:
Sets if this DisplayObject should be cached as a bitmap.

When invoked it will take a snapshot of the DisplayObject, as it is at that moment, and store it 
in a RenderTexture. This is then used whenever this DisplayObject is rendered. It can provide a
performance benefit for complex, but static, DisplayObjects. I.e. those with lots of children.

Cached Bitmaps do not track their parents. If you update a property of this DisplayObject, it will not
re-generate the cached bitmap automatically. To do that you need to call `DisplayObject.updateCache`.

To remove a cached bitmap, set this property to `null`.

classes.name: Phaser.Text
classes.description: Create a new game object for displaying Text.This uses a local hidden Canvas object and renders the type into it. It then makes a texture from this for rendering to the view.Because of this you can only display fonts that are currently loaded and available to the browser: fonts must be pre-loaded.See {@link http://www.jordanm.co.uk/tinytype this compatibility table} for the available default fonts across mobile browsers.

constructor.name: Text
constructor.description: Create a new game object for displaying Text.This uses a local hidden Canvas object and renders the type into it. It then makes a texture from this for rendering to the view.Because of this you can only display fonts that are currently loaded and available to the browser: fonts must be pre-loaded.See {@link http://www.jordanm.co.uk/tinytype this compatibility table} for the available default fonts across mobile browsers.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: Current game instance.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: X position of the new text object.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Y position of the new text object.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The actual text that will be written.

parameters.name: style
parameters.description: The style properties to be set on the Text.

parameters.name: style.font
parameters.description: The style and size of the font.

parameters.name: style.fontStyle
parameters.description: The style of the font (eg. 'italic'): overrides the value in `style.font`.

parameters.name: style.fontVariant
parameters.description: The variant of the font (eg. 'small-caps'): overrides the value in `style.font`.

parameters.name: style.fontWeight
parameters.description: The weight of the font (eg. 'bold'): overrides the value in `style.font`.

parameters.name: style.fontSize
parameters.description: The size of the font (eg. 32 or '32px'): overrides the value in `style.font`.

parameters.name: style.backgroundColor
parameters.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used as the background for the whole Text object. Set to `null` to disable.

parameters.name: style.fill
parameters.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg 'red', '#00FF00'.

parameters.name: style.align
parameters.description: Horizontal alignment of each line in multiline text. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'. Does not affect single lines of text (see `textBounds` and `boundsAlignH` for that).

parameters.name: style.boundsAlignH
parameters.description: Horizontal alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'.

parameters.name: style.boundsAlignV
parameters.description: Vertical alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'top', 'middle' or 'bottom'.

parameters.name: style.stroke
parameters.description: A canvas stroke style that will be used on the text stroke eg 'blue', '#FCFF00'.

parameters.name: style.strokeThickness
parameters.description: A number that represents the thickness of the stroke. Default is 0 (no stroke).

parameters.name: style.wordWrap
parameters.description: Indicates if word wrap should be used.

parameters.name: style.wordWrapWidth
parameters.description: The width in pixels at which text will wrap.

parameters.name: style.maxLines
parameters.description: The maximum number of lines to be shown for wrapped text.

parameters.name: style.tabs
parameters.description: The size (in pixels) of the tabs, for when text includes tab characters. 0 disables. Can be an array of varying tab sizes, one per tab stop.

functions.name: preUpdate
functions.description: Automatically called by World.preUpdate.

functions.name: update
functions.description: Override this function to handle any special update requirements.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroy this Text object, removing it from the group it belongs to.

parameters.name: destroyChildren
parameters.description: Should every child of this object have its destroy method called?

functions.name: setShadow
functions.description: Sets a drop shadow effect on the Text. You can specify the horizontal and vertical distance of the drop shadow with the `x` and `y` parameters.The color controls the shade of the shadow (default is black) and can be either an `rgba` or `hex` value.The blur is the strength of the shadow. A value of zero means a hard shadow, a value of 10 means a very soft shadow.To remove a shadow already in place you can call this method with no parameters set.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The shadowOffsetX value in pixels. This is how far offset horizontally the shadow effect will be.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The shadowOffsetY value in pixels. This is how far offset vertically the shadow effect will be.

parameters.name: color
parameters.description: The color of the shadow, as given in CSS rgba or hex format. Set the alpha component to 0 to disable the shadow.

parameters.name: blur
parameters.description: The shadowBlur value. Make the shadow softer by applying a Gaussian blur to it. A number from 0 (no blur) up to approx. 10 (depending on scene).

parameters.name: shadowStroke
parameters.description: Apply the drop shadow to the Text stroke (if set).

parameters.name: shadowFill
parameters.description: Apply the drop shadow to the Text fill (if set).

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: setStyle
functions.description: Set the style of the text by passing a single style object to it.

parameters.name: style
parameters.description: The style properties to be set on the Text.

parameters.name: style.font
parameters.description: The style and size of the font.

parameters.name: style.fontStyle
parameters.description: The style of the font (eg. 'italic'): overrides the value in `style.font`.

parameters.name: style.fontVariant
parameters.description: The variant of the font (eg. 'small-caps'): overrides the value in `style.font`.

parameters.name: style.fontWeight
parameters.description: The weight of the font (eg. 'bold'): overrides the value in `style.font`.

parameters.name: style.fontSize
parameters.description: The size of the font (eg. 32 or '32px'): overrides the value in `style.font`.

parameters.name: style.backgroundColor
parameters.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used as the background for the whole Text object. Set to `null` to disable.

parameters.name: style.fill
parameters.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg 'red', '#00FF00'.

parameters.name: style.align
parameters.description: Horizontal alignment of each line in multiline text. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'. Does not affect single lines of text (see `textBounds` and `boundsAlignH` for that).

parameters.name: style.boundsAlignH
parameters.description: Horizontal alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'.

parameters.name: style.boundsAlignV
parameters.description: Vertical alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'top', 'middle' or 'bottom'.

parameters.name: style.stroke
parameters.description: A canvas stroke style that will be used on the text stroke eg 'blue', '#FCFF00'.

parameters.name: style.strokeThickness
parameters.description: A number that represents the thickness of the stroke. Default is 0 (no stroke).

parameters.name: style.wordWrap
parameters.description: Indicates if word wrap should be used.

parameters.name: style.wordWrapWidth
parameters.description: The width in pixels at which text will wrap.

parameters.name: style.maxLines
parameters.description: The maximum number of lines to be shown for wrapped text.

parameters.name: style.tabs
parameters.description: The size (in pixels) of the tabs, for when text includes tab characters. 0 disables. Can be an array of varying tab sizes, one per tab stop.

parameters.name: update
parameters.description: Immediately update the Text object after setting the new style? Or wait for the next frame.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: updateText
functions.description: Renders text to the internal canvas.

functions.name: renderTabLine
functions.description: Renders a line of text that contains tab characters if Text.tab > 0.Called automatically by updateText.

parameters.name: line
parameters.description: The line of text to render.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to start rendering from.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to start rendering from.

parameters.name: fill
parameters.description: If true uses fillText, if false uses strokeText.

functions.name: updateShadow
functions.description: Sets the Shadow on the Text.context based on the Style settings, or disables it if not enabled.This is called automatically by Text.updateText.

parameters.name: state
parameters.description: If true the shadow will be set to the Style values, otherwise it will be set to zero.

functions.name: measureLine
functions.description: Measures a line of text character by character taking into the account the specified character styles.

parameters.name: line
parameters.description: The line of text to measure.

returns.description: length of the line.

functions.name: updateLine
functions.description: Updates a line of text, applying fill and stroke per-character colors or style and weight per-character font if applicable.

functions.name: clearColors
functions.description: Clears any text fill or stroke colors that were set by `addColor` or `addStrokeColor`.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: clearFontValues
functions.description: Clears any text styles or weights font that were set by `addFontStyle` or `addFontWeight`.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: addColor
functions.description: Set specific colors for certain characters within the Text.It works by taking a color value, which is a typical HTML string such as `#ff0000` or `rgb(255,0,0)` and a position.The position value is the index of the character in the Text string to start applying this color to.Once set the color remains in use until either another color or the end of the string is encountered.For example if the Text was `Photon Storm` and you did `Text.addColor('#ffff00', 6)` it would color in the word `Storm` in yellow.If you wish to change the stroke color see addStrokeColor instead.

parameters.name: color
parameters.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg `red`, `#00FF00`, `rgba()`.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The index of the character in the string to start applying this color value from.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: addStrokeColor
functions.description: Set specific stroke colors for certain characters within the Text.It works by taking a color value, which is a typical HTML string such as `#ff0000` or `rgb(255,0,0)` and a position.The position value is the index of the character in the Text string to start applying this color to.Once set the color remains in use until either another color or the end of the string is encountered.For example if the Text was `Photon Storm` and you did `Text.addColor('#ffff00', 6)` it would color in the word `Storm` in yellow.This has no effect if stroke is disabled or has a thickness of 0.If you wish to change the text fill color see addColor instead.

parameters.name: color
parameters.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text stroke eg `red`, `#00FF00`, `rgba()`.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The index of the character in the string to start applying this color value from.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: addFontStyle
functions.description: Set specific font styles for certain characters within the Text.It works by taking a font style value, which is a typical string such as `normal`, `italic` or `oblique`.The position value is the index of the character in the Text string to start applying this font style to.Once set the font style remains in use until either another font style or the end of the string is encountered.For example if the Text was `Photon Storm` and you did `Text.addFontStyle('italic', 6)` it would font style in the word `Storm` in italic.If you wish to change the text font weight see addFontWeight instead.

parameters.name: style
parameters.description: A canvas font-style that will be used on the text style eg `normal`, `italic`, `oblique`.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The index of the character in the string to start applying this font style value from.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: addFontWeight
functions.description: Set specific font weights for certain characters within the Text.It works by taking a font weight value, which is a typical string such as `normal`, `bold`, `bolder`, etc.The position value is the index of the character in the Text string to start applying this font weight to.Once set the font weight remains in use until either another font weight or the end of the string is encountered.For example if the Text was `Photon Storm` and you did `Text.addFontWeight('bold', 6)` it would font weight in the word `Storm` in bold.If you wish to change the text font style see addFontStyle instead.

parameters.name: style
parameters.description: A canvas font-weight that will be used on the text weight eg `normal`, `bold`, `bolder`, `lighter`, etc.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The index of the character in the string to start applying this font weight value from.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: precalculateWordWrap
functions.description: Runs the given text through the Text.runWordWrap function and returnsthe results as an array, where each element of the array corresponds to a wrappedline of text.Useful if you wish to control pagination on long pieces of content.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The text for which the wrapping will be calculated.

returns.description: An array of strings with the pieces of wrapped text.

functions.name: runWordWrap
functions.description: Greedy wrapping algorithm that will wrap words as the line grows longer than its horizontal bounds.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The text to perform word wrap detection against.

functions.name: advancedWordWrap
functions.description: Advanced wrapping algorithm that will wrap words as the line grows longer than its horizontal bounds.White space is condensed (e.g., consecutive spaces are replaced with one).Lines are trimmed of white space before processing.Throws an error if the user was smart enough to specify a wordWrapWidth less than a single character.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The text to perform word wrap detection against.

functions.name: basicWordWrap
functions.description: Greedy wrapping algorithm that will wrap words as the line grows longer than its horizontal bounds.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The text to perform word wrap detection against.

functions.name: updateFont
functions.description: Updates the internal `style.font` if it now differs according to generation from components.

parameters.name: components
parameters.description: Font components.

functions.name: fontToComponents
functions.description: Converting a short CSS-font string into the relevant components.

parameters.name: font
parameters.description: a CSS font string

functions.name: componentsToFont
functions.description: Converts individual font components (see `fontToComponents`) to a short CSS font string.

parameters.name: components
parameters.description: Font components.

functions.name: setText
functions.description: The text to be displayed by this Text object.Use a \n to insert a carriage return and split the text.The text will be rendered with any style currently set.Use the optional `immediate` argument if you need the Text display to update immediately.If not it will re-create the texture of this Text object during the next time the renderloop is called.

parameters.name: text
parameters.description: The text to be displayed. Set to an empty string to clear text that is already present.

parameters.name: immediate
parameters.description: Update the texture used by this Text object immediately (true) or automatically during the next render loop (false).

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: parseList
functions.description: Converts the given array into a tab delimited string and then updates this Text object.This is mostly used when you want to display external data using tab stops.The array can be either single or multi dimensional depending on the result you need:`[ 'a', 'b', 'c' ]` would convert in to `"a\tb\tc"`.Where as:`[     [ 'a', 'b', 'c' ],     [ 'd', 'e', 'f']]`would convert in to: `"a\tb\tc\nd\te\tf"`

parameters.name: list
parameters.description: The array of data to convert into a string.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: setTextBounds
functions.description: The Text Bounds is a rectangular region that you control the dimensions of into which the Text object itself is positioned,regardless of the number of lines in the text, the font size or any other attribute.Alignment is controlled via the properties `boundsAlignH` and `boundsAlignV` within the Text.style object, or can be directlyset through the setters `Text.boundsAlignH` and `Text.boundsAlignV`. Bounds alignment is independent of text alignment.For example: If your game is 800x600 in size and you set the text bounds to be 0,0,800,600 then by setting boundsAlignH to'center' and boundsAlignV to 'bottom' the text will render in the center and at the bottom of your game window, regardless ofhow many lines of text there may be. Even if you adjust the text content or change the style it will remain at the bottom centerof the text bounds.This is especially powerful when you need to align text against specific coordinates in your game, but the actual text dimensionsmay vary based on font (say for multi-lingual games).If `Text.wordWrapWidth` is greater than the width of the text bounds it is clamped to match the bounds width.Call this method with no arguments given to reset an existing textBounds.It works by calculating the final position based on the Text.canvas size, which is modified as the text is updated. Some fontshave additional padding around them which you can mitigate by tweaking the Text.padding property. It then adjusts the `pivot`property based on the given bounds and canvas size. This means if you need to set the pivot property directly in your game thenyou either cannot use `setTextBounds` or you must place the Text object inside another DisplayObject on which you set the pivot.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the Text Bounds region.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the Text Bounds region.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the Text Bounds region.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the Text Bounds region.

returns.description: This Text instance.

functions.name: updateTexture
functions.description: Updates the texture based on the canvas dimensions.

functions.name: _renderWebGL
functions.description: Renders the object using the WebGL renderer

parameters.name: renderSession
parameters.description: The Render Session to render the Text on.

functions.name: _renderCanvas
functions.description: Renders the object using the Canvas renderer.

parameters.name: renderSession
parameters.description: The Render Session to render the Text on.

functions.name: determineFontProperties
functions.description: Calculates the ascent, descent and fontSize of a given font style.

functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: Returns the bounds of the Text as a rectangle.The bounds calculation takes the worldTransform into account.

parameters.name: matrix
parameters.description: The transformation matrix of the Text.

returns.description: The framing rectangle

functions.name: setCharacterLimit
functions.description: Sets the character limit of the text, with a suffix.If the text is longer than this limit, it is truncated and the suffix is appended.

parameters.name: characterLimit
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the Text Bounds region.

parameters.name: suffix
parameters.description: The suffix to append to the truncated text.

functions.name: setTexture
functions.description:
Sets the texture of the sprite. Be warned that this doesn't remove or destroy the previous
texture this Sprite was using.

parameters.name: texture
parameters.description: The PIXI texture that is displayed by the sprite

parameters.name: destroy
parameters.description: Call Texture.destroy on the current texture before replacing it with the new one?

functions.name: onTextureUpdate
functions.description: When the texture is updated, this event will fire to update the scale and frame

functions.name: getLocalBounds
functions.description: Retrieves the non-global local bounds of the Sprite as a rectangle. The calculation takes all visible children into consideration.

returns.description: The rectangular bounding area

functions.name: addChild
functions.description: Adds a child to the container.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to add to the container

returns.description: The child that was added.

functions.name: addChildAt
functions.description: Adds a child to the container at a specified index. If the index is out of bounds an error will be thrown

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child to add

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to place the child in

returns.description: The child that was added.

functions.name: swapChildren
functions.description: Swaps the position of 2 Display Objects within this container.

functions.name: getChildIndex
functions.description: Returns the index position of a child DisplayObject instance

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject instance to identify

returns.description: The index position of the child display object to identify

functions.name: setChildIndex
functions.description: Changes the position of an existing child in the display object container

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The child DisplayObject instance for which you want to change the index number

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The resulting index number for the child display object

functions.name: getChildAt
functions.description: Returns the child at the specified index

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to get the child from

returns.description: The child at the given index, if any.

functions.name: removeChild
functions.description: Removes a child from the container.

parameters.name: child
parameters.description: The DisplayObject to remove

returns.description: The child that was removed.

functions.name: removeChildAt
functions.description: Removes a child from the specified index position.

parameters.name: index
parameters.description: The index to get the child from

returns.description: The child that was removed.

functions.name: removeChildren
functions.description: Removes all children from this container that are within the begin and end indexes.

parameters.name: beginIndex
parameters.description: The beginning position. Default value is 0.

parameters.name: endIndex
parameters.description: The ending position. Default value is size of the container.

functions.name: contains
functions.description: Determines whether the specified display object is a child of the DisplayObjectContainer instance or the instance itself.

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: Internal method called by the World postUpdate cycle.

functions.name: play
functions.description: Plays an Animation.The animation should have previously been created via `animations.add`.If the animation is already playing calling this again won't do anything.If you need to reset an already running animation do so directly on the Animation object itself or via `AnimationManager.stop`.

parameters.name: name
parameters.description: The name of the animation to be played, e.g. "fire", "walk", "jump". Must have been previously created via 'AnimationManager.add'.

parameters.name: frameRate
parameters.description: The framerate to play the animation at. The speed is given in frames per second. If not provided the previously set frameRate of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: loop
parameters.description: Should the animation be looped after playback. If not provided the previously set loop value of the Animation is used.

parameters.name: killOnComplete
parameters.description: If set to true when the animation completes (only happens if loop=false) the parent Sprite will be killed.

returns.description: A reference to playing Animation.

functions.name: alignIn
functions.description: Aligns this Game Object within another Game Object, or Rectangle, known as the'container', to one of 9 possible positions.The container must be a Game Object, or Phaser.Rectangle object. This can include propertiessuch as `World.bounds` or `Camera.view`, for aligning Game Objects within the world and camera bounds. Or it can include other Sprites, Images, Text objects, BitmapText,TileSprites or Buttons.Please note that aligning a Sprite to another Game Object does **not** make it a child ofthe container. It simply modifies its position coordinates so it aligns with it.The position constants you can use are:`Phaser.TOP_LEFT`, `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` and `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.The Game Objects are placed in such a way that their _bounds_ align with thecontainer, taking into consideration rotation, scale and the anchor property.This allows you to neatly align Game Objects, irrespective of their position value.The optional `offsetX` and `offsetY` arguments allow you to apply extra spacing to the finalaligned position of the Game Object. For example:`sprite.alignIn(background, Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT, -20, -20)`Would align the `sprite` to the bottom-right, but moved 20 pixels in from the corner.Think of the offsets as applying an adjustment to the containers bounds before the alignment takes place.So providing a negative offset will 'shrink' the container bounds by that amount, and providing a positiveone expands it.

parameters.name: container
parameters.description: The Game Object or Rectangle with which to align this Game Object to. Can also include properties such as `World.bounds` or `Camera.view`.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The position constant. One of `Phaser.TOP_LEFT` (default), `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` or `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: A horizontal adjustment of the Containers bounds, applied to the aligned position of the Game Object. Use a negative value to shrink the bounds, positive to increase it.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: A vertical adjustment of the Containers bounds, applied to the aligned position of the Game Object. Use a negative value to shrink the bounds, positive to increase it.

returns.description: This Game Object.

functions.name: alignTo
functions.description: Aligns this Game Object to the side of another Game Object, or Rectangle, known as the'parent', in one of 11 possible positions.The parent must be a Game Object, or Phaser.Rectangle object. This can include propertiessuch as `World.bounds` or `Camera.view`, for aligning Game Objects within the world and camera bounds. Or it can include other Sprites, Images, Text objects, BitmapText,TileSprites or Buttons.Please note that aligning a Sprite to another Game Object does **not** make it a child ofthe parent. It simply modifies its position coordinates so it aligns with it.The position constants you can use are:`Phaser.TOP_LEFT` (default), `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_TOP`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.LEFT_BOTTOM`, `Phaser.RIGHT_TOP`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_BOTTOM`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` and `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.The Game Objects are placed in such a way that their _bounds_ align with theparent, taking into consideration rotation, scale and the anchor property.This allows you to neatly align Game Objects, irrespective of their position value.The optional `offsetX` and `offsetY` arguments allow you to apply extra spacing to the finalaligned position of the Game Object. For example:`sprite.alignTo(background, Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT, -20, -20)`Would align the `sprite` to the bottom-right, but moved 20 pixels in from the corner.Think of the offsets as applying an adjustment to the parents bounds before the alignment takes place.So providing a negative offset will 'shrink' the parent bounds by that amount, and providing a positiveone expands it.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The Game Object or Rectangle with which to align this Game Object to. Can also include properties such as `World.bounds` or `Camera.view`.

parameters.name: position
parameters.description: The position constant. One of `Phaser.TOP_LEFT`, `Phaser.TOP_CENTER`, `Phaser.TOP_RIGHT`, `Phaser.LEFT_TOP`, `Phaser.LEFT_CENTER`, `Phaser.LEFT_BOTTOM`, `Phaser.RIGHT_TOP`, `Phaser.RIGHT_CENTER`, `Phaser.RIGHT_BOTTOM`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_LEFT`, `Phaser.BOTTOM_CENTER` or `Phaser.BOTTOM_RIGHT`.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: A horizontal adjustment of the Containers bounds, applied to the aligned position of the Game Object. Use a negative value to shrink the bounds, positive to increase it.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: A vertical adjustment of the Containers bounds, applied to the aligned position of the Game Object. Use a negative value to shrink the bounds, positive to increase it.

returns.description: This Game Object.

functions.name: bringToTop
functions.description: Brings this Game Object to the top of its parents display list.Visually this means it will render over the top of any old child in the same Group.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will bring it to the top of the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: sendToBack
functions.description: Sends this Game Object to the bottom of its parents display list.Visually this means it will render below all other children in the same Group.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will send it to the bottom of the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: moveUp
functions.description: Moves this Game Object up one place in its parents display list.This call has no effect if the Game Object is already at the top of the display list.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will move it one object up within the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: moveDown
functions.description: Moves this Game Object down one place in its parents display list.This call has no effect if the Game Object is already at the bottom of the display list.If this Game Object hasn't been added to a custom Group then this method will move it one object down within the Game World, because the World is the root Group from which all Game Objects descend.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: crop
functions.description: Crop allows you to crop the texture being used to display this Game Object.Setting a crop rectangle modifies the core texture frame. The Game Object width and height properties will be adjusted accordingly.Cropping takes place from the top-left and can be modified in real-time either by providing an updated rectangle object to this method,or by modifying `cropRect` property directly and then calling `updateCrop`.The rectangle object given to this method can be either a `Phaser.Rectangle` or any other object so long as it has public `x`, `y`, `width`, `height`, `right` and `bottom` properties.A reference to the rectangle is stored in `cropRect` unless the `copy` parameter is `true`, in which case the values are duplicated to a local object.

parameters.name: rect
parameters.description: The Rectangle used during cropping. Pass null or no parameters to clear a previously set crop rectangle.

parameters.name: copy
parameters.description: If false `cropRect` will be stored as a reference to the given rect. If true it will copy the rect values into a local Phaser Rectangle object stored in cropRect.

functions.name: updateCrop
functions.description: If you have set a crop rectangle on this Game Object via `crop` and since modified the `cropRect` property,or the rectangle it references, then you need to update the crop frame by calling this method.

functions.name: revive
functions.description: Brings a 'dead' Game Object back to life, optionally resetting its health value in the process.A resurrected Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to true.It will dispatch the `onRevived` event. Listen to `events.onRevived` for the signal.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object. Only set if the GameObject has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: kill
functions.description: Kills a Game Object. A killed Game Object has its `alive`, `exists` and `visible` properties all set to false.It will dispatch the `onKilled` event. You can listen to `events.onKilled` for the signal.Note that killing a Game Object is a way for you to quickly recycle it in an object pool,it doesn't destroy the object or free it up from memory.If you don't need this Game Object any more you should call `destroy` instead.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: loadTexture
functions.description: Changes the base texture the Game Object is using. The old texture is removed and the new one is referenced or fetched from the Cache.If your Game Object is using a frame from a texture atlas and you just wish to change to another frame, then see the `frame` or `frameName` properties instead.You should only use `loadTexture` if you want to replace the base texture entirely.Calling this method causes a WebGL texture update, so use sparingly or in low-intensity portions of your game, or if you know the new texture is already on the GPU.You can use the new const `Phaser.PENDING_ATLAS` as the texture key for any sprite. Doing this then sets the key to be the `frame` argument (the frame is set to zero). This allows you to create sprites using `load.image` during development, and then change them to use a Texture Atlas later in development by simply searching your code for 'PENDING_ATLAS' and swapping it to be the key of the atlas data.Note: You cannot use a RenderTexture as a texture for a TileSprite.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: This is the image or texture used by the Sprite during rendering. It can be a string which is a reference to the Cache Image entry, or an instance of a RenderTexture, BitmapData, Video or PIXI.Texture.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: If this Sprite is using part of a sprite sheet or texture atlas you can specify the exact frame to use by giving a string or numeric index.

parameters.name: stopAnimation
parameters.description: If an animation is already playing on this Sprite you can choose to stop it or let it carry on playing.

functions.name: setFrame
functions.description: Sets the texture frame the Game Object uses for rendering.This is primarily an internal method used by `loadTexture`, but is exposed for the use of plugins and custom classes.

parameters.name: frame
parameters.description: The Frame to be used by the texture.

functions.name: resizeFrame
functions.description: Resizes the Frame dimensions that the Game Object uses for rendering.You shouldn't normally need to ever call this, but in the case of special texture types such as Video or BitmapDatait can be useful to adjust the dimensions directly in this way.

parameters.name: parent
parameters.description: The parent texture object that caused the resize, i.e. a Phaser.Video object.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The new width of the texture.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The new height of the texture.

functions.name: resetFrame
functions.description: Resets the texture frame dimensions that the Game Object uses for rendering.

functions.name: overlap
functions.description: Checks to see if the bounds of this Game Object overlaps with the bounds of the given Display Object, which can be a Sprite, Image, TileSprite or anything that extends those such as Button or provides a `getBounds` method and result.This check ignores the `hitArea` property if set and runs a `getBounds` comparison on both objects to determine the result.Therefore it's relatively expensive to use in large quantities, i.e. with lots of Sprites at a high frequency.It should be fine for low-volume testing where physics isn't required.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The display object to check against.

returns.description: True if the bounds of this Game Object intersects at any point with the bounds of the given display object.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets the Game Object.This moves the Game Object to the given x/y world coordinates and sets `fresh`, `exists`, `visible` and `renderable` to true.If this Game Object has the LifeSpan component it will also set `alive` to true and `health` to the given value.If this Game Object has a Physics Body it will reset the Body.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate (in world space) to position the Game Object at.

parameters.name: health
parameters.description: The health to give the Game Object if it has the Health component.

returns.description: This instance.

functions.name: checkTransform
functions.description: Adjust scaling limits, if set, to this Game Object.

parameters.name: wt
parameters.description: The updated worldTransform matrix.

functions.name: setScaleMinMax
functions.description: Sets the scaleMin and scaleMax values. These values are used to limit how far this Game Object will scale based on its parent.For example if this Game Object has a `minScale` value of 1 and its parent has a `scale` value of 0.5, the 0.5 will be ignored and the scale value of 1 will be used, as the parents scale is lower than the minimum scale this Game Object should adhere to.By setting these values you can carefully control how Game Objects deal with responsive scaling.If only one parameter is given then that value will be used for both scaleMin and scaleMax:`setScaleMinMax(1)` = scaleMin.x, scaleMin.y, scaleMax.x and scaleMax.y all = 1If only two parameters are given the first is set as scaleMin.x and y and the second as scaleMax.x and y:`setScaleMinMax(0.5, 2)` = scaleMin.x and y = 0.5 and scaleMax.x and y = 2If you wish to set `scaleMin` with different values for x and y then either modify Game Object.scaleMin directly, or pass `null` for the `maxX` and `maxY` parameters.Call `setScaleMinMax(null)` to clear all previously set values.

parameters.name: minX
parameters.description: The minimum horizontal scale value this Game Object can scale down to.

parameters.name: minY
parameters.description: The minimum vertical scale value this Game Object can scale down to.

parameters.name: maxX
parameters.description: The maximum horizontal scale value this Game Object can scale up to.

parameters.name: maxY
parameters.description: The maximum vertical scale value this Game Object can scale up to.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: physicsType
members.description: The const physics body type of this object.

members.name: padding
members.description: Specify a padding value which is added to the line width and height when calculating the Text size.ALlows you to add extra spacing if Phaser is unable to accurately determine the true font dimensions.

members.name: textBounds
members.description: The textBounds property allows you to specify a rectangular region upon which text alignment is based.See `Text.setTextBounds` for more details.

members.name: canvas
members.description: The canvas element that the text is rendered.

members.name: context
members.description: The context of the canvas element that the text is rendered to.

members.name: colors
members.description: An array of the color values as specified by {@link Phaser.Text#addColor addColor}.

members.name: strokeColors
members.description: An array of the stroke color values as specified by {@link Phaser.Text#addStrokeColor addStrokeColor}.

members.name: fontStyles
members.description: An array of the font styles values as specified by {@link Phaser.Text#addFontStyle addFontStyle}.

members.name: fontWeights
members.description: An array of the font weights values as specified by {@link Phaser.Text#addFontWeight addFontWeight}.

members.name: autoRound
members.description: Should the linePositionX and Y values be automatically rounded before rendering the Text?You may wish to enable this if you want to remove the effect of sub-pixel aliasing from text.

members.name: useAdvancedWrap
members.description: Will this Text object use Basic or Advanced Word Wrapping?Advanced wrapping breaks long words if they are the first of a line, and repeats the process as necessary.White space is condensed (e.g., consecutive spaces are replaced with one).Lines are trimmed of white space before processing.It throws an error if wordWrapWidth is less than a single character.

members.name: splitRegExp
members.description: The Regular Expression that is used to split the text up into lines, inmulti-line text. By default this is `/(?:\r\n|\r|\n)/`.You can change this RegExp to be anything else that you may need.

members.name: characterLimitSize
members.description: The maximum number of characters that can be set.

members.name: characterLimitSuffix
members.description: The suffix that is applied to truncated text that is longer than thecharacterLimitSize.

members.name: _res
members.description: Internal canvas resolution var.

members.name: _text
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: _fontComponents
members.description: The font, broken down into components, set in `setStyle`.

members.name: _lineSpacing
members.description: Additional spacing (in pixels) between each line of text if multi-line.

members.name: _charCount
members.description: Internal character counter used by the text coloring.

members.name: _width
members.description: Internal width var.

members.name: _height
members.description: Internal height var.

members.name: text
members.description: The text to be displayed by this Text object.Use a \n to insert a carriage return and split the text.The text will be rendered with any style currently set.

members.name: cssFont
members.description: Change the font used.This is equivalent of the `font` property specified to {@link Phaser.Text#setStyle setStyle}, exceptthat unlike using `setStyle` this will not change any current font fill/color settings.The CSS font string can also be individually altered with the `font`, `fontSize`, `fontWeight`, `fontStyle`, and `fontVariant` properties.

members.name: font
members.description: Change the font family that the text will be rendered in, such as 'Arial'.Multiple CSS font families and generic fallbacks can be specified as long as{@link http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#propdef-font-family CSS font-family rules} are followed.To change the entire font string use {@link Phaser.Text#cssFont cssFont} instead: eg. `text.cssFont = 'bold 20pt Arial'`.

members.name: fontSize
members.description: The size of the font.If the font size is specified in pixels (eg. `32` or `'32px`') then a number (ie. `32`) representingthe font size in pixels is returned; otherwise the value with CSS unit is returned as a string (eg. `'12pt'`).

members.name: fontWeight
members.description: The weight of the font: 'normal', 'bold', or {@link http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/fonts.html#propdef-font-weight a valid CSS font weight}.

members.name: fontStyle
members.description: The style of the font: 'normal', 'italic', 'oblique'

members.name: fontVariant
members.description: The variant the font: 'normal', 'small-caps'

members.name: fill
members.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text eg 'red', '#00FF00'.

members.name: align
members.description: Controls the horizontal alignment for multiline text.Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'.Does not affect single lines of text. For that please see `setTextBounds`.

members.name: resolution
members.description: The resolution of the canvas the text is rendered to.This defaults to match the resolution of the renderer, but can be changed on a per Text object basis.

members.name: tabs
members.description: The size (in pixels) of the tabs, for when text includes tab characters. 0 disables. Can be an integer or an array of varying tab sizes, one tab per element.For example if you set tabs to 100 then when Text encounters a tab it will jump ahead 100 pixels.If you set tabs to be `[100,200]` then it will set the first tab at 100px and the second at 200px.

members.name: boundsAlignH
members.description: Horizontal alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'left', 'center' or 'right'.

members.name: boundsAlignV
members.description: Vertical alignment of the text within the `textBounds`. Can be: 'top', 'middle' or 'bottom'.

members.name: stroke
members.description: A canvas fillstyle that will be used on the text stroke eg 'blue', '#FCFF00'.

members.name: strokeThickness
members.description: A number that represents the thickness of the stroke. Default is 0 (no stroke)

members.name: wordWrap
members.description: Indicates if word wrap should be used.

members.name: wordWrapWidth
members.description: The width at which text will wrap.

members.name: lineSpacing
members.description: Additional spacing (in pixels) between each line of text if multi-line.

members.name: shadowOffsetX
members.description: The shadowOffsetX value in pixels. This is how far offset horizontally the shadow effect will be.

members.name: shadowOffsetY
members.description: The shadowOffsetY value in pixels. This is how far offset vertically the shadow effect will be.

members.name: shadowColor
members.description: The color of the shadow, as given in CSS rgba format. Set the alpha component to 0 to disable the shadow.

members.name: shadowBlur
members.description: The shadowBlur value. Make the shadow softer by applying a Gaussian blur to it. A number from 0 (no blur) up to approx. 10 (depending on scene).

members.name: shadowStroke
members.description: Sets if the drop shadow is applied to the Text stroke.

members.name: shadowFill
members.description: Sets if the drop shadow is applied to the Text fill.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of the Text object in pixels. This is width of the Texture frame / the Text.resolution. The width of the Text. Setting this will modify the scale to achieve the value requested.

members.name: height
members.description: The height of the Text object in pixels. This is height of the Texture frame / the Text.resolution. The height of the Text. Setting this will modify the scale to achieve the value requested.

members.name: anchor
members.description:
The anchor sets the origin point of the texture.
The default is 0,0 this means the texture's origin is the top left
Setting than anchor to 0.5,0.5 means the textures origin is centered
Setting the anchor to 1,1 would mean the textures origin points will be the bottom right corner

members.name: texture
members.description: The texture that the sprite is using

members.name: tint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: cachedTint
members.description: The tint applied to the sprite. This is a hex value. A value of 0xFFFFFF will remove any tint effect.

members.name: tintedTexture
members.description: A canvas that contains the tinted version of the Sprite (in Canvas mode, WebGL doesn't populate this)

members.name: blendMode
members.description:
The blend mode to be applied to the sprite. Set to PIXI.blendModes.NORMAL to remove any blend mode.

Warning: You cannot have a blend mode and a filter active on the same Sprite. Doing so will render the sprite invisible.

members.name: shader
members.description:
The shader that will be used to render this Sprite.
Set to null to remove a current shader.

members.name: exists
members.description: Controls if this Sprite is processed by the core Phaser game loops and Group loops.

members.name: children
members.description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

members.name: ignoreChildInput
members.description:
If `ignoreChildInput`  is `false` it will allow this objects _children_ to be considered as valid for Input events.

If this property is `true` then the children will _not_ be considered as valid for Input events.

Note that this property isn't recursive: only immediate children are influenced, it doesn't scan further down.

members.name: position
members.description:
The coordinates, in pixels, of this DisplayObject, relative to its parent container.

The value of this property does not reflect any positioning happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldPosition` property.

members.name: scale
members.description:
The scale of this DisplayObject. A scale of 1:1 represents the DisplayObject
at its default size. A value of 0.5 would scale this DisplayObject by half, and so on.

The value of this property does not reflect any scaling happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldScale` property.

members.name: pivot
members.description:
The pivot point of this DisplayObject that it rotates around. The values are expressed
in pixel values.

members.name: rotation
members.description:
The rotation of this DisplayObject. The value is given, and expressed, in radians, and is based on
a right-handed orientation.

The value of this property does not reflect any rotation happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldRotation` property.

members.name: alpha
members.description:
The alpha value of this DisplayObject. A value of 1 is fully opaque. A value of 0 is transparent.
Please note that an object with an alpha value of 0 is skipped during the render pass.

The value of this property does not reflect any alpha values set further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldAlpha` property.

members.name: visible
members.description:
The visibility of this DisplayObject. A value of `false` makes the object invisible.
A value of `true` makes it visible. Please note that an object with a visible value of
`false` is skipped during the render pass. Equally a DisplayObject with visible false will
not render any of its children.

The value of this property does not reflect any visible values set further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldVisible` property.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: renderable
members.description:
Should this DisplayObject be rendered by the renderer? An object with a renderable value of
`false` is skipped during the render pass.

members.name: parent
members.description:
The parent DisplayObjectContainer that this DisplayObject is a child of.
All DisplayObjects must belong to a parent in order to be rendered.
The root parent is the Stage object. This property is set automatically when the
DisplayObject is added to, or removed from, a DisplayObjectContainer.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description:
The multiplied alpha value of this DisplayObject. A value of 1 is fully opaque. A value of 0 is transparent.
