functions.description: Internal handler called automatically by the Video.paused setter.

functions.name: setResume
functions.description: Internal handler called automatically by the Video.paused setter.

functions.name: changeSource
functions.description: On some mobile browsers you cannot play a video until the user has explicitly touched the video to allow it.Phaser handles this via the `setTouchLock` method. However if you have 3 different videos, maybe an "Intro", "Start" and "Game Over"split into three different Video objects, then you will need the user to touch-unlock every single one of them.You can avoid this by using just one Video object and simply changing the video source. Once a Video element is unlocked it remainsunlocked, even if the source changes. So you can use this to your benefit to avoid forcing the user to 'touch' the video yet again.As you'd expect there are limitations. So far we've found that the videos need to be in the same encoding format and bitrate.This method will automatically handle a change in video dimensions, but if you try swapping to a different bitrate we've found itcannot render the new video on iOS (desktop browsers cope better).When the video source is changed the video file is requested over the network. Listen for the `onChangeSource` signal to knowwhen the new video has downloaded enough content to be able to be played. Previous settings such as the volume and loop stateare adopted automatically by the new video.

parameters.name: src
parameters.description: The new URL to change the video.src to.

parameters.name: autoplay
parameters.description: Should the video play automatically after the source has been updated?

returns.description: This Video object for method chaining.

functions.name: checkVideoProgress
functions.description: Internal callback that monitors the download progress of a video after changing its source.

functions.name: setTouchLock
functions.description: Sets the Input Manager touch callback to be Video.unlock.Required for mobile video unlocking. Mostly just used internally.

functions.name: unlock
functions.description: Enables the video on mobile devices, usually after the first touch.If the SoundManager hasn't been unlocked then this will automatically unlock that as well.Only one video can be pending unlock at any one time.

functions.name: grab
functions.description: Grabs the current frame from the Video or Video Stream and renders it to the Video.snapshot BitmapData.You can optionally set if the BitmapData should be cleared or not, the alpha and the blend mode of the draw.If you need more advanced control over the grabbing them call `Video.snapshot.copy` directly with the same parameters as BitmapData.copy.

parameters.name: clear
parameters.description: Should the BitmapData be cleared before the Video is grabbed? Unless you are using alpha or a blend mode you can usually leave this set to false.

parameters.name: alpha
parameters.description: The alpha that will be set on the video before drawing. A value between 0 (fully transparent) and 1, opaque.

parameters.name: blendMode
parameters.description: The composite blend mode that will be used when drawing. The default is no blend mode at all. This is a Canvas globalCompositeOperation value such as 'lighter' or 'xor'.

returns.description: A reference to the Video.snapshot BitmapData object for further method chaining.

functions.name: removeVideoElement
functions.description: Removes the Video element from the DOM by calling parentNode.removeChild on itself.Also removes the autoplay and src attributes and nulls the reference.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys the Video object. This calls `Video.stop` and then `Video.removeVideoElement`.If any Sprites are using this Video as their texture it is up to you to manage those.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running game.

members.name: key
members.description: The key of the Video in the Cache, if stored there. Will be `null` if this Video is using the webcam instead.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of the video in pixels.

members.name: height
members.description: The height of the video in pixels.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: disableTextureUpload
members.description: If true this video will never send its image data to the GPU when its dirty flag is true. This only applies in WebGL.

members.name: touchLocked
members.description: true if this video is currently locked awaiting a touch event. This happens on some mobile devices, such as iOS.

members.name: onPlay
members.description: This signal is dispatched when the Video starts to play. It sends 3 parameters: a reference to the Video object, if the video is set to loop or not and the playback rate.

members.name: onChangeSource
members.description: This signal is dispatched if the Video source is changed. It sends 3 parameters: a reference to the Video object and the new width and height of the new video source.

members.name: onComplete
members.description: This signal is dispatched when the Video completes playback, i.e. enters an 'ended' state. On iOS specifically it also fires if the user hits the 'Done' button at any point during playback. Videos set to loop will never dispatch this signal.

members.name: onAccess
members.description: This signal is dispatched if the user allows access to their webcam.

members.name: onError
members.description: This signal is dispatched if an error occurs either getting permission to use the webcam (for a Video Stream) or when trying to play back a video file.

members.name: onTimeout
members.description: This signal is dispatched if when asking for permission to use the webcam no response is given within a the Video.timeout limit.This may be because the user has picked `Not now` in the permissions window, or there is a delay in establishing the LocalMediaStream.

members.name: timeout
members.description: The amount of ms allowed to elapsed before the Video.onTimeout signal is dispatched while waiting for webcam access.

members.name: _timeOutID
members.description: setTimeout ID.

members.name: video
members.description: The HTML Video Element that is added to the document.

members.name: videoStream
members.description: The Video Stream data. Only set if this Video is streaming from the webcam via `startMediaStream`.

members.name: isStreaming
members.description: Is there a streaming video source? I.e. from a webcam.

members.name: retryLimit
members.description: When starting playback of a video Phaser will monitor its readyState using a setTimeout call.The setTimeout happens once every `Video.retryInterval` ms. It will carry on monitoring the videostate in this manner until the `retryLimit` is reached and then abort.

members.name: retry
members.description: The current retry attempt.

members.name: retryInterval
members.description: The number of ms between each retry at monitoring the status of a downloading video.

members.name: _retryID
members.description: The callback ID of the retry setTimeout.

members.name: _codeMuted
members.description: Internal mute tracking var.

members.name: _muted
members.description: Internal mute tracking var.

members.name: _codePaused
members.description: Internal paused tracking var.

members.name: _paused
members.description: Internal paused tracking var.

members.name: _pending
members.description: Internal var tracking play pending.

members.name: _pendingChangeSource
members.description: Internal var tracking play pending.

members.name: _autoplay
members.description: Internal var tracking autoplay when changing source.

members.name: _endCallback
members.description: The addEventListener ended function.

members.name: _playCallback
members.description: The addEventListener playing function.

members.name: texture
members.description: The PIXI.Texture.

members.name: textureFrame
members.description: The Frame this video uses for rendering.

members.name: snapshot
members.description: A snapshot grabbed from the video. This is initially black. Populate it by calling Video.grab().When called the BitmapData is updated with a grab taken from the current video playing or active video stream.If Phaser has been compiled without BitmapData support this property will always be `null`.

members.name: currentTime
members.description: The current time of the video in seconds. If set the video will attempt to seek to that point in time.

members.name: duration
members.description: The duration of the video in seconds.

members.name: progress
members.description: The progress of this video. This is a value between 0 and 1, where 0 is the start and 1 is the end of the video.

members.name: mute
members.description: Gets or sets the muted state of the Video.

members.name: paused
members.description: Gets or sets the paused state of the Video.If the video is still touch locked (such as on iOS devices) this call has no effect.

members.name: volume
members.description: Gets or sets the volume of the Video, a value between 0 and 1. The value given is clamped to the range 0 to 1.

members.name: playbackRate
members.description: Gets or sets the playback rate of the Video. This is the speed at which the video is playing.

members.name: loop
members.description: Gets or sets if the Video is set to loop.Please note that at present some browsers (i.e. Chrome) do not support *seamless* video looping.If the video isn't yet set this will always return false.

members.name: playing
members.description: True if the video is currently playing (and not paused or ended), otherwise false.

classes.name: Phaser.Circle
classes.description: Creates a new Circle object with the center coordinate specified by the x and y parameters and the diameter specified by the diameter parameter.If you call this function without parameters, a circle with x, y, diameter and radius properties set to 0 is created.

constructor.name: Circle
constructor.description: Creates a new Circle object with the center coordinate specified by the x and y parameters and the diameter specified by the diameter parameter.If you call this function without parameters, a circle with x, y, diameter and radius properties set to 0 is created.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: diameter
parameters.description: The diameter of the circle.

functions.name: circumference
functions.description: The circumference of the circle.

returns.description: The circumference of the circle.

functions.name: random
functions.description: Returns a uniformly distributed random point from anywhere within this Circle.

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: A Phaser.Point, or any object with public x/y properties, that the values will be set in.    If no object is provided a new Phaser.Point object will be created. In high performance areas avoid this by re-using an existing object.

returns.description: An object containing the random point in its `x` and `y` properties.

functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: Returns the framing rectangle of the circle as a Phaser.Rectangle object.

returns.description: The bounds of the Circle.

functions.name: setTo
functions.description: Sets the members of Circle to the specified values.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

parameters.name: diameter
parameters.description: The diameter of the circle.

returns.description: This circle object.

functions.name: copyFrom
functions.description: Copies the x, y and diameter properties from any given object to this Circle.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The object to copy from.

returns.description: This Circle object.

functions.name: copyTo
functions.description: Copies the x, y and diameter properties from this Circle to any given object.

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: The object to copy to.

returns.description: This dest object.

functions.name: distance
functions.description: Returns the distance from the center of the Circle object to the given object(can be Circle, Point or anything with x/y properties)

parameters.name: dest
parameters.description: The target object. Must have visible x and y properties that represent the center of the object.

parameters.name: round
parameters.description: Round the distance to the nearest integer.

returns.description: The distance between this Point object and the destination Point object.

functions.name: clone
functions.description: Returns a new Circle object with the same values for the x, y, width, and height properties as this Circle object.

parameters.name: output
parameters.description: Optional Circle object. If given the values will be set into the object, otherwise a brand new Circle object will be created and returned.

returns.description: The cloned Circle object.

functions.name: contains
functions.description: Return true if the given x/y coordinates are within this Circle object.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The X value of the coordinate to test.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The Y value of the coordinate to test.

returns.description: True if the coordinates are within this circle, otherwise false.

functions.name: circumferencePoint
functions.description: Returns a Point object containing the coordinates of a point on the circumference of the Circle based on the given angle.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to return the point from.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: An optional Point object to put the result in to. If none specified a new Point object will be created.

returns.description: The Point object holding the result.

functions.name: offset
functions.description: Adjusts the location of the Circle object, as determined by its center coordinate, by the specified amounts.

parameters.name: dx
parameters.description: Moves the x value of the Circle object by this amount.

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: Moves the y value of the Circle object by this amount.

returns.description: This Circle object.

functions.name: offsetPoint
functions.description: Adjusts the location of the Circle object using a Point object as a parameter. This method is similar to the Circle.offset() method, except that it takes a Point object as a parameter.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: A Point object to use to offset this Circle object (or any valid object with exposed x and y properties).

returns.description: This Circle object.

functions.name: toString
functions.description: Returns a string representation of this object.

returns.description: a string representation of the instance.

functions.name: contains
functions.description: Return true if the given x/y coordinates are within the Circle object.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The Circle to be checked.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The X value of the coordinate to test.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The Y value of the coordinate to test.

returns.description: True if the coordinates are within this circle, otherwise false.

functions.name: equals
functions.description: Determines whether the two Circle objects match. This method compares the x, y and diameter properties.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first Circle object.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second Circle object.

returns.description: A value of true if the object has exactly the same values for the x, y and diameter properties as this Circle object; otherwise false.

functions.name: intersects
functions.description: Determines whether the two Circle objects intersect.This method checks the radius distances between the two Circle objects to see if they intersect.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first Circle object.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second Circle object.

returns.description: A value of true if the specified object intersects with this Circle object; otherwise false.

functions.name: circumferencePoint
functions.description: Returns a Point object containing the coordinates of a point on the circumference of the Circle based on the given angle.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first Circle object.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to return the point from.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: An optional Point object to put the result in to. If none specified a new Point object will be created.

returns.description: The Point object holding the result.

functions.name: intersectsRectangle
functions.description: Checks if the given Circle and Rectangle objects intersect.

parameters.name: c
parameters.description: The Circle object to test.

parameters.name: r
parameters.description: The Rectangle object to test.

returns.description: True if the two objects intersect, otherwise false.

members.name: x
members.description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

members.name: y
members.description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

members.name: _diameter
members.description: The diameter of the circle.

members.name: _radius
members.description: The radius of the circle.

members.name: type
members.description: The const type of this object.

members.name: diameter
members.description: The largest distance between any two points on the circle. The same as the radius * 2. Gets or sets the diameter of the circle.

members.name: radius
members.description: The length of a line extending from the center of the circle to any point on the circle itself. The same as half the diameter. Gets or sets the radius of the circle.

members.name: left
members.description: The x coordinate of the leftmost point of the circle. Changing the left property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties. However it does affect the diameter, whereas changing the x value does not affect the diameter property.

members.name: right
members.description: The x coordinate of the rightmost point of the circle. Changing the right property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties. However it does affect the diameter, whereas changing the x value does not affect the diameter property. Gets or sets the value of the rightmost point of the circle.

members.name: top
members.description: The sum of the y minus the radius property. Changing the top property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties, but does change the diameter. Gets or sets the top of the circle.

members.name: bottom
members.description: The sum of the y and radius properties. Changing the bottom property of a Circle object has no effect on the x and y properties, but does change the diameter. Gets or sets the bottom of the circle.

members.name: area
members.description: The area of this Circle.

members.name: empty
members.description: Determines whether or not this Circle object is empty. Will return a value of true if the Circle objects diameter is less than or equal to 0; otherwise false.If set to true it will reset all of the Circle objects properties to 0. A Circle object is empty if its diameter is less than or equal to 0. Gets or sets the empty state of the circle.

classes.name: Phaser.Hermite
classes.description: A data representation of a Hermite Curve (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_Hermite_spline)A Hermite curve has a start and end point and tangent vectors for both of them.The curve will always pass through the two control points and the shape of it is controlledby the length and direction of the tangent vectors.  At the control points the curve willbe facing exactly in the vector direction.As these curves change speed (speed = distance between points separated by an equal change in't' value - see Hermite.getPoint) this class attempts to reduce the variation by pre-calculatingthe `accuracy` number of points on the curve. The straight-line distances to these points are storedin the private 'points' array, and this information is used by Hermite.findT() to convert a pixeldistance along the curve into a 'time' value.Higher `accuracy` values will result in more even movement, but require more memory for the pointslist. 5 works, but 10 seems to be an ideal value for the length of curves found in most games ona desktop screen. If you use very long curves (more than 400 pixels) you may need to increasethis value further.

constructor.name: Hermite
constructor.description: A data representation of a Hermite Curve (see http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cubic_Hermite_spline)A Hermite curve has a start and end point and tangent vectors for both of them.The curve will always pass through the two control points and the shape of it is controlledby the length and direction of the tangent vectors.  At the control points the curve willbe facing exactly in the vector direction.As these curves change speed (speed = distance between points separated by an equal change in't' value - see Hermite.getPoint) this class attempts to reduce the variation by pre-calculatingthe `accuracy` number of points on the curve. The straight-line distances to these points are storedin the private 'points' array, and this information is used by Hermite.findT() to convert a pixeldistance along the curve into a 'time' value.Higher `accuracy` values will result in more even movement, but require more memory for the pointslist. 5 works, but 10 seems to be an ideal value for the length of curves found in most games ona desktop screen. If you use very long curves (more than 400 pixels) you may need to increasethis value further.

parameters.name: p1x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the start of the curve.

parameters.name: p1y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the start of the curve.

parameters.name: p2x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the end of the curve.

parameters.name: p2y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the end of the curve.

parameters.name: v1x
parameters.description: The x component of the tangent vector for the start of the curve.

parameters.name: v1y
parameters.description: The y component of the tangent vector for the start of the curve.

parameters.name: v2x
parameters.description: The x component of the tangent vector for the end of the curve.

parameters.name: v2y
parameters.description: The y component of the tangent vector for the end of the curve.

parameters.name: accuracy
parameters.description: The amount of points to pre-calculate on the curve.

functions.name: recalculate
functions.description: Performs the curve calculations.This is called automatically if you change any of the curves public properties, such as `Hermite.p1x` or `Hermite.v2y`.If you adjust any of the internal private values, then call this to update the points.

returns.description: This object.

functions.name: calculateEvenPoints
functions.description: Calculate a number of points along the curve, based on `Hermite.accuracy`, and stores them in the private `_points` array.

returns.description: The total length of the curve approximated as straight line distances between the points.

functions.name: findT
functions.description: Convert a distance along this curve into a `time` value which will be between 0 and 1.For example if this curve has a length of 100 pixels then `findT(50)` would return `0.5`.

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: The distance into the curve in pixels. Should be a positive integer.

returns.description: The time (`t`) value, a float between 0 and 1.

functions.name: getX
functions.description: Get the X component of a point on the curve based on the `t` (time) value, which must be between 0 and 1.

parameters.name: t
parameters.description: The time value along the curve from which to extract a point. This is a value between 0 and 1, where 0 represents the start of the curve and 1 the end.

returns.description: The X component of a point on the curve based on the `t` (time) value.

functions.name: getY
functions.description: Get the Y component of a point on the curve based on the `t` (time) value, which must be between 0 and 1.

parameters.name: t
parameters.description: The time value along the curve from which to extract a point. This is a value between 0 and 1, where 0 represents the start of the curve and 1 the end.

returns.description: The Y component of a point on the curve based on the `t` (time) value.

functions.name: getPoint
functions.description: Get a point on the curve using the `t` (time) value, which must be between 0 and 1.

parameters.name: t
parameters.description: The time value along the curve from which to extract a point. This is a value between 0 and 1, where 0 represents the start of the curve and 1 the end.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: An optional Phaser.Point, or Object containing public `x` and `y` properties. If given the resulting values will be stored in the Objects `x` and `y` properties. If omitted a new Phaser.Point object is created.

returns.description: An Object with the x, y coordinate of the curve at the specified `t` value set in its `x` and `y` properties.

functions.name: getPointWithDistance
functions.description: Get a point on the curve using the distance, in pixels, along the curve.

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: The distance along the curve to get the point from, given in pixels.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: An optional Phaser.Point, or Object containing public `x` and `y` properties. If given the resulting values will be stored in the Objects `x` and `y` properties. If omitted a new Phaser.Point object is created.

returns.description: The point on the line at the specified 'distance' along the curve.

functions.name: getAngle
functions.description: Calculate and return the angle, in radians, of the curves tangent based on time.

parameters.name: t
parameters.description: The `t` (time) value at which to find the angle. Must be between 0 and 1.

returns.description: The angle of the line at the specified `t` time value along the curve. The value is in radians.

functions.name: getAngleWithDistance
functions.description: Calculate and return the angle, in radians, of the curves tangent at the given pixel distance along the curves length.

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: The distance along the curve to get the angle from, in pixels.

returns.description: The angle of the line at the specified distance along the curve. The value is in radians.

functions.name: getEntryTangent
functions.description: Get the angle of the curves entry point.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: The Phaser.Point object, or an Object with public `x` and `y` properties, in which the tangent vector values will be stored.

returns.description: A Point object containing the tangent vector of this Hermite curve.

functions.name: rotate
functions.description: Rotates the line by the amount specified in `angle`.Rotation takes place from the center of the line.If you wish to rotate around a different point see Line.rotateAround.If you wish to rotate the ends of the Line then see Line.start.rotate or Line.end.rotate.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to rotate the line by.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

functions.name: rotateAround
functions.description: Rotates the line by the amount specified in `angle`.Rotation takes place around the coordinates given.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to offset the rotation from.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to rotate the line by.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

returns.description: This line object

functions.name: intersects
functions.description: Checks for intersection between this line and another Line.If asSegment is true it will check for segment intersection. If asSegment is false it will check for line intersection.Returns the intersection segment of AB and EF as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.

parameters.name: line
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

parameters.name: asSegment
parameters.description: If true it will check for segment intersection, otherwise full line intersection.

parameters.name: result
parameters.description: A Point object to store the result in, if not given a new one will be created.

returns.description: The intersection segment of the two lines as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.

functions.name: reflect
functions.description: Returns the reflected angle between two lines.This is the outgoing angle based on the angle of this line and the normalAngle of the given line.

parameters.name: line
parameters.description: The line to reflect off this line.

returns.description: The reflected angle in radians.

functions.name: midPoint
functions.description: Returns a Point object where the x and y values correspond to the center (or midpoint) of the Line segment.

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: A Phaser.Point object into which the result will be populated. If not given a new Point object is created.

returns.description: A Phaser.Point object with the x and y values set to the center of the line segment.

functions.name: centerOn
functions.description: Centers this Line on the given coordinates.The line is centered by positioning the start and end points so that the lines midpoint matchesthe coordinates given.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x position to center the line on.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y position to center the line on.

returns.description: This line object

functions.name: pointOnLine
functions.description: Tests if the given coordinates fall on this line. See pointOnSegment to test against just the line segment.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

returns.description: True if the point is on the line, false if not.

functions.name: pointOnSegment
functions.description: Tests if the given coordinates fall on this line and within the segment. See pointOnLine to test against just the line.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The line to check against this one.

returns.description: True if the point is on the line and segment, false if not.

functions.name: random
functions.description: Picks a random point from anywhere on the Line segment and returns it.

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: A Phaser.Point, or any object with public x/y properties, that the values will be set in.    If no object is provided a new Phaser.Point object will be created. In high performance areas avoid this by re-using an object.

returns.description: An object containing the random point in its `x` and `y` properties.

functions.name: coordinatesOnLine
functions.description: Using Bresenham's line algorithm this will return an array of all coordinates on this line.The start and end points are rounded before this runs as the algorithm works on integers.

parameters.name: stepRate
parameters.description: How many steps will we return? 1 = every coordinate on the line, 2 = every other coordinate, etc.

parameters.name: results
parameters.description: The array to store the results in. If not provided a new one will be generated.

returns.description: An array of coordinates.

functions.name: clone
functions.description: Returns a new Line object with the same values for the start and end properties as this Line object.

parameters.name: output
parameters.description: Optional Line object. If given the values will be set into the object, otherwise a brand new Line object will be created and returned.

returns.description: The cloned Line object.

functions.name: intersectsPoints
functions.description: Checks for intersection between two lines as defined by the given start and end points.If asSegment is true it will check for line segment intersection. If asSegment is false it will check for line intersection.Returns the intersection segment of AB and EF as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.Adapted from code by Keith Hair

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The start of the first Line to be checked.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The end of the first line to be checked.

parameters.name: e
parameters.description: The start of the second Line to be checked.

parameters.name: f
parameters.description: The end of the second line to be checked.

parameters.name: asSegment
parameters.description: If true it will check for segment intersection, otherwise full line intersection.

parameters.name: result
parameters.description: A Point object to store the result in, if not given a new one will be created.

returns.description: The intersection segment of the two lines as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.

functions.name: intersects
functions.description: Checks for intersection between two lines.If asSegment is true it will check for segment intersection.If asSegment is false it will check for line intersection.Returns the intersection segment of AB and EF as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.Adapted from code by Keith Hair

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first Line to be checked.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second Line to be checked.

parameters.name: asSegment
parameters.description: If true it will check for segment intersection, otherwise full line intersection.

parameters.name: result
parameters.description: A Point object to store the result in, if not given a new one will be created.

returns.description: The intersection segment of the two lines as a Point, or null if there is no intersection.

functions.name: intersectsRectangle
functions.description: Checks for intersection between the Line and a Rectangle shape, or a rectangle-likeobject, with public `x`, `y`, `right` and `bottom` properties, such as a Sprite or Body.An intersection is considered valid if:The line starts within or ends within the rectangle; orThe line segment intersects one of the 4 rectangle edges; andThe line has a non-zero length; andThe rectangle is not empty.For the purposes of this function rectangles are considered 'solid'.

parameters.name: line
parameters.description: The line to check for intersection with.

parameters.name: rect
parameters.description: The rectangle, or rectangle-like object, to check for intersection with.

returns.description: True if the line intersects with the rectangle edges, or starts or ends within the rectangle.

functions.name: reflect
functions.description: Returns the reflected angle between two lines.This is the outgoing angle based on the angle of Line 1 and the normalAngle of Line 2.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The base line.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The line to be reflected from the base line.

returns.description: The reflected angle in radians.

classes.name: Phaser.Matrix
classes.description: The Matrix is a 3x3 matrix mostly used for display transforms within the renderer.It is represented like so:| a | b | tx || c | d | ty || 0 | 0 | 1 |

constructor.name: Matrix
constructor.description: The Matrix is a 3x3 matrix mostly used for display transforms within the renderer.It is represented like so:| a | b | tx || c | d | ty || 0 | 0 | 1 |

classes.name: Phaser.Point
classes.description: A Point object represents a location in a two-dimensional coordinate system, where x represents the horizontal axis and y represents the vertical axis.The following code creates a point at (0,0):`var myPoint = new Phaser.Point();`You can also use them as 2D Vectors and you'll find different vector related methods in this class.

constructor.name: Point
constructor.description: A Point object represents a location in a two-dimensional coordinate system, where x represents the horizontal axis and y represents the vertical axis.The following code creates a point at (0,0):`var myPoint = new Phaser.Point();`You can also use them as 2D Vectors and you'll find different vector related methods in this class.

functions.name: rotate
functions.description: Rotates a Point object, or any object with exposed x/y properties, around the given coordinates bythe angle specified. If the angle between the point and coordinates was 45 deg and the angle argumentis 45 deg then the resulting angle will be 90 deg, as the angle argument is added to the current angle.The distance allows you to specify a distance constraint for the rotation between the point and the coordinates. If none is given the distance between the two is calculated and used.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The Point object to rotate.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the anchor point

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the anchor point

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in radians (unless asDegrees is true) to rotate the Point by.

parameters.name: asDegrees
parameters.description: Is the given angle in radians (false) or degrees (true)?

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: An optional distance constraint between the Point and the anchor.

returns.description: The modified point object.

classes.name: Phaser.Polygon
classes.description: Creates a new Polygon.The points can be set from a variety of formats:- An array of Point objects: `[new Phaser.Point(x1, y1), ...]`- An array of objects with public x/y properties: `[obj1, obj2, ...]`- An array of paired numbers that represent point coordinates: `[x1,y1, x2,y2, ...]`- As separate Point arguments: `setTo(new Phaser.Point(x1, y1), ...)`- As separate objects with public x/y properties arguments: `setTo(obj1, obj2, ...)`- As separate arguments representing point coordinates: `setTo(x1,y1, x2,y2, ...)`

constructor.name: Polygon
constructor.description: Creates a new Polygon.The points can be set from a variety of formats:- An array of Point objects: `[new Phaser.Point(x1, y1), ...]`- An array of objects with public x/y properties: `[obj1, obj2, ...]`- An array of paired numbers that represent point coordinates: `[x1,y1, x2,y2, ...]`- As separate Point arguments: `setTo(new Phaser.Point(x1, y1), ...)`- As separate objects with public x/y properties arguments: `setTo(obj1, obj2, ...)`- As separate arguments representing point coordinates: `setTo(x1,y1, x2,y2, ...)`

parameters.name: points
parameters.description: The points to set.

functions.name: toNumberArray
functions.description: Export the points as an array of flat numbers, following the sequence [ x,y, x,y, x,y ]

parameters.name: output
parameters.description: The array to append the points to. If not specified a new array will be created.

returns.description: The flattened array.

functions.name: flatten
functions.description: Flattens this Polygon so the points are a sequence of numbers.Any Point objects found are removed and replaced with two numbers.Also sets the Polygon.flattened property to `true`.

returns.description: This Polygon object

functions.name: clone
functions.description: Creates a copy of the given Polygon.This is a deep clone, the resulting copy contains new Phaser.Point objects

parameters.name: output
parameters.description: The polygon to update. If not specified a new polygon will be created.

returns.description: The cloned (`output`) polygon object.

functions.name: contains
functions.description: Checks whether the x and y coordinates are contained within this polygon.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The X value of the coordinate to test.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The Y value of the coordinate to test.

returns.description: True if the coordinates are within this polygon, otherwise false.

functions.name: setTo
functions.description: Sets this Polygon to the given points.The points can be set from a variety of formats:- An array of Point objects: `[new Phaser.Point(x1, y1), ...]`- An array of objects with public x/y properties: `[obj1, obj2, ...]`- An array of paired numbers that represent point coordinates: `[x1,y1, x2,y2, ...]`- An array of arrays with two elements representing x/y coordinates: `[[x1, y1], [x2, y2], ...]`- As separate Point arguments: `setTo(new Phaser.Point(x1, y1), ...)`- As separate objects with public x/y properties arguments: `setTo(obj1, obj2, ...)`- As separate arguments representing point coordinates: `setTo(x1,y1, x2,y2, ...)``setTo` may also be called without any arguments to remove all points.

parameters.name: points
parameters.description: The points to set.

returns.description: This Polygon object

functions.name: calculateArea
functions.description: Calcuates the area of the Polygon. This is available in the property Polygon.area

parameters.name: y0
parameters.description: The lowest boundary

returns.description: The area of the Polygon.

members.name: area
members.description: The area of this Polygon.

members.name: _points
members.description: An array of Points that make up this Polygon.

members.name: closed
members.description: Is the Polygon closed or not?

members.name: flattened
members.description: Has this Polygon been flattened by a call to `Polygon.flatten` ?

members.name: type
members.description: The base object type.

members.name: points
members.description: Sets and modifies the points of this polygon.See {@link Phaser.Polygon#setTo setTo} for the different kinds of arrays formats that can be assigned. The array of vertex points.

classes.name: Phaser.Rectangle
classes.description: Creates a new Rectangle object with the top-left corner specified by the x and y parameters and with the specified width and height parameters.If you call this function without parameters, a Rectangle with x, y, width, and height properties set to 0 is created.

constructor.name: Rectangle
constructor.description: Creates a new Rectangle object with the top-left corner specified by the x and y parameters and with the specified width and height parameters.If you call this function without parameters, a Rectangle with x, y, width, and height properties set to 0 is created.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of the top-left corner of the Rectangle.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the top-left corner of the Rectangle.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the Rectangle. Should always be either zero or a positive value.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the Rectangle. Should always be either zero or a positive value.

functions.name: offset
functions.description: Adjusts the location of the Rectangle object, as determined by its top-left corner, by the specified amounts.

parameters.description: Moves the x value of the Rectangle object by this amount.

parameters.name: dy
parameters.description: Moves the y value of the Rectangle object by this amount.

returns.description: This Rectangle object.

functions.description: Adjusts the location of the Rectangle object using a Point object as a parameter. This method is similar to the Rectangle.offset() method, except that it takes a Point object as a parameter.

returns.description: This Rectangle object.

functions.description: Sets the members of Rectangle to the specified values.

functions.name: scale
functions.description: Scales the width and height of this Rectangle by the given amounts.

parameters.description: The amount to scale the width of the Rectangle by. A value of 0.5 would reduce by half, a value of 2 would double the width, etc.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The amount to scale the height of the Rectangle by. A value of 0.5 would reduce by half, a value of 2 would double the height, etc.

parameters.description: The object to copy to.

functions.name: inflate
functions.description: Increases the size of the Rectangle object by the specified amounts. The center point of the Rectangle object stays the same, and its size increases to the left and right by the dx value, and to the top and the bottom by the dy value.

parameters.name: dx

parameters.name: dy

parameters.name: height

functions.name: contains

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of the point to test.

returns.description: A value of true if the Rectangle object contains the specified point; otherwise false.

functions.name: containsRect
functions.description: Determines whether the first Rectangle object is fully contained within the second Rectangle object.A Rectangle object is said to contain another if the second Rectangle object falls entirely within the boundaries of the first.

functions.name: intersection

classes.name: Phaser.DeviceButton
classes.description: DeviceButtons belong to both `Phaser.Pointer` and `Phaser.SinglePad` (Gamepad) instances.For Pointers they represent the various buttons that can exist on mice and pens, such as the left button, right button,middle button and advanced buttons like back and forward.Access them via `Pointer.leftbutton`, `Pointer.rightButton` and so on.On Gamepads they represent all buttons on the pad: from shoulder buttons to action buttons.At the time of writing this there are device limitations you should be aware of:- On Windows, if you install a mouse driver, and its utility software allows you to customize button actions   (e.g., IntelliPoint and SetPoint), the middle (wheel) button, the 4th button, and the 5th button might not be set,   even when they are pressed.- On Linux (GTK), the 4th button and the 5th button are not supported.- On Mac OS X 10.5 there is no platform API for implementing any advanced buttons.

constructor.name: DeviceButton
constructor.description: DeviceButtons belong to both `Phaser.Pointer` and `Phaser.SinglePad` (Gamepad) instances.For Pointers they represent the various buttons that can exist on mice and pens, such as the left button, right button,middle button and advanced buttons like back and forward.Access them via `Pointer.leftbutton`, `Pointer.rightButton` and so on.On Gamepads they represent all buttons on the pad: from shoulder buttons to action buttons.At the time of writing this there are device limitations you should be aware of:- On Windows, if you install a mouse driver, and its utility software allows you to customize button actions   (e.g., IntelliPoint and SetPoint), the middle (wheel) button, the 4th button, and the 5th button might not be set,   even when they are pressed.- On Linux (GTK), the 4th button and the 5th button are not supported.- On Mac OS X 10.5 there is no platform API for implementing any advanced buttons.

returns.description: True if the button is just pressed otherwise false.

returns.description: True if the button is just released otherwise false.

members.description: A reference to the Pointer or Gamepad that owns this button.

members.description: The DOM event that caused the change in button state.

members.description: The "up" state of the button.

members.description: The timestamp when the button was last pressed down.

members.name: timeUp
members.description: The timestamp when the button was last released.

members.description: Gamepad only.If a button is held down this holds down the number of times the button has 'repeated'.

members.description: True if the alt key was held down when this button was last pressed or released.Not supported on Gamepads.

members.name: shiftKey
members.description: True if the shift key was held down when this button was last pressed or released.Not supported on Gamepads.

members.name: ctrlKey
members.description: True if the control key was held down when this button was last pressed or released.Not supported on Gamepads.

members.name: value
members.description: Button value. Mainly useful for checking analog buttons (like shoulder triggers) on Gamepads.

members.name: buttonCode
members.description: The buttoncode of this button if a Gamepad, or the DOM button event value if a Pointer.

members.name: onDown
members.description: This Signal is dispatched every time this DeviceButton is pressed down.It is only dispatched once (until the button is released again).When dispatched it sends 2 arguments: A reference to this DeviceButton and the value of the button.

members.name: onUp
members.description: This Signal is dispatched every time this DeviceButton is released from a down state.It is only dispatched once (until the button is pressed again).When dispatched it sends 2 arguments: A reference to this DeviceButton and the value of the button.

members.name: onFloat
members.description: Gamepad only.This Signal is dispatched every time this DeviceButton changes floating value (between, but not exactly, 0 and 1).When dispatched it sends 2 arguments: A reference to this DeviceButton and the value of the button.

members.name: duration
members.description: How long the button has been held down for in milliseconds.If not currently down it returns -1.

classes.name: Phaser.Gamepad
classes.description: The Gamepad class handles gamepad input and dispatches gamepad events.Remember to call `gamepad.start()`.HTML5 GAMEPAD API SUPPORT IS AT AN EXPERIMENTAL STAGE!At moment of writing this (end of 2013) only Chrome supports parts of it out of the box. Firefox supports itvia prefs flags (about:config, search gamepad). The browsers map the same controllers differently.This class has constants for Windows 7 Chrome mapping of XBOX 360 controller.
