functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: Retrieves the global bounds of the displayObjectContainer as a rectangle. The bounds calculation takes all visible children into consideration.

parameters.name: targetCoordinateSpace
parameters.description: Returns a rectangle that defines the area of the display object relative to the coordinate system of the targetCoordinateSpace object.

returns.description: The rectangular bounding area

functions.name: getLocalBounds
functions.description: Retrieves the non-global local bounds of the displayObjectContainer as a rectangle without any transformations. The calculation takes all visible children into consideration.

returns.description: The rectangular bounding area

functions.name: contains
functions.description: Determines whether the specified display object is a child of the DisplayObjectContainer instance or the instance itself.

functions.name: _renderWebGL
functions.description: Renders the object using the WebGL renderer

functions.name: _renderCanvas
functions.description: Renders the object using the Canvas renderer

members.name: maxParticles
members.description: The total number of particles in this emitter.

members.name: _id
members.description: Internal ID for this emitter -- only used by the Particle System in most cases

members.name: name
members.description: A handy string name for this emitter. Can be set to anything.

members.name: type
members.description: Internal Phaser Type value.

members.name: physicsType
members.description: The const physics body type of this object.

members.name: area
members.description: The area of the emitter. Particles can be randomly generated from anywhere within this rectangle.

members.name: minParticleSpeed
members.description: The minimum possible velocity of a particle.

members.name: maxParticleSpeed
members.description: The maximum possible velocity of a particle.

members.name: minParticleScale
members.description: The minimum possible scale of a particle. This is applied to the X and Y axis. If you need to control each axis see minParticleScaleX.

members.name: maxParticleScale
members.description: The maximum possible scale of a particle. This is applied to the X and Y axis. If you need to control each axis see maxParticleScaleX.

members.name: scaleData
members.description: An array of the calculated scale easing data applied to particles with scaleRates > 0.

members.name: minRotation
members.description: The minimum possible angular velocity of a particle.

members.name: maxRotation
members.description: The maximum possible angular velocity of a particle.

members.name: minParticleAlpha
members.description: The minimum possible alpha value of a particle.

members.name: maxParticleAlpha
members.description: The maximum possible alpha value of a particle.

members.name: alphaData
members.description: An array of the calculated alpha easing data applied to particles with alphaRates > 0.

members.name: gravity
members.description: Sets the `body.gravity` of each particle sprite to this on launch.

members.name: particleClass
members.description: For emitting your own particle class types. They must extend Phaser.Particle.

members.name: particleDrag
members.description: The X and Y drag component of particles launched from the emitter.

members.name: angularDrag
members.description: The angular drag component of particles launched from the emitter if they are rotating.

members.name: frequency
members.description: How often a particle is emitted in ms (if emitter is started with Explode === false).

members.name: lifespan
members.description: How long each particle lives once it is emitted in ms. Default is 2 seconds. Set lifespan to 'zero' for particles to live forever.

members.name: bounce
members.description: How much each particle should bounce on each axis. 1 = full bounce, 0 = no bounce.

members.name: on
members.description: Determines whether the emitter is currently emitting particles. It is totally safe to directly toggle this.

members.name: particleAnchor
members.description: When a particle is created its anchor will be set to match this Point object (defaults to x/y: 0.5 to aid in rotation)

members.name: blendMode
members.description: The blendMode as set on the particle when emitted from the Emitter. Defaults to NORMAL. Needs browser capable of supporting canvas blend-modes (most not available in WebGL)

members.name: emitX
members.description: The point the particles are emitted from.Emitter.x and Emitter.y control the containers location, which updates all current particlesEmitter.emitX and Emitter.emitY control the emission location relative to the x/y position.

members.name: emitY
members.description: The point the particles are emitted from.Emitter.x and Emitter.y control the containers location, which updates all current particlesEmitter.emitX and Emitter.emitY control the emission location relative to the x/y position.

members.name: autoScale
members.description: When a new Particle is emitted this controls if it will automatically scale in size. Use Emitter.setScale to configure.

members.name: autoAlpha
members.description: When a new Particle is emitted this controls if it will automatically change alpha. Use Emitter.setAlpha to configure.

members.name: particleBringToTop
members.description: If this is `true` then when the Particle is emitted it will be bought to the top of the Emitters display list.

members.name: particleSendToBack
members.description: If this is `true` then when the Particle is emitted it will be sent to the back of the Emitters display list.

members.name: _minParticleScale
members.description: Internal particle scale var.

members.name: _maxParticleScale
members.description: Internal particle scale var.

members.name: _quantity
members.description: Internal helper for deciding how many particles to launch.

members.name: _timer
members.description: Internal helper for deciding when to launch particles or kill them.

members.name: _counter
members.description: Internal counter for figuring out how many particles to launch.

members.name: _flowQuantity
members.description: Internal counter for figuring out how many particles to launch per flow update.

members.name: _flowTotal
members.description: Internal counter for figuring out how many particles to launch in total.

members.name: _explode
members.description: Internal helper for the style of particle emission (all at once, or one at a time).

members.name: _frames
members.description: Internal helper for the particle frame.

members.name: id
members.description: Gets the internal ID that represents this emitter.

members.name: width
members.description: Gets or sets the width of the Emitter. This is the region in which a particle can be emitted.

members.name: height
members.description: Gets or sets the height of the Emitter. This is the region in which a particle can be emitted.

members.name: x
members.description: Gets or sets the x position of the Emitter.

members.name: y
members.description: Gets or sets the y position of the Emitter.

members.name: left
members.description: Gets the left position of the Emitter.

members.name: right
members.description: Gets the right position of the Emitter.

members.name: top
members.description: Gets the top position of the Emitter.

members.name: bottom
members.description: Gets the bottom position of the Emitter.

members.name: game
members.description: A reference to the currently running Game.

members.name: z
members.description: The z-depth value of this object within its parent container/Group - the World is a Group as well.This value must be unique for each child in a Group.

members.name: alive
members.description: The alive property is useful for Groups that are children of other Groups and need to be included/excluded in checks like forEachAlive.

members.name: exists
members.description: If exists is false the group will be excluded from collision checks and filters such as {@link forEachExists}. The group will not call `preUpdate` and `postUpdate` on its children and the children will not receive physics updates or camera/world boundary checks. The group will still be {@link Phaser.Group#visible visible} and will still call `update` on its children.

members.name: ignoreDestroy
members.description: A group with `ignoreDestroy` set to `true` ignores all calls to its `destroy` method.

members.name: pendingDestroy
members.description: A Group is that has `pendingDestroy` set to `true` is flagged to have its destroy methodcalled on the next logic update.You can set it directly to flag the Group to be destroyed on its next update.This is extremely useful if you wish to destroy a Group from within one of its own callbacksor a callback of one of its children.

members.name: classType
members.description: The type of objects that will be created when using {@link Phaser.Group#create create} or {@link Phaser.Group#createMultiple createMultiple}.Any object may be used but it should extend either Sprite or Image and accept the same constructor arguments:when a new object is created it is passed the following parameters to its constructor: `(game, x, y, key, frame)`.

members.name: cursor
members.description: The current display object that the group cursor is pointing to, if any. (Can be set manually.)The cursor is a way to iterate through the children in a Group using {@link Phaser.Group#next next} and {@link Phaser.Group#previous previous}.

members.name: inputEnableChildren
members.description: A Group with `inputEnableChildren` set to `true` will automatically call `inputEnabled = true` on any children _added_ to, or _created by_, this Group.If there are children already in the Group at the time you set this property, they are not changed.

members.name: onChildInputDown
members.description: This Signal is dispatched whenever a child of this Group emits an onInputDown signal as a resultof having been interacted with by a Pointer. You can bind functions to this Signal instead of toevery child Sprite.This Signal is sent 2 arguments: A reference to the Sprite that triggered the signal, anda reference to the Pointer that caused it.

members.name: onChildInputUp
members.description: This Signal is dispatched whenever a child of this Group emits an onInputUp signal as a resultof having been interacted with by a Pointer. You can bind functions to this Signal instead of toevery child Sprite.This Signal is sent 3 arguments: A reference to the Sprite that triggered the signal, a reference to the Pointer that caused it, and a boolean value `isOver` that tells you if the Pointeris still over the Sprite or not.

members.name: onChildInputOver
members.description: This Signal is dispatched whenever a child of this Group emits an onInputOver signal as a resultof having been interacted with by a Pointer. You can bind functions to this Signal instead of toevery child Sprite.This Signal is sent 2 arguments: A reference to the Sprite that triggered the signal, anda reference to the Pointer that caused it.

members.name: onChildInputOut
members.description: This Signal is dispatched whenever a child of this Group emits an onInputOut signal as a resultof having been interacted with by a Pointer. You can bind functions to this Signal instead of toevery child Sprite.This Signal is sent 2 arguments: A reference to the Sprite that triggered the signal, anda reference to the Pointer that caused it.

members.name: enableBody
members.description: If true all Sprites created by, or added to this group, will have a physics body enabled on them.If there are children already in the Group at the time you set this property, they are not changed.The default body type is controlled with {@link Phaser.Group#physicsBodyType physicsBodyType}.

members.name: enableBodyDebug
members.description: If true when a physics body is created (via {@link Phaser.Group#enableBody enableBody}) it will create a physics debug object as well.This only works for P2 bodies.

members.name: physicsBodyType
members.description: If {@link Phaser.Group#enableBody enableBody} is true this is the type of physics body that is created on new Sprites.The valid values are {@link Phaser.Physics.ARCADE}, {@link Phaser.Physics.P2JS}, {@link Phaser.Physics.NINJA}, etc.

members.name: physicsSortDirection
members.description: If this Group contains Arcade Physics Sprites you can set a custom sort direction via this property.It should be set to one of the Phaser.Physics.Arcade sort direction constants: Phaser.Physics.Arcade.SORT_NONEPhaser.Physics.Arcade.LEFT_RIGHTPhaser.Physics.Arcade.RIGHT_LEFTPhaser.Physics.Arcade.TOP_BOTTOMPhaser.Physics.Arcade.BOTTOM_TOPIf set to `null` the Group will use whatever Phaser.Physics.Arcade.sortDirection is set to. This is the default behavior.

members.name: onDestroy
members.description: This signal is dispatched when the group is destroyed.

members.name: cursorIndex
members.description: The current index of the Group cursor. Advance it with Group.next.

members.name: fixedToCamera
members.description: A Group that is fixed to the camera uses its x/y coordinates as offsets from the top left of the camera. These are stored in Group.cameraOffset.Note that the cameraOffset values are in addition to any parent in the display list.So if this Group was in a Group that has x: 200, then this will be added to the cameraOffset.x

members.name: cameraOffset
members.description: If this object is {@link Phaser.Group#fixedToCamera fixedToCamera} then this stores the x/y position offset relative to the top-left of the camera view.If the parent of this Group is also `fixedToCamera` then the offset here is in addition to that and should typically be disabled.

members.name: hash
members.description: The hash array is an array belonging to this Group into which you can add any of its children via Group.addToHash and Group.removeFromHash.Only children of this Group can be added to and removed from the hash.This hash is used automatically by Phaser Arcade Physics in order to perform non z-index based destructive sorting.However if you don't use Arcade Physics, or this isn't a physics enabled Group, then you can use the hash to perform your ownsorting and filtering of Group children without touching their z-index (and therefore display draw order)

members.name: _sortProperty
members.description: The property on which children are sorted.

members.name: total
members.description: Total number of existing children in the group.

members.name: length
members.description: Total number of children in this group, regardless of exists/alive status.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle of rotation of the group container, in degrees.This adjusts the group itself by modifying its local rotation transform.This has no impact on the rotation/angle properties of the children, but it will update their worldTransformand on-screen orientation and position.

members.name: centerX
members.description: The center x coordinate of this Group.It is derived by calling `getBounds`, calculating the Groups dimensions based on itsvisible children.

members.name: centerY
members.description: The center y coordinate of this Group.It is derived by calling `getBounds`, calculating the Groups dimensions based on itsvisible children.

members.name: rotation
members.description: The angle of rotation of the group container, in radians.This will adjust the group container itself by modifying its rotation.This will have no impact on the rotation value of its children, but it will update their worldTransform and on-screen position.

members.name: visible
members.description: The visible state of the group. Non-visible Groups and all of their children are not rendered.

members.name: alpha
members.description: The alpha value of the group container.

members.name: children
members.description: [read-only] The array of children of this container.

members.name: ignoreChildInput
members.description:
If `ignoreChildInput`  is `false` it will allow this objects _children_ to be considered as valid for Input events.

If this property is `true` then the children will _not_ be considered as valid for Input events.

Note that this property isn't recursive: only immediate children are influenced, it doesn't scan further down.

members.name: position
members.description:
The coordinates, in pixels, of this DisplayObject, relative to its parent container.

The value of this property does not reflect any positioning happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldPosition` property.

members.name: scale
members.description:
The scale of this DisplayObject. A scale of 1:1 represents the DisplayObject
at its default size. A value of 0.5 would scale this DisplayObject by half, and so on.

The value of this property does not reflect any scaling happening further up the display list.
To obtain that value please see the `worldScale` property.

members.name: pivot
members.description:
The pivot point of this DisplayObject that it rotates around. The values are expressed
in pixel values.

members.name: hitArea
members.description:
This is the defined area that will pick up mouse / touch events. It is null by default.
Setting it is a neat way of optimising the hitTest function that the interactionManager will use (as it will not need to hit test all the children)

members.name: renderable
members.description:
Should this DisplayObject be rendered by the renderer? An object with a renderable value of
`false` is skipped during the render pass.

members.name: parent
members.description:
The parent DisplayObjectContainer that this DisplayObject is a child of.
All DisplayObjects must belong to a parent in order to be rendered.
The root parent is the Stage object. This property is set automatically when the
DisplayObject is added to, or removed from, a DisplayObjectContainer.

members.name: worldAlpha
members.description:
The multiplied alpha value of this DisplayObject. A value of 1 is fully opaque. A value of 0 is transparent.
This value is the calculated total, based on the alpha values of all parents of this DisplayObjects 
in the display list.

To obtain, and set, the local alpha value, see the `alpha` property.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldTransform
members.description:
The current transform of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the transforms of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldPosition
members.description:
The coordinates, in pixels, of this DisplayObject within the world.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the positions of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldScale
members.description:
The global scale of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the scales of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: worldRotation
members.description:
The rotation, in radians, of this DisplayObject.

This property contains the calculated total, based on the rotations of all parents of this 
DisplayObject in the display list.

Note: This property is only updated at the end of the `updateTransform` call, once per render. Until 
that happens this property will contain values based on the previous frame. Be mindful of this if
accessing this property outside of the normal game flow, i.e. from an asynchronous event callback.

members.name: filterArea
members.description: The rectangular area used by filters when rendering a shader for this DisplayObject.

members.name: worldVisible
members.description: Indicates if this DisplayObject is visible, based on it, and all of its parents, `visible` property values.

members.name: mask
members.description:
Sets a mask for this DisplayObject. A mask is an instance of a Graphics object.
When applied it limits the visible area of this DisplayObject to the shape of the mask.
Under a Canvas renderer it uses shape clipping. Under a WebGL renderer it uses a Stencil Buffer.
To remove a mask, set this property to `null`.

members.name: filters
members.description:
Sets the filters for this DisplayObject. This is a WebGL only feature, and is ignored by the Canvas
Renderer. A filter is a shader applied to this DisplayObject. You can modify the placement of the filter
using `DisplayObject.filterArea`.

To remove filters, set this property to `null`.

Note: You cannot have a filter set, and a MULTIPLY Blend Mode active, at the same time. Setting a 
filter will reset this DisplayObjects blend mode to NORMAL.

members.name: cacheAsBitmap
members.description:
Sets if this DisplayObject should be cached as a bitmap.

When invoked it will take a snapshot of the DisplayObject, as it is at that moment, and store it 
in a RenderTexture. This is then used whenever this DisplayObject is rendered. It can provide a
performance benefit for complex, but static, DisplayObjects. I.e. those with lots of children.

Cached Bitmaps do not track their parents. If you update a property of this DisplayObject, it will not
re-generate the cached bitmap automatically. To do that you need to call `DisplayObject.updateCache`.

To remove a cached bitmap, set this property to `null`.

classes.name: Phaser.Physics.Arcade.Body
classes.description: The Physics Body is linked to a single Sprite. All physics operations should be performed against the body rather thanthe Sprite itself. For example you can set the velocity, acceleration, bounce values etc all on the Body.

constructor.name: Body
constructor.description: The Physics Body is linked to a single Sprite. All physics operations should be performed against the body rather thanthe Sprite itself. For example you can set the velocity, acceleration, bounce values etc all on the Body.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The Sprite object this physics body belongs to.

functions.name: updateBounds
functions.description: Internal method.

functions.name: preUpdate
functions.description: Internal method.

functions.name: updateMovement
functions.description: Internal method.

functions.name: stopMovement
functions.description: If this Body is moving as a result of a call to `moveTo` or `moveFrom` (i.e. ithas Body.isMoving true), then calling this method will stop the movement beforeeither the duration or distance counters expire.The `onMoveComplete` signal is dispatched.

parameters.name: stopVelocity
parameters.description: Should the Body.velocity be set to zero?

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: Internal method.

functions.name: checkWorldBounds
functions.description: Internal method.

returns.description: True if the Body collided with the world bounds, otherwise false.

functions.name: moveFrom
functions.description: Note: This method is experimental, and may be changed or removed in a future release.This method moves the Body in the given direction, for the duration specified.It works by setting the velocity on the Body, and an internal timer, and thenmonitoring the duration each frame. When the duration is up the movement isstopped and the `Body.onMoveComplete` signal is dispatched.Movement also stops if the Body collides or overlaps with any other Body.You can control if the velocity should be reset to zero on collision, by usingthe property `Body.stopVelocityOnCollide`.Stop the movement at any time by calling `Body.stopMovement`.You can optionally set a speed in pixels per second. If not specified itwill use the current `Body.speed` value. If this is zero, the function will return false.Please note that due to browser timings you should allow for a variance in when the duration will actually expire. Depending on system it may be as much as+- 50ms. Also this method doesn't take into consideration any other forces actingon the Body, such as Gravity, drag or maxVelocity, all of which may impact themovement.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The duration of the movement, in ms.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed of the movement, in pixels per second. If not provided `Body.speed` is used.

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: The angle of movement. If not provided `Body.angle` is used.

returns.description: True if the movement successfully started, otherwise false.

functions.name: moveTo
functions.description: Note: This method is experimental, and may be changed or removed in a future release.This method moves the Body in the given direction, for the duration specified.It works by setting the velocity on the Body, and an internal distance counter.The distance is monitored each frame. When the distance equals the distancespecified in this call, the movement is stopped, and the `Body.onMoveComplete` signal is dispatched.Movement also stops if the Body collides or overlaps with any other Body.You can control if the velocity should be reset to zero on collision, by usingthe property `Body.stopVelocityOnCollide`.Stop the movement at any time by calling `Body.stopMovement`.Please note that due to browser timings you should allow for a variance in when the distance will actually expire.Note: This method doesn't take into consideration any other forces actingon the Body, such as Gravity, drag or maxVelocity, all of which may impact themovement.

parameters.name: duration
parameters.description: The duration of the movement, in ms.

parameters.name: distance
parameters.description: The distance, in pixels, the Body will move.

parameters.name: direction
parameters.description: The angle of movement. If not provided `Body.angle` is used.

returns.description: True if the movement successfully started, otherwise false.

functions.name: setSize
functions.description: You can modify the size of the physics Body to be any dimension you need.This allows you to make it smaller, or larger, than the parent Sprite.You can also control the x and y offset of the Body. This is the position of theBody relative to the top-left of the Sprite _texture_.For example: If you have a Sprite with a texture that is 80x100 in size,and you want the physics body to be 32x32 pixels in the middle of the texture, you would do:`setSize(32 / Math.abs(this.scale.x), 32 / Math.abs(this.scale.y), 24, 34)`Where the first two parameters are the new Body size (32x32 pixels) relative to the Sprite's scale.24 is the horizontal offset of the Body from the top-left of the Sprites texture, and 34is the vertical offset.If you've scaled a Sprite by altering its `width`, `height`, or `scale` and you want toposition the Body relative to the Sprite's dimensions (which will differ from its texture'sdimensions), you should divide these arguments by the Sprite's current scale:`setSize(32 / sprite.scale.x, 32 / sprite.scale.y)`Calling `setSize` on a Body that has already had `setCircle` will reset all of the Circleproperties, making this Body rectangular again.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the Body.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the Body.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: The X offset of the Body from the top-left of the Sprite's texture.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: The Y offset of the Body from the top-left of the Sprite's texture.

functions.name: setCircle
functions.description: Sets this Body as using a circle, of the given radius, for all collision detection instead of a rectangle.The radius is given in pixels and is the distance from the center of the circle to the edge.You can also control the x and y offset, which is the position of the Body relative to the top-left of the Sprite.To change a Body back to being rectangular again call `Body.setSize`.Note: Circular collision only happens with other Arcade Physics bodies, it does notwork against tile maps, where rectangular collision is the only method supported.

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: The radius of the Body in pixels. Pass a value of zero / undefined, to stop the Body using a circle for collision.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: The X offset of the Body from the Sprite position.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: The Y offset of the Body from the Sprite position.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets all Body values (velocity, acceleration, rotation, etc)

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x position of the Body.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new y position of the Body.

functions.name: getBounds
functions.description: Returns the bounds of this physics body.Only used internally by the World collision methods.

parameters.name: obj
parameters.description: The object in which to set the bounds values.

returns.description: The object that was given to this method.

functions.name: hitTest
functions.description: Tests if a world point lies within this Body.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The world x coordinate to test.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The world y coordinate to test.

returns.description: True if the given coordinates are inside this Body, otherwise false.

functions.name: onFloor
functions.description: Returns true if the bottom of this Body is in contact with either the world bounds or a tile.

returns.description: True if in contact with either the world bounds or a tile.

functions.name: onCeiling
functions.description: Returns true if the top of this Body is in contact with either the world bounds or a tile.

returns.description: True if in contact with either the world bounds or a tile.

functions.name: onWall
functions.description: Returns true if either side of this Body is in contact with either the world bounds or a tile.

returns.description: True if in contact with either the world bounds or a tile.

functions.name: deltaAbsX
functions.description: Returns the absolute delta x value.

returns.description: The absolute delta value.

functions.name: deltaAbsY
functions.description: Returns the absolute delta y value.

returns.description: The absolute delta value.

functions.name: deltaX
functions.description: Returns the delta x value. The difference between Body.x now and in the previous step.

returns.description: The delta value. Positive if the motion was to the right, negative if to the left.

functions.name: deltaY
functions.description: Returns the delta y value. The difference between Body.y now and in the previous step.

returns.description: The delta value. Positive if the motion was downwards, negative if upwards.

functions.name: deltaZ
functions.description: Returns the delta z value. The difference between Body.rotation now and in the previous step.

returns.description: The delta value. Positive if the motion was clockwise, negative if anti-clockwise.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys this Body.First it calls Group.removeFromHash if the Game Object this Body belongs to is part of a Group.Then it nulls the Game Objects body reference, and nulls this Body.sprite reference.

members.name: sprite
members.description: Reference to the parent Sprite.

members.name: game
members.description: Local reference to game.

members.name: type
members.description: The type of physics system this body belongs to.

members.name: enable
members.description: A disabled body won't be checked for any form of collision or overlap or have its pre/post updates run.

members.name: isCircle
members.description: If `true` this Body is using circular collision detection. If `false` it is using rectangular.Use `Body.setCircle` to control the collision shape this Body uses.

members.name: radius
members.description: The radius of the circular collision shape this Body is using if Body.setCircle has been enabled.If you wish to change the radius then call `setCircle` again with the new value.If you wish to stop the Body using a circle then call `setCircle` with a radius of zero (or undefined).

members.name: offset
members.description: The offset of the Physics Body from the Sprite x/y position.

members.name: position
members.description: The position of the physics body.

members.name: prev
members.description: The previous position of the physics body.

members.name: allowRotation
members.description: Allow this Body to be rotated? (via angularVelocity, etc)

members.name: rotation
members.description: The Body's rotation in degrees, as calculated by its angularVelocity and angularAcceleration. Please understand that the collision Bodyitself never rotates, it is always axis-aligned. However these values are passed up to the parent Sprite and updates its rotation.

members.name: preRotation
members.description: The previous rotation of the physics body.

members.name: width
members.description: The calculated width of the physics body.

members.name: height
members.description: The calculated height of the physics body.

members.name: sourceWidth
members.description: The un-scaled original size.

members.name: sourceHeight
members.description: The un-scaled original size.

members.name: halfWidth
members.description: The calculated width / 2 of the physics body.

members.name: halfHeight
members.description: The calculated height / 2 of the physics body.

members.name: center
members.description: The center coordinate of the Physics Body.

members.name: velocity
members.description: The velocity, or rate of change in speed of the Body. Measured in pixels per second.

members.name: newVelocity
members.description: The new velocity. Calculated during the Body.preUpdate and applied to its position.

members.name: deltaMax
members.description: The Sprite position is updated based on the delta x/y values. You can set a cap on those (both +-) using deltaMax.

members.name: acceleration
members.description: The acceleration is the rate of change of the velocity. Measured in pixels per second squared.

members.name: drag
members.description: The drag applied to the motion of the Body.

members.name: allowGravity
members.description: Allow this Body to be influenced by gravity? Either world or local.

members.name: gravity
members.description: A local gravity applied to this Body. If non-zero this over rides any world gravity, unless Body.allowGravity is set to false.

members.name: bounce
members.description: The elasticity of the Body when colliding. bounce.x/y = 1 means full rebound, bounce.x/y = 0.5 means 50% rebound velocity.

members.name: worldBounce
members.description: The elasticity of the Body when colliding with the World bounds.By default this property is `null`, in which case `Body.bounce` is used instead. Set this propertyto a Phaser.Point object in order to enable a World bounds specific bounce value.

members.name: onWorldBounds
members.description: A Signal that is dispatched when this Body collides with the world bounds.Due to the potentially high volume of signals this could create it is disabled by default.To use this feature set this property to a Phaser.Signal: `sprite.body.onWorldBounds = new Phaser.Signal()`and it will be called when a collision happens, passing five arguments:`onWorldBounds(sprite, up, down, left, right)`where the Sprite is a reference to the Sprite that owns this Body, and the other arguments are booleansindicating on which side of the world the Body collided.

members.name: onCollide
members.description: A Signal that is dispatched when this Body collides with another Body.You still need to call `game.physics.arcade.collide` in your `update` method in orderfor this signal to be dispatched.Usually you'd pass a callback to the `collide` method, but this signal provides fora different level of notification.Due to the potentially high volume of signals this could create it is disabled by default.To use this feature set this property to a Phaser.Signal: `sprite.body.onCollide = new Phaser.Signal()`and it will be called when a collision happens, passing two arguments: the sprites which collided.The first sprite in the argument is always the owner of this Body.If two Bodies with this Signal set collide, both will dispatch the Signal.

members.name: onOverlap
members.description: A Signal that is dispatched when this Body overlaps with another Body.You still need to call `game.physics.arcade.overlap` in your `update` method in orderfor this signal to be dispatched.Usually you'd pass a callback to the `overlap` method, but this signal provides fora different level of notification.Due to the potentially high volume of signals this could create it is disabled by default.To use this feature set this property to a Phaser.Signal: `sprite.body.onOverlap = new Phaser.Signal()`and it will be called when a collision happens, passing two arguments: the sprites which collided.The first sprite in the argument is always the owner of this Body.If two Bodies with this Signal set collide, both will dispatch the Signal.

members.name: maxVelocity
members.description: The maximum velocity in pixels per second sq. that the Body can reach.

members.name: friction
members.description: The amount of movement that will occur if another object 'rides' this one.

members.name: angularVelocity
members.description: The angular velocity controls the rotation speed of the Body. It is measured in degrees per second.

members.name: angularAcceleration
members.description: The angular acceleration is the rate of change of the angular velocity. Measured in degrees per second squared.

members.name: angularDrag
members.description: The drag applied during the rotation of the Body. Measured in degrees per second squared.

members.name: maxAngular
members.description: The maximum angular velocity in degrees per second that the Body can reach.

members.name: mass
members.description: The mass of the Body. When two bodies collide their mass is used in the calculation to determine the exchange of velocity.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle of the Body's velocity in radians.

members.name: speed
members.description: The speed of the Body as calculated by its velocity.

members.name: facing
members.description: A const reference to the direction the Body is traveling or facing.

members.name: immovable
members.description: An immovable Body will not receive any impacts from other bodies.

members.name: moves
members.description: If you have a Body that is being moved around the world via a tween or a Group motion, but its local x/y position neveractually changes, then you should set Body.moves = false. Otherwise it will most likely fly off the screen.If you want the physics system to move the body around, then set moves to true. Set to true to allow the Physics system to move this Body, otherwise false to move it manually.

members.name: customSeparateX
members.description: This flag allows you to disable the custom x separation that takes place by Physics.Arcade.separate.Used in combination with your own collision processHandler you can create whatever type of collision response you need. Use a custom separation system or the built-in one?

members.name: customSeparateY
members.description: This flag allows you to disable the custom y separation that takes place by Physics.Arcade.separate.Used in combination with your own collision processHandler you can create whatever type of collision response you need. Use a custom separation system or the built-in one?

members.name: overlapX
members.description: When this body collides with another, the amount of overlap is stored here. The amount of horizontal overlap during the collision.

members.name: overlapY
members.description: When this body collides with another, the amount of overlap is stored here. The amount of vertical overlap during the collision.

members.name: overlapR
members.description: If `Body.isCircle` is true, and this body collides with another circular body, the amount of overlap is stored here. The amount of overlap during the collision.

members.name: embedded
members.description: If a body is overlapping with another body, but neither of them are moving (maybe they spawned on-top of each other?) this is set to true. Body embed value.

members.name: collideWorldBounds
members.description: A Body can be set to collide against the World bounds automatically and rebound back into the World if this is set to true. Otherwise it will leave the World. Should the Body collide with the World bounds?

members.name: checkCollision
members.description: Set the checkCollision properties to control which directions collision is processed for this Body.For example checkCollision.up = false means it won't collide when the collision happened while moving up.If you need to disable a Body entirely, use `body.enable = false`, this will also disable motion.If you need to disable just collision and/or overlap checks, but retain motion, set `checkCollision.none = true`. An object containing allowed collision.

members.name: touching
members.description: This object is populated with boolean values when the Body collides with another.touching.up = true means the collision happened to the top of this Body for example. An object containing touching results.

members.name: wasTouching
members.description: This object is populated with previous touching values from the bodies previous collision. An object containing previous touching results.

members.name: blocked
members.description: This object is populated with boolean values when the Body collides with the World bounds or a Tile.For example if blocked.up is true then the Body cannot move up. An object containing on which faces this Body is blocked from moving, if any.

members.name: tilePadding
members.description: If this is an especially small or fast moving object then it can sometimes skip over tilemap collisions if it moves through a tile in a step.Set this padding value to add extra padding to its bounds. tilePadding.x applied to its width, y to its height. Extra padding to be added to this sprite's dimensions when checking for tile collision.

members.name: dirty
members.description: If this Body in a preUpdate (true) or postUpdate (false) state?

members.name: skipQuadTree
members.description: If true and you collide this Sprite against a Group, it will disable the collision check from using a QuadTree.

members.name: syncBounds
members.description: If true the Body will check itself against the Sprite.getBounds() dimensions and adjust its width and height accordingly.If false it will compare its dimensions against the Sprite scale instead, and adjust its width height if the scale has changed.Typically you would need to enable syncBounds if your sprite is the child of a responsive display object such as a FlexLayer, or in any situation where the Sprite scale doesn't change, but its parents scale is effecting the dimensions regardless.

members.name: isMoving
members.description: Set by the `moveTo` and `moveFrom` methods.

members.name: stopVelocityOnCollide
members.description: Set by the `moveTo` and `moveFrom` methods.

members.name: moveTimer
members.description: Internal time used by the `moveTo` and `moveFrom` methods.

members.name: moveDistance
members.description: Internal distance value, used by the `moveTo` and `moveFrom` methods.

members.name: moveDuration
members.description: Internal duration value, used by the `moveTo` and `moveFrom` methods.

members.name: moveTarget
members.description: Set by the `moveTo` method, and updated each frame.

members.name: moveEnd
members.description: Set by the `moveTo` method, and updated each frame.

members.name: onMoveComplete
members.description: Listen for the completion of `moveTo` or `moveFrom` events.

members.name: movementCallback
members.description: Optional callback. If set, invoked during the running of `moveTo` or `moveFrom` events.

members.name: movementCallbackContext
members.description: Context in which to call the movementCallback.

members.name: _reset
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: _sx
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: _sy
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: _dx
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: _dy
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.description: The x position of the Body. The same as `Body.x`.

members.name: right
members.description: The right value of this Body (same as Body.x + Body.width)

members.name: top
members.description: The y position of the Body. The same as `Body.y`.

members.name: bottom

members.description: The x position.

classes.name: Phaser.Physics.Arcade
classes.description: The Arcade Physics world. Contains Arcade Physics related collision, overlap and motion methods.

constructor.name: Arcade
constructor.description: The Arcade Physics world. Contains Arcade Physics related collision, overlap and motion methods.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: reference to the current game instance.

functions.name: setBounds
functions.description: Updates the size of this physics world.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: Top left most corner of the world.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Top left most corner of the world.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: New width of the world. Can never be smaller than the Game.width.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: New height of the world. Can never be smaller than the Game.height.

functions.name: setBoundsToWorld
functions.description: Updates the size of this physics world to match the size of the game world.

functions.name: enable
functions.description: This will create an Arcade Physics body on the given game object or array of game objects.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the object is destroyed.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. Can also be an array or Group of objects, a body will be created on every child that has a `body` property.

parameters.name: children
parameters.description: Should a body be created on all children of this object? If true it will recurse down the display list as far as it can go.

functions.name: enableBody
functions.description: Creates an Arcade Physics body on the given game object.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the body is nulled.When you add an Arcade Physics body to an object it will automatically add the object into its parent Groups hash array.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. A body will only be created if this object has a null `body` property.

functions.name: updateMotion
functions.description: Called automatically by a Physics body, it updates all motion related values on the Body unless `World.isPaused` is `true`.

parameters.name: The
parameters.description: Body object to be updated.

functions.name: computeVelocity
functions.description: A tween-like function that takes a starting velocity and some other factors and returns an altered velocity.Based on a function in Flixel by @ADAMATOMIC

parameters.name: axis
parameters.description: 0 for nothing, 1 for horizontal, 2 for vertical.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The Body object to be updated.

parameters.name: velocity
parameters.description: Any component of velocity (e.g. 20).

parameters.name: acceleration
parameters.description: Rate at which the velocity is changing.

parameters.name: drag
parameters.description: Really kind of a deceleration, this is how much the velocity changes if Acceleration is not set.

parameters.name: max
parameters.description: An absolute value cap for the velocity.

returns.description: The altered Velocity value.

functions.name: overlap
functions.description: Checks for overlaps between two game objects. The objects can be Sprites, Groups or Emitters.You can perform Sprite vs. Sprite, Sprite vs. Group and Group vs. Group overlap checks.Unlike collide the objects are NOT automatically separated or have any physics applied, they merely test for overlap results.Both the first and second parameter can be arrays of objects, of differing types.If two arrays are passed, the contents of the first parameter will be tested against all contents of the 2nd parameter.NOTE: This function is not recursive, and will not test against children of objects passed (i.e. Groups within Groups).

parameters.name: object1
parameters.description: The first object or array of objects to check. Can be Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group or Phaser.Particles.Emitter.

parameters.name: object2
parameters.description: The second object or array of objects to check. Can be Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group or Phaser.Particles.Emitter.

parameters.name: overlapCallback
parameters.description: An optional callback function that is called if the objects overlap. The two objects will be passed to this function in the same order in which you specified them, unless you are checking Group vs. Sprite, in which case Sprite will always be the first parameter.

parameters.name: processCallback
parameters.description: A callback function that lets you perform additional checks against the two objects if they overlap. If this is set then `overlapCallback` will only be called if this callback returns `true`.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which to run the callbacks.

returns.description: True if an overlap occurred otherwise false.

functions.name: collide
functions.description: Checks for collision between two game objects. You can perform Sprite vs. Sprite, Sprite vs. Group, Group vs. Group, Sprite vs. Tilemap Layer or Group vs. Tilemap Layer collisions.Both the first and second parameter can be arrays of objects, of differing types.If two arrays are passed, the contents of the first parameter will be tested against all contents of the 2nd parameter.The objects are also automatically separated. If you don't require separation then use ArcadePhysics.overlap instead.An optional processCallback can be provided. If given this function will be called when two sprites are found to be colliding. It is called before any separation takes place,giving you the chance to perform additional checks. If the function returns true then the collision and separation is carried out. If it returns false it is skipped.The collideCallback is an optional function that is only called if two sprites collide. If a processCallback has been set then it needs to return true for collideCallback to be called.NOTE: This function is not recursive, and will not test against children of objects passed (i.e. Groups or Tilemaps within other Groups).

parameters.name: object1
parameters.description: The first object or array of objects to check. Can be Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group, Phaser.Particles.Emitter, or Phaser.TilemapLayer.

parameters.name: object2
parameters.description: The second object or array of objects to check. Can be Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group, Phaser.Particles.Emitter or Phaser.TilemapLayer.

parameters.name: collideCallback
parameters.description: An optional callback function that is called if the objects collide. The two objects will be passed to this function in the same order in which you specified them, unless you are colliding Group vs. Sprite, in which case Sprite will always be the first parameter.

parameters.name: processCallback
parameters.description: A callback function that lets you perform additional checks against the two objects if they overlap. If this is set then collision will only happen if processCallback returns true. The two objects will be passed to this function in the same order in which you specified them, unless you are colliding Group vs. Sprite, in which case Sprite will always be the first parameter.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which to run the callbacks.

returns.description: True if a collision occurred otherwise false.

parameters.name: a
parameters.description: The first Sprite to test. The Sprite must have an Arcade Physics Body.

parameters.name: b
parameters.description: The second Sprite to test. The Sprite must have an Arcade Physics Body.

returns.description: A negative value if `a > b`, a positive value if `a < b` or 0 if `a === b` or the bodies are invalid.

functions.name: sort
functions.description: This method will sort a Groups hash array.If the Group has `physicsSortDirection` set it will use the sort direction defined.Otherwise if the sortDirection parameter is undefined, or Group.physicsSortDirection is null, it will use Phaser.Physics.Arcade.sortDirection.By changing Group.physicsSortDirection you can customise each Group to sort in a different order.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The Group to sort.

parameters.name: sortDirection
parameters.description: The sort direction used to sort this Group.

functions.name: getObjectsUnderPointer
functions.description: Given a Group and a Pointer this will check to see which Group children overlap with the Pointer coordinates.Each child will be sent to the given callback for further processing.Note that the children are not checked for depth order, but simply if they overlap the Pointer or not.

parameters.name: pointer
parameters.description: The Pointer to check.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The Group to check.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A callback function that is called if the object overlaps with the Pointer. The callback will be sent two parameters: the Pointer and the Object that overlapped with it.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which to run the callback.

returns.description: An array of the Sprites from the Group that overlapped the Pointer coordinates.

functions.name: getObjectsAtLocation
functions.description: Given a Group and a location this will check to see which Group children overlap with the coordinates.Each child will be sent to the given callback for further processing.Note that the children are not checked for depth order, but simply if they overlap the coordinate or not.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to check.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to check.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The Group to check.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: A callback function that is called if the object overlaps the coordinates. The callback will be sent two parameters: the callbackArg and the Object that overlapped the location.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which to run the callback.

parameters.name: callbackArg
parameters.description: An argument to pass to the callback.

returns.description: An array of the Sprites from the Group that overlapped the coordinates.

functions.name: moveToObject
functions.description: Move the given display object towards the destination object at a steady velocity.If you specify a maxTime then it will adjust the speed (overwriting what you set) so it arrives at the destination in that number of seconds.Timings are approximate due to the way browser timers work. Allow for a variance of +- 50ms.Note: The display object does not continuously track the target. If the target changes location during transit the display object will not modify its course.Note: The display object doesn't stop moving once it reaches the destination coordinates.Note: Doesn't take into account acceleration, maxVelocity or drag (if you've set drag or acceleration too high this object may not move at all)

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The display object to move.

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: The display object to move towards. Can be any object but must have visible x/y properties.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed it will move, in pixels per second (default is 60 pixels/sec)

parameters.name: maxTime
parameters.description: Time given in milliseconds (1000 = 1 sec). If set the speed is adjusted so the object will arrive at destination in the given number of ms.

returns.description: The angle (in radians) that the object should be visually set to in order to match its new velocity.

functions.name: moveToPointer
functions.description: Move the given display object towards the pointer at a steady velocity. If no pointer is given it will use Phaser.Input.activePointer.If you specify a maxTime then it will adjust the speed (over-writing what you set) so it arrives at the destination in that number of seconds.Timings are approximate due to the way browser timers work. Allow for a variance of +- 50ms.Note: The display object does not continuously track the target. If the target changes location during transit the display object will not modify its course.Note: The display object doesn't stop moving once it reaches the destination coordinates.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The display object to move.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed it will move, in pixels per second (default is 60 pixels/sec)

parameters.name: pointer
parameters.description: The pointer to move towards. Defaults to Phaser.Input.activePointer.

parameters.name: maxTime
parameters.description: Time given in milliseconds (1000 = 1 sec). If set the speed is adjusted so the object will arrive at destination in the given number of ms.

returns.description: The angle (in radians) that the object should be visually set to in order to match its new velocity.

functions.name: moveToXY
functions.description: Move the given display object towards the x/y coordinates at a steady velocity.If you specify a maxTime then it will adjust the speed (over-writing what you set) so it arrives at the destination in that number of seconds.Timings are approximate due to the way browser timers work. Allow for a variance of +- 50ms.Note: The display object does not continuously track the target. If the target changes location during transit the display object will not modify its course.Note: The display object doesn't stop moving once it reaches the destination coordinates.Note: Doesn't take into account acceleration, maxVelocity or drag (if you've set drag or acceleration too high this object may not move at all)

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The display object to move.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to move towards.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to move towards.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed it will move, in pixels per second (default is 60 pixels/sec)

parameters.name: maxTime
parameters.description: Time given in milliseconds (1000 = 1 sec). If set the speed is adjusted so the object will arrive at destination in the given number of ms.

returns.description: The angle (in radians) that the object should be visually set to in order to match its new velocity.

functions.name: velocityFromAngle
functions.description: Given the angle (in degrees) and speed calculate the velocity and return it as a Point object, or set it to the given point object.One way to use this is: velocityFromAngle(angle, 200, sprite.velocity) which will set the values directly to the sprites velocity and not create a new Point object.

parameters.name: angle
parameters.description: The angle in degrees calculated in clockwise positive direction (down = 90 degrees positive, right = 0 degrees positive, up = 90 degrees negative)

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed it will move, in pixels per second sq.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: The Point object in which the x and y properties will be set to the calculated velocity.

returns.description: - A Point where point.x contains the velocity x value and point.y contains the velocity y value.

functions.name: velocityFromRotation
functions.description: Given the rotation (in radians) and speed calculate the velocity and return it as a Point object, or set it to the given point object.One way to use this is: velocityFromRotation(rotation, 200, sprite.velocity) which will set the values directly to the sprites velocity and not create a new Point object.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: The angle in radians.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed it will move, in pixels per second sq.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: The Point object in which the x and y properties will be set to the calculated velocity.

returns.description: - A Point where point.x contains the velocity x value and point.y contains the velocity y value.

functions.name: accelerationFromRotation
functions.description: Given the rotation (in radians) and speed calculate the acceleration and return it as a Point object, or set it to the given point object.One way to use this is: accelerationFromRotation(rotation, 200, sprite.acceleration) which will set the values directly to the sprites acceleration and not create a new Point object.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: The angle in radians.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed it will move, in pixels per second sq.

parameters.name: point
parameters.description: The Point object in which the x and y properties will be set to the calculated acceleration.

returns.description: - A Point where point.x contains the acceleration x value and point.y contains the acceleration y value.

functions.name: accelerateToObject
functions.description: Sets the acceleration.x/y property on the display object so it will move towards the target at the given speed (in pixels per second sq.)You must give a maximum speed value, beyond which the display object won't go any faster.Note: The display object does not continuously track the target. If the target changes location during transit the display object will not modify its course.Note: The display object doesn't stop moving once it reaches the destination coordinates.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The display object to move.

parameters.name: destination
parameters.description: The display object to move towards. Can be any object but must have visible x/y properties.

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed it will accelerate in pixels per second.

parameters.name: xSpeedMax
parameters.description: The maximum x velocity the display object can reach.

parameters.name: ySpeedMax
parameters.description: The maximum y velocity the display object can reach.

returns.description: The angle (in radians) that the object should be visually set to in order to match its new trajectory.

functions.name: distanceBetween
functions.description: Find the distance between two display objects (like Sprites).The optional `world` argument allows you to return the result based on the Game Objects `world` property,instead of its `x` and `y` values. This is useful of the object has been nested inside an offset Group,or parent Game Object.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The Display Object to test from.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: The Display Object to test to.

parameters.name: world
parameters.description: Calculate the distance using World coordinates (true), or Object coordinates (false, the default)

returns.description: The distance between the source and target objects.

functions.name: distanceToXY
functions.description: Find the distance between a display object (like a Sprite) and the given x/y coordinates.The calculation is made from the display objects x/y coordinate. This may be the top-left if its anchor hasn't been changed.If you need to calculate from the center of a display object instead use the method distanceBetweenCenters()The optional `world` argument allows you to return the result based on the Game Objects `world` property,instead of its `x` and `y` values. This is useful of the object has been nested inside an offset Group,or parent Game Object.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The Display Object to test from.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to move towards.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to move towards.

parameters.name: world
parameters.description: Calculate the distance using World coordinates (true), or Object coordinates (false, the default)

returns.description: The distance between the object and the x/y coordinates.

functions.name: distanceToPointer
functions.description: Find the distance between a display object (like a Sprite) and a Pointer. If no Pointer is given the Input.activePointer is used.The calculation is made from the display objects x/y coordinate. This may be the top-left if its anchor hasn't been changed.If you need to calculate from the center of a display object instead use the method distanceBetweenCenters()The optional `world` argument allows you to return the result based on the Game Objects `world` property,instead of its `x` and `y` values. This is useful of the object has been nested inside an offset Group,or parent Game Object.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The Display Object to test from.

parameters.name: pointer
parameters.description: The Phaser.Pointer to test to. If none is given then Input.activePointer is used.

parameters.name: world
parameters.description: Calculate the distance using World coordinates (true), or Object coordinates (false, the default)

returns.description: The distance between the object and the Pointer.

functions.name: angleBetween
functions.description: Find the angle in radians between two display objects (like Sprites).The optional `world` argument allows you to return the result based on the Game Objects `world` property,instead of its `x` and `y` values. This is useful of the object has been nested inside an offset Group,or parent Game Object.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The Display Object to test from.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: The Display Object to test to.

parameters.name: world
parameters.description: Calculate the angle using World coordinates (true), or Object coordinates (false, the default)

returns.description: The angle in radians between the source and target display objects.

functions.name: angleBetweenCenters
functions.description: Find the angle in radians between centers of two display objects (like Sprites).

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: The Display Object to test from.

parameters.name: target
parameters.description: The Display Object to test to.

returns.description: The angle in radians between the source and target display objects.

functions.name: angleToXY
functions.description: Find the angle in radians between a display object (like a Sprite) and the given x/y coordinate.The optional `world` argument allows you to return the result based on the Game Objects `world` property,instead of its `x` and `y` values. This is useful of the object has been nested inside an offset Group,or parent Game Object.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The Display Object to test from.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate to get the angle to.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate to get the angle to.

parameters.name: world
parameters.description: Calculate the angle using World coordinates (true), or Object coordinates (false, the default)

returns.description: The angle in radians between displayObject.x/y to Pointer.x/y

functions.name: angleToPointer
functions.description: Find the angle in radians between a display object (like a Sprite) and a Pointer, taking their x/y and center into account.The optional `world` argument allows you to return the result based on the Game Objects `world` property,instead of its `x` and `y` values. This is useful of the object has been nested inside an offset Group,or parent Game Object.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The Display Object to test from.

parameters.name: pointer
parameters.description: The Phaser.Pointer to test to. If none is given then Input.activePointer is used.

parameters.name: world
parameters.description: Calculate the angle using World coordinates (true), or Object coordinates (false, the default)

returns.description: The angle in radians between displayObject.x/y to Pointer.x/y

functions.name: worldAngleToPointer
functions.description: Find the angle in radians between a display object (like a Sprite) and a Pointer, taking their x/y and center into account relative to the world.

parameters.name: displayObject
parameters.description: The DisplayObjerct to test from.

parameters.name: pointer
parameters.description: The Phaser.Pointer to test to. If none is given then Input.activePointer is used.

returns.description: The angle in radians between displayObject.world.x/y to Pointer.worldX / worldY

members.name: game
members.description: Local reference to game.

members.name: gravity
members.description: The World gravity setting. Defaults to x: 0, y: 0, or no gravity.

members.name: bounds
members.description: The bounds inside of which the physics world exists. Defaults to match the world bounds.

members.name: checkCollision
members.description: Set the checkCollision properties to control for which bounds collision is processed.For example checkCollision.down = false means Bodies cannot collide with the World.bounds.bottom. An object containing allowed collision flags.

members.name: maxObjects
members.description: Used by the QuadTree to set the maximum number of objects per quad.

members.name: maxLevels
members.description: Used by the QuadTree to set the maximum number of iteration levels.

members.name: OVERLAP_BIAS
members.description: A value added to the delta values during collision checks.

members.name: forceX
members.description: If true World.separate will always separate on the X axis before Y. Otherwise it will check gravity totals first.

members.name: sortDirection
members.description: Used when colliding a Sprite vs. a Group, or a Group vs. a Group, this defines the direction the sort is based on. Default is Phaser.Physics.Arcade.LEFT_RIGHT.

members.name: skipQuadTree
members.description: If true the QuadTree will not be used for any collision. QuadTrees are great if objects are well spread out in your game, otherwise they are a performance hit. If you enable this you can disable on a per body basis via `Body.skipQuadTree`.

members.name: isPaused
members.description: If `true` the `Body.preUpdate` method will be skipped, halting all motion for all bodies. Note that other methods such as `collide` will still work, so be careful not to call them on paused bodies.

members.name: quadTree
members.description: The world QuadTree.

members.name: _total
members.description: Internal cache var.

members.name: SORT_NONE
members.description: A constant used for the sortDirection value.Use this if you don't wish to perform any pre-collision sorting at all, or will manually sort your Groups.

members.name: LEFT_RIGHT
members.description: A constant used for the sortDirection value.Use this if your game world is wide but short and scrolls from the left to the right (i.e. Mario)

members.name: RIGHT_LEFT
members.description: A constant used for the sortDirection value.Use this if your game world is wide but short and scrolls from the right to the left (i.e. Mario backwards)

members.name: TOP_BOTTOM
members.description: A constant used for the sortDirection value.Use this if your game world is narrow but tall and scrolls from the top to the bottom (i.e. Dig Dug)

members.name: BOTTOM_TOP
members.description: A constant used for the sortDirection value.Use this if your game world is narrow but tall and scrolls from the bottom to the top (i.e. Commando or a vertically scrolling shoot-em-up)

classes.name: Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Body
classes.description: The Physics Body is linked to a single Sprite. All physics operations should be performed against the body rather thanthe Sprite itself. For example you can set the velocity, bounce values etc all on the Body.

constructor.name: Body
constructor.description: The Physics Body is linked to a single Sprite. All physics operations should be performed against the body rather thanthe Sprite itself. For example you can set the velocity, bounce values etc all on the Body.

parameters.name: system
parameters.description: The physics system this Body belongs to.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The Sprite object this physics body belongs to.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of Ninja shape to create. 1 = AABB, 2 = Circle or 3 = Tile.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: If this body is using a Tile shape, you can set the Tile id here, i.e. Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Tile.SLOPE_45DEGpn, Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Tile.CONVEXpp, etc.

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: If this body is using a Circle shape this controls the radius.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of this Body. This is only used if a sprite is not provided.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of this Body. This is only used if a sprite is not provided.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of this Body. This is only used if a sprite is not provided.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of this Body. This is only used if a sprite is not provided.

functions.name: preUpdate
functions.description: Internal method.

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: Internal method.

functions.name: setZeroVelocity
functions.description: Stops all movement of this body.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets all Body values and repositions on the Sprite.

functions.name: deltaAbsX
functions.description: Returns the absolute delta x value.

returns.description: The absolute delta value.

functions.name: deltaAbsY
functions.description: Returns the absolute delta y value.

returns.description: The absolute delta value.

functions.name: deltaX
functions.description: Returns the delta x value. The difference between Body.x now and in the previous step.

returns.description: The delta value. Positive if the motion was to the right, negative if to the left.

functions.name: deltaY
functions.description: Returns the delta y value. The difference between Body.y now and in the previous step.

returns.description: The delta value. Positive if the motion was downwards, negative if upwards.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys this body's reference to the sprite and system, and destroys its shape.

functions.name: render
functions.description: Render Sprite's Body.

parameters.name: context
parameters.description: The context to render to.

parameters.name: body
parameters.description: The Body to render.

parameters.name: color
parameters.description: color of the debug shape to be rendered. (format is css color string).

parameters.name: filled
parameters.description: Render the shape as a filled (default, true) or a stroked (false)

members.name: sprite
members.description: Reference to the parent Sprite.

members.name: game
members.description: Local reference to game.

members.name: type
members.description: The type of physics system this body belongs to.

members.name: system
members.description: The parent physics system.

members.name: aabb
members.description: The AABB object this body is using for collision.

members.name: tile
members.description: The Tile object this body is using for collision.

members.name: circle
members.description: The Circle object this body is using for collision.

members.name: shape
members.description: A local reference to the body shape.

members.name: drag
members.description: The drag applied to this object as it moves.

members.name: friction
members.description: The friction applied to this object as it moves.

members.name: gravityScale
members.description: How much of the world gravity should be applied to this object? 1 = all of it, 0.5 = 50%, etc.

members.name: bounce
members.description: The bounciness of this object when it collides. A value between 0 and 1. We recommend setting it to 0.999 to avoid jittering.

members.name: velocity
members.description: The velocity in pixels per second sq. of the Body.

members.name: facing
members.description: A const reference to the direction the Body is traveling or facing.

members.name: immovable
members.description: An immovable Body will not receive any impacts from other bodies. Not fully implemented.

members.name: collideWorldBounds
members.description: A Body can be set to collide against the World bounds automatically and rebound back into the World if this is set to true. Otherwise it will leave the World. Should the Body collide with the World bounds?

members.name: checkCollision
members.description: Set the checkCollision properties to control which directions collision is processed for this Body.For example checkCollision.up = false means it won't collide when the collision happened while moving up. An object containing allowed collision.

members.name: touching
members.description: This object is populated with boolean values when the Body collides with another.touching.up = true means the collision happened to the top of this Body for example. An object containing touching results.

members.name: wasTouching
members.description: This object is populated with previous touching values from the bodies previous collision. An object containing previous touching results.

members.name: maxSpeed
members.description: The maximum speed this body can travel at (taking drag and friction into account)

members.name: x
members.description: The x position.

members.name: y
members.description: The y position.

members.name: width
members.description: The width of this Body

members.name: height
members.description: The height of this Body

members.name: bottom
members.description: The bottom value of this Body (same as Body.y + Body.height)

members.name: right
members.description: The right value of this Body (same as Body.x + Body.width)

members.name: speed
members.description: The speed of this Body

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle of this Body
