classes.name: Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Tile
classes.description: Ninja Physics Tile constructor.A Tile is defined by its width, height and type. It's type can include slope data, such as 45 degree slopes, or convex slopes.Understand that for any type including a slope (types 2 to 29) the Tile must be SQUARE, i.e. have an equal width and height.Also note that as Tiles are primarily used for levels they have gravity disabled and world bounds collision disabled by default.Note: This class could be massively optimised and reduced in size. I leave that challenge up to you.

constructor.name: Tile
constructor.description: Ninja Physics Tile constructor.A Tile is defined by its width, height and type. It's type can include slope data, such as 45 degree slopes, or convex slopes.Understand that for any type including a slope (types 2 to 29) the Tile must be SQUARE, i.e. have an equal width and height.Also note that as Tiles are primarily used for levels they have gravity disabled and world bounds collision disabled by default.Note: This class could be massively optimised and reduced in size. I leave that challenge up to you.

classes.name: Phaser.Physics.Ninja
classes.description: Ninja Physics. The Ninja Physics system was created in Flash by Metanet Software and ported to JavaScript by Richard Davey.It allows for AABB and Circle to Tile collision. Tiles can be any of 34 different types, including slopes, convex and concave shapes.It does what it does very well, but is ripe for expansion and optimisation. Here are some features that I'd love to see the community add:* AABB to AABB collision* AABB to Circle collision* AABB and Circle 'immovable' property support* n-way collision, so an AABB/Circle could pass through a tile from below and land upon it.* QuadTree or spatial grid for faster Body vs. Tile Group look-ups.* Optimise the internal vector math and reduce the quantity of temporary vars created.* Expand Gravity and Bounce to allow for separate x/y axis values.* Support Bodies linked to Sprites that don't have anchor set to 0.5Feel free to attempt any of the above and submit a Pull Request with your code! Be sure to include test cases proving they work.

constructor.name: Ninja
constructor.description: Ninja Physics. The Ninja Physics system was created in Flash by Metanet Software and ported to JavaScript by Richard Davey.It allows for AABB and Circle to Tile collision. Tiles can be any of 34 different types, including slopes, convex and concave shapes.It does what it does very well, but is ripe for expansion and optimisation. Here are some features that I'd love to see the community add:* AABB to AABB collision* AABB to Circle collision* AABB and Circle 'immovable' property support* n-way collision, so an AABB/Circle could pass through a tile from below and land upon it.* QuadTree or spatial grid for faster Body vs. Tile Group look-ups.* Optimise the internal vector math and reduce the quantity of temporary vars created.* Expand Gravity and Bounce to allow for separate x/y axis values.* Support Bodies linked to Sprites that don't have anchor set to 0.5Feel free to attempt any of the above and submit a Pull Request with your code! Be sure to include test cases proving they work.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: reference to the current game instance.

functions.name: enableAABB
functions.description: This will create a Ninja Physics AABB body on the given game object. Its dimensions will match the width and height of the object at the point it is created.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the object is destroyed.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. Can also be an array or Group of objects, a body will be created on every child that has a `body` property.

parameters.name: children
parameters.description: Should a body be created on all children of this object? If true it will recurse down the display list as far as it can go.

functions.name: enableCircle
functions.description: This will create a Ninja Physics Circle body on the given game object.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the object is destroyed.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. Can also be an array or Group of objects, a body will be created on every child that has a `body` property.

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: The radius of the Circle.

parameters.name: children
parameters.description: Should a body be created on all children of this object? If true it will recurse down the display list as far as it can go.

functions.name: enableTile
functions.description: This will create a Ninja Physics Tile body on the given game object. There are 34 different types of tile you can create, including 45 degree slopes,convex and concave circles and more. The id parameter controls which Tile type is created, but you can also change it at run-time.Note that for all degree based tile types they need to have an equal width and height. If the given object doesn't have equal width and height it will use the width.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the object is destroyed.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. Can also be an array or Group of objects, a body will be created on every child that has a `body` property.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: The type of Tile this will use, i.e. Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Tile.SLOPE_45DEGpn, Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Tile.CONVEXpp, etc.

parameters.name: children
parameters.description: Should a body be created on all children of this object? If true it will recurse down the display list as far as it can go.

functions.name: enable
functions.description: This will create a Ninja Physics body on the given game object or array of game objects.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the object is destroyed.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. Can also be an array or Group of objects, a body will be created on every child that has a `body` property.

parameters.name: type
parameters.description: The type of Ninja shape to create. 1 = AABB, 2 = Circle or 3 = Tile.

parameters.name: id
parameters.description: If this body is using a Tile shape, you can set the Tile id here, i.e. Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Tile.SLOPE_45DEGpn, Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Tile.CONVEXpp, etc.

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: If this body is using a Circle shape this controls the radius.

parameters.name: children
parameters.description: Should a body be created on all children of this object? If true it will recurse down the display list as far as it can go.

functions.name: enableBody
functions.description: Creates a Ninja Physics body on the given game object.A game object can only have 1 physics body active at any one time, and it can't be changed until the body is nulled.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The game object to create the physics body on. A body will only be created if this object has a null `body` property.

functions.name: setBounds
functions.description: Updates the size of this physics world.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: Top left most corner of the world.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: Top left most corner of the world.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: New width of the world. Can never be smaller than the Game.width.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: New height of the world. Can never be smaller than the Game.height.

functions.name: setBoundsToWorld
functions.description: Updates the size of this physics world to match the size of the game world.

functions.name: clearTilemapLayerBodies
functions.description: Clears all physics bodies from the given TilemapLayer that were created with `World.convertTilemap`.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The Tilemap to get the map data from.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to map.currentLayer.

functions.name: convertTilemap
functions.description: Goes through all tiles in the given Tilemap and TilemapLayer and converts those set to collide into physics tiles.Only call this *after* you have specified all of the tiles you wish to collide with calls like Tilemap.setCollisionBetween, etc.Every time you call this method it will destroy any previously created bodies and remove them from the world.Therefore understand it's a very expensive operation and not to be done in a core game update loop.In Ninja the Tiles have an ID from 0 to 33, where 0 is 'empty', 1 is a full tile, 2 is a 45-degree slope, etc. You can find the IDlist either at the very bottom of `Tile.js`, or in a handy visual reference in the `resources/Ninja Physics Debug Tiles` folder in the repository.The slopeMap parameter is an array that controls how the indexes of the tiles in your tilemap data will map to the Ninja Tile IDs.For example if you had 6 tiles in your tileset: Imagine the first 4 should be converted into fully solid Tiles and the other 2 are 45-degree slopes.Your slopeMap array would look like this: `[ 1, 1, 1, 1, 2, 3 ]`.Where each element of the array is a tile in your tilemap and the resulting Ninja Tile it should create.

parameters.name: map
parameters.description: The Tilemap to get the map data from.

parameters.name: layer
parameters.description: The layer to operate on. If not given will default to map.currentLayer.

parameters.name: slopeMap
parameters.description: The tilemap index to Tile ID map.

returns.description: An array of the Phaser.Physics.Ninja.Tile objects that were created.

functions.name: overlap
functions.description: Checks for overlaps between two game objects. The objects can be Sprites, Groups or Emitters.You can perform Sprite vs. Sprite, Sprite vs. Group and Group vs. Group overlap checks.Unlike collide the objects are NOT automatically separated or have any physics applied, they merely test for overlap results.The second parameter can be an array of objects, of differing types.

parameters.name: object1
parameters.description: The first object to check. Can be an instance of Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group or Phaser.Particles.Emitter.

parameters.name: object2
parameters.description: The second object or array of objects to check. Can be Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group or Phaser.Particles.Emitter.

parameters.name: overlapCallback
parameters.description: An optional callback function that is called if the objects overlap. The two objects will be passed to this function in the same order in which you specified them.

parameters.name: processCallback
parameters.description: A callback function that lets you perform additional checks against the two objects if they overlap. If this is set then overlapCallback will only be called if processCallback returns true.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which to run the callbacks.

returns.description: True if an overlap occured otherwise false.

functions.name: collide
functions.description: Checks for collision between two game objects. You can perform Sprite vs. Sprite, Sprite vs. Group, Group vs. Group, Sprite vs. Tilemap Layer or Group vs. Tilemap Layer collisions.The second parameter can be an array of objects, of differing types.The objects are also automatically separated. If you don't require separation then use ArcadePhysics.overlap instead.An optional processCallback can be provided. If given this function will be called when two sprites are found to be colliding. It is called before any separation takes place,giving you the chance to perform additional checks. If the function returns true then the collision and separation is carried out. If it returns false it is skipped.The collideCallback is an optional function that is only called if two sprites collide. If a processCallback has been set then it needs to return true for collideCallback to be called.

parameters.name: object1
parameters.description: The first object to check. Can be an instance of Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group, Phaser.Particles.Emitter, or Phaser.TilemapLayer.

parameters.name: object2
parameters.description: The second object or array of objects to check. Can be Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group, Phaser.Particles.Emitter or Phaser.TilemapLayer.

parameters.name: collideCallback
parameters.description: An optional callback function that is called if the objects collide. The two objects will be passed to this function in the same order in which you specified them.

parameters.name: processCallback
parameters.description: A callback function that lets you perform additional checks against the two objects if they overlap. If this is set then collision will only happen if processCallback returns true. The two objects will be passed to this function in the same order in which you specified them.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which to run the callbacks.

returns.description: True if a collision occured otherwise false.

functions.name: collideHandler
functions.description: Internal collision handler.

parameters.name: object1
parameters.description: The first object to check. Can be an instance of Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group, Phaser.Particles.Emitter, or Phaser.TilemapLayer.

parameters.name: object2
parameters.description: The second object to check. Can be an instance of Phaser.Sprite, Phaser.Group, Phaser.Particles.Emitter or Phaser.TilemapLayer. Can also be an array of objects to check.

parameters.name: collideCallback
parameters.description: An optional callback function that is called if the objects collide. The two objects will be passed to this function in the same order in which you specified them.

parameters.name: processCallback
parameters.description: A callback function that lets you perform additional checks against the two objects if they overlap. If this is set then collision will only happen if processCallback returns true. The two objects will be passed to this function in the same order in which you specified them.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context in which to run the callbacks.

parameters.name: overlapOnly
parameters.description: Just run an overlap or a full collision.

functions.name: collideSpriteVsSprite
functions.description: An internal function. Use Phaser.Physics.Ninja.collide instead.

functions.description: An internal function. Use Phaser.Physics.Ninja.collide instead.

functions.description: An internal function. Use Phaser.Physics.Ninja.collide instead.

functions.name: collideGroupVsGroup
functions.description: An internal function. Use Phaser.Physics.Ninja.collide instead.

functions.name: separate
functions.description: The core separation function to separate two physics bodies.

parameters.name: body1
parameters.description: The Body object to separate.

parameters.name: body2
parameters.description: The Body object to separate.

returns.description: Returns true if the bodies collided, otherwise false.

classes.name: Phaser.Physics.P2.Body
classes.description: The Physics Body is typically linked to a single Sprite and defines properties that determine how the physics body is simulated.These properties affect how the body reacts to forces, what forces it generates on itself (to simulate friction), and how it reacts to collisions in the scene.In most cases, the properties are used to simulate physical effects. Each body also has its own property values that determine exactly how it reacts to forces and collisions in the scene.By default a single Rectangle shape is added to the Body that matches the dimensions of the parent Sprite. See addShape, removeShape, clearShapes to add extra shapes around the Body.Note: When bound to a Sprite to avoid single-pixel jitters on mobile devices we strongly recommend using Sprite sizes that are even on both axis, i.e. 128x128 not 127x127.Note: When a game object is given a P2 body it has its anchor x/y set to 0.5, so it becomes centered.

constructor.name: Body
constructor.description: The Physics Body is typically linked to a single Sprite and defines properties that determine how the physics body is simulated.These properties affect how the body reacts to forces, what forces it generates on itself (to simulate friction), and how it reacts to collisions in the scene.In most cases, the properties are used to simulate physical effects. Each body also has its own property values that determine exactly how it reacts to forces and collisions in the scene.By default a single Rectangle shape is added to the Body that matches the dimensions of the parent Sprite. See addShape, removeShape, clearShapes to add extra shapes around the Body.Note: When bound to a Sprite to avoid single-pixel jitters on mobile devices we strongly recommend using Sprite sizes that are even on both axis, i.e. 128x128 not 127x127.Note: When a game object is given a P2 body it has its anchor x/y set to 0.5, so it becomes centered.

parameters.name: game
parameters.description: Game reference to the currently running game.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The Sprite object this physics body belongs to.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The x coordinate of this Body.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The y coordinate of this Body.

parameters.name: mass
parameters.description: The default mass of this Body (0 = static).

functions.name: createBodyCallback
functions.description: Sets a callback to be fired any time a shape in this Body impacts with a shape in the given Body. The impact test is performed against body.id values.The callback will be sent 4 parameters: This body, the body that impacted, the Shape in this body and the shape in the impacting body.Note that the impact event happens after collision resolution, so it cannot be used to prevent a collision from happening.It also happens mid-step. So do not destroy a Body during this callback, instead set safeDestroy to true so it will be killed on the next preUpdate.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The object to send impact events for.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback to fire on impact. Set to null to clear a previously set callback.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context under which the callback will fire.

functions.name: createGroupCallback
functions.description: Sets a callback to be fired any time this Body impacts with the given Group. The impact test is performed against shape.collisionGroup values.The callback will be sent 4 parameters: This body, the body that impacted, the Shape in this body and the shape in the impacting body.This callback will only fire if this Body has been assigned a collision group.Note that the impact event happens after collision resolution, so it cannot be used to prevent a collision from happening.It also happens mid-step. So do not destroy a Body during this callback, instead set safeDestroy to true so it will be killed on the next preUpdate.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The Group to send impact events for.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The callback to fire on impact. Set to null to clear a previously set callback.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context under which the callback will fire.

functions.name: getCollisionMask
functions.description: Gets the collision bitmask from the groups this body collides with.

returns.description: The bitmask.

functions.name: updateCollisionMask
functions.description: Updates the collisionMask.

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: An optional Shape. If not provided the collision group will be added to all Shapes in this Body.

functions.name: setCollisionGroup
functions.description: Sets the given CollisionGroup to be the collision group for all shapes in this Body, unless a shape is specified.This also resets the collisionMask.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The Collision Group that this Bodies shapes will use.

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: An optional Shape. If not provided the collision group will be added to all Shapes in this Body.

functions.name: clearCollision
functions.description: Clears the collision data from the shapes in this Body. Optionally clears Group and/or Mask.

parameters.name: clearGroup
parameters.description: Clear the collisionGroup value from the shape/s?

parameters.name: clearMask
parameters.description: Clear the collisionMask value from the shape/s?

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: An optional Shape. If not provided the collision data will be cleared from all Shapes in this Body.

functions.name: removeCollisionGroup
functions.description: Removes the given CollisionGroup, or array of CollisionGroups, from the list of groups that this body will collide with and updates the collision masks.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The Collision Group or Array of Collision Groups that this Bodies shapes should not collide with anymore.

parameters.name: clearCallback
parameters.description: Clear the callback that will be triggered when this Body impacts with the given Group?

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: An optional Shape. If not provided the updated collision mask will be added to all Shapes in this Body.

functions.name: collides
functions.description: Adds the given CollisionGroup, or array of CollisionGroups, to the list of groups that this body will collide with and updates the collision masks.

parameters.name: group
parameters.description: The Collision Group or Array of Collision Groups that this Bodies shapes will collide with.

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: Optional callback that will be triggered when this Body impacts with the given Group.

parameters.name: callbackContext
parameters.description: The context under which the callback will be called.

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: An optional Shape. If not provided the collision mask will be added to all Shapes in this Body.

functions.name: adjustCenterOfMass
functions.description: Moves the shape offsets so their center of mass becomes the body center of mass.

functions.name: getVelocityAtPoint
functions.description: Gets the velocity of a point in the body.

parameters.name: result
parameters.description: A vector to store the result in.

parameters.name: relativePoint
parameters.description: A world oriented vector, indicating the position of the point to get the velocity from.

returns.description: The result vector.

functions.name: applyDamping
functions.description: Apply damping, see http://code.google.com/p/bullet/issues/detail?id=74 for details.

parameters.name: dt
parameters.description: Current time step.

functions.name: applyImpulse
functions.description: Apply impulse to a point relative to the body.This could for example be a point on the Body surface. An impulse is a force added to a body during a short period of time (impulse = force * time). Impulses will be added to Body.velocity and Body.angularVelocity.

parameters.name: impulse
parameters.description: The impulse vector to add, oriented in world space.

parameters.name: worldX
parameters.description: A point relative to the body in world space. If not given, it is set to zero and all of the impulse will be exerted on the center of mass.

parameters.name: worldY
parameters.description: A point relative to the body in world space. If not given, it is set to zero and all of the impulse will be exerted on the center of mass.

functions.name: applyImpulseLocal
functions.description: Apply impulse to a point local to the body.This could for example be a point on the Body surface. An impulse is a force added to a body during a short period of time (impulse = force * time). Impulses will be added to Body.velocity and Body.angularVelocity.

parameters.name: impulse
parameters.description: The impulse vector to add, oriented in local space.

parameters.name: localX
parameters.description: A local point on the body.

parameters.name: localY
parameters.description: A local point on the body.

functions.name: applyForce
functions.description: Apply force to a world point.This could for example be a point on the RigidBody surface. Applying force this way will add to Body.force and Body.angularForce.

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: The force vector to add.

parameters.name: worldX
parameters.description: The world x point to apply the force on.

parameters.name: worldY
parameters.description: The world y point to apply the force on.

functions.name: setZeroForce
functions.description: Sets the force on the body to zero.

functions.name: setZeroRotation
functions.description: If this Body is dynamic then this will zero its angular velocity.

functions.name: setZeroVelocity
functions.description: If this Body is dynamic then this will zero its velocity on both axis.

functions.name: setZeroDamping
functions.description: Sets the Body damping and angularDamping to zero.

functions.name: toLocalFrame
functions.description: Transform a world point to local body frame.

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: The vector to store the result in.

parameters.name: worldPoint
parameters.description: The input world vector.

functions.name: toWorldFrame
functions.description: Transform a local point to world frame.

parameters.name: out
parameters.description: The vector to store the result in.

parameters.name: localPoint
parameters.description: The input local vector.

functions.name: rotateLeft
functions.description: This will rotate the Body by the given speed to the left (counter-clockwise).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should rotate.

functions.name: rotateRight
functions.description: This will rotate the Body by the given speed to the left (clockwise).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should rotate.

functions.name: moveForward
functions.description: Moves the Body forwards based on its current angle and the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should move forwards.

functions.name: moveBackward
functions.description: Moves the Body backwards based on its current angle and the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should move backwards.

functions.name: thrust
functions.description: Applies a force to the Body that causes it to 'thrust' forwards, based on its current angle and the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should thrust.

functions.name: thrustLeft
functions.description: Applies a force to the Body that causes it to 'thrust' to the left, based on its current angle and the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should move to the left.

functions.name: thrustRight
functions.description: Applies a force to the Body that causes it to 'thrust' to the right, based on its current angle and the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should move to the right.

functions.name: reverse
functions.description: Applies a force to the Body that causes it to 'thrust' backwards (in reverse), based on its current angle and the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should reverse.

functions.name: moveLeft
functions.description: If this Body is dynamic then this will move it to the left by setting its x velocity to the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should move to the left, in pixels per second.

functions.name: moveRight
functions.description: If this Body is dynamic then this will move it to the right by setting its x velocity to the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should move to the right, in pixels per second.

functions.name: moveUp
functions.description: If this Body is dynamic then this will move it up by setting its y velocity to the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should move up, in pixels per second.

functions.name: moveDown
functions.description: If this Body is dynamic then this will move it down by setting its y velocity to the given speed.The speed is represented in pixels per second. So a value of 100 would move 100 pixels in 1 second (1000ms).

parameters.name: speed
parameters.description: The speed at which it should move down, in pixels per second.

functions.name: preUpdate
functions.description: Internal method. This is called directly before the sprites are sent to the renderer and after the update function has finished.

functions.name: postUpdate
functions.description: Internal method. This is called directly before the sprites are sent to the renderer and after the update function has finished.

functions.name: reset
functions.description: Resets the Body force, velocity (linear and angular) and rotation. Optionally resets damping and mass.

parameters.name: x
parameters.description: The new x position of the Body.

parameters.name: y
parameters.description: The new x position of the Body.

parameters.name: resetDamping
parameters.description: Resets the linear and angular damping.

parameters.name: resetMass
parameters.description: Sets the Body mass back to 1.

functions.name: addToWorld
functions.description: Adds this physics body to the world.

functions.name: removeFromWorld
functions.description: Removes this physics body from the world.

functions.name: destroy
functions.description: Destroys this Body and all references it holds to other objects.

functions.name: clearShapes
functions.description: Removes all Shapes from this Body.

functions.name: addShape
functions.description: Add a shape to the body. You can pass a local transform when adding a shape, so that the shape gets an offset and an angle relative to the body center of mass.Will automatically update the mass properties and bounding radius.If this Body had a previously set Collision Group you will need to re-apply it to the new Shape this creates.

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: The shape to add to the body.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: Local horizontal offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

returns.description: The shape that was added to the body.

functions.name: addCircle
functions.description: Adds a Circle shape to this Body. You can control the offset from the center of the body and the rotation.

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: The radius of this circle (in pixels)

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: Local horizontal offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

returns.description: The Circle shape that was added to the Body.

functions.name: addRectangle
functions.description: Adds a Rectangle shape to this Body. You can control the offset from the center of the body and the rotation.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the rectangle in pixels.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the rectangle in pixels.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: Local horizontal offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

returns.description: The shape that was added to the Body.

functions.name: addPlane
functions.description: Adds a Plane shape to this Body. The plane is facing in the Y direction. You can control the offset from the center of the body and the rotation.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: Local horizontal offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

returns.description: The Plane shape that was added to the Body.

functions.name: addParticle
functions.description: Adds a Particle shape to this Body. You can control the offset from the center of the body and the rotation.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

returns.description: The Particle shape that was added to the Body.

functions.name: addLine
functions.description: Adds a Line shape to this Body.The line shape is along the x direction, and stretches from [-length/2, 0] to [length/2,0].You can control the offset from the center of the body and the rotation.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: The length of this line (in pixels)

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: Local horizontal offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

returns.description: The Line shape that was added to the Body.

functions.name: addCapsule
functions.description: Adds a Capsule shape to this Body.You can control the offset from the center of the body and the rotation.

parameters.name: length
parameters.description: The distance between the end points in pixels.

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: Radius of the capsule in pixels.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: Local horizontal offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

returns.description: The Capsule shape that was added to the Body.

functions.name: addPolygon
functions.description: Reads a polygon shape path, and assembles convex shapes from that and puts them at proper offset points. The shape must be simple and without holes.This function expects the x.y values to be given in pixels. If you want to provide them at p2 world scales then call Body.data.fromPolygon directly.

parameters.name: options
parameters.description: An object containing the build options:

parameters.name: options.optimalDecomp
parameters.description: Set to true if you need optimal decomposition. Warning: very slow for polygons with more than 10 vertices.

parameters.name: options.skipSimpleCheck
parameters.description: Set to true if you already know that the path is not intersecting itself.

parameters.name: options.removeCollinearPoints
parameters.description: Set to a number (angle threshold value) to remove collinear points, or false to keep all points.

parameters.name: points
parameters.description: An array of 2d vectors that form the convex or concave polygon.                                      Either [[0,0], [0,1],...] or a flat array of numbers that will be interpreted as [x,y, x,y, ...],                                      or the arguments passed can be flat x,y values e.g. `setPolygon(options, x,y, x,y, x,y, ...)` where `x` and `y` are numbers.

returns.description: True on success, else false.

functions.name: removeShape
functions.description: Remove a shape from the body. Will automatically update the mass properties and bounding radius.

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: The shape to remove from the body.

returns.description: True if the shape was found and removed, else false.

functions.name: setCircle
functions.description: Clears any previously set shapes. Then creates a new Circle shape and adds it to this Body.If this Body had a previously set Collision Group you will need to re-apply it to the new Shape this creates.

parameters.name: radius
parameters.description: The radius of this circle (in pixels)

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: Local horizontal offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

functions.name: setRectangle
functions.description: Clears any previously set shapes. The creates a new Rectangle shape at the given size and offset, and adds it to this Body.If you wish to create a Rectangle to match the size of a Sprite or Image see Body.setRectangleFromSprite.If this Body had a previously set Collision Group you will need to re-apply it to the new Shape this creates.

parameters.name: width
parameters.description: The width of the rectangle in pixels.

parameters.name: height
parameters.description: The height of the rectangle in pixels.

parameters.name: offsetX
parameters.description: Local horizontal offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: offsetY
parameters.description: Local vertical offset of the shape relative to the body center of mass.

parameters.name: rotation
parameters.description: Local rotation of the shape relative to the body center of mass, specified in radians.

returns.description: The Rectangle shape that was added to the Body.

functions.name: setRectangleFromSprite
functions.description: Clears any previously set shapes.Then creates a Rectangle shape sized to match the dimensions and orientation of the Sprite given.If no Sprite is given it defaults to using the parent of this Body.If this Body had a previously set Collision Group you will need to re-apply it to the new Shape this creates.

parameters.name: sprite
parameters.description: The Sprite on which the Rectangle will get its dimensions.

returns.description: The Rectangle shape that was added to the Body.

functions.name: setMaterial
functions.description: Adds the given Material to all Shapes that belong to this Body.If you only wish to apply it to a specific Shape in this Body then provide that as the 2nd parameter.

parameters.name: material
parameters.description: The Material that will be applied.

parameters.name: shape
parameters.description: An optional Shape. If not provided the Material will be added to all Shapes in this Body.

functions.name: shapeChanged
functions.description: Updates the debug draw if any body shapes change.

functions.name: addPhaserPolygon
functions.description: Reads the shape data from a physics data file stored in the Game.Cache and adds it as a polygon to this Body.The shape data format is based on the output of the{@link https://github.com/photonstorm/phaser/tree/master/resources/PhysicsEditor%20Exporter|custom phaser exporter} for{@link https://www.codeandweb.com/physicseditor|PhysicsEditor}

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the Physics Data file as stored in Game.Cache.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The key of the object within the Physics data file that you wish to load the shape data from.

returns.description: A list of created fixtures to be used with Phaser.Physics.P2.FixtureList

functions.name: addFixture
functions.description: Add a polygon fixture. This is used during #loadPolygon.

parameters.name: fixtureData
parameters.description: The data for the fixture. It contains: isSensor, filter (collision) and the actual polygon shapes.

returns.description: An array containing the generated shapes for the given polygon.

functions.name: loadPolygon
functions.description: Reads the shape data from a physics data file stored in the Game.Cache and adds it as a polygon to this Body.As well as reading the data from the Cache you can also pass `null` as the first argument and aphysics data object as the second. When doing this you must ensure the structure of the object is correct in advance.For more details see the format of the Lime / Corona Physics Editor export.

parameters.name: key
parameters.description: The key of the Physics Data file as stored in Game.Cache. Alternatively set to `null` and pass the     data as the 2nd argument.

parameters.name: object
parameters.description: The key of the object within the Physics data file that you wish to load the shape data from,     or if key is null pass the actual physics data object itself as this parameter.

parameters.name: scale
parameters.description: Optionally resize the loaded polygon.

returns.description: True on success, else false.

members.name: game
members.description: Local reference to game.

members.name: world
members.description: Local reference to the P2 World.

members.name: sprite
members.description: Reference to the parent Sprite.

members.name: type
members.description: The type of physics system this body belongs to.

members.name: offset
members.description: The offset of the Physics Body from the Sprite x/y position.

members.name: data
members.description: The p2 Body data.

members.name: velocity
members.description: The velocity of the body. Set velocity.x to a negative value to move to the left, position to the right. velocity.y negative values move up, positive move down.

members.name: force
members.description: The force applied to the body.

members.name: gravity
members.description: A locally applied gravity force to the Body. Applied directly before the world step. NOTE: Not currently implemented.

members.name: onBeginContact
members.description: Dispatched when a first contact is created between shapes in two bodies. This event is fired during the step, so collision has already taken place.The event will be sent 5 arguments in this order:The Phaser.Physics.P2.Body it is in contact with. *This might be null* if the Body was created directly in the p2 world.The p2.Body this Body is in contact with.The Shape from this body that caused the contact.The Shape from the contact body.The Contact Equation data array.

members.name: onEndContact
members.description: Dispatched when contact ends between shapes in two bodies.This event is fired during the step, so collision has already taken place.The event will be sent 4 arguments in this order:The Phaser.Physics.P2.Body it is in contact with. *This might be null* if the Body was created directly in the p2 world.The p2.Body this Body has ended contact with.The Shape from this body that caused the original contact.The Shape from the contact body.

members.name: collidesWith
members.description: Array of CollisionGroups that this Bodies shapes collide with.

members.name: removeNextStep
members.description: To avoid deleting this body during a physics step, and causing all kinds of problems, set removeNextStep to true to have it removed in the next preUpdate.

members.name: debugBody
members.description: Reference to the debug body.

members.name: dirty
members.description: Internally used by Sprite.x/y

members.name: _collideWorldBounds
members.description: Internal var that determines if this Body collides with the world bounds or not.

members.name: _bodyCallbacks
members.description: Array of Body callbacks.

members.name: _bodyCallbackContext
members.description: Array of Body callback contexts.

members.name: _groupCallbacks
members.description: Array of Group callbacks.

members.name: _groupCallbackContext
members.description: Array of Grouo callback contexts.

members.name: _reset
members.description: Internal var.

members.name: DYNAMIC
members.description: Dynamic body. Dynamic bodies body can move and respond to collisions and forces.

members.name: STATIC
members.description: Static body. Static bodies do not move, and they do not respond to forces or collision.

members.name: KINEMATIC
members.description: Kinematic body. Kinematic bodies only moves according to its .velocity, and does not respond to collisions or force.

members.name: static
members.description: Returns true if the Body is static. Setting Body.static to 'false' will make it dynamic.

members.name: dynamic
members.description: Returns true if the Body is dynamic. Setting Body.dynamic to 'false' will make it static.

members.name: kinematic
members.description: Returns true if the Body is kinematic. Setting Body.kinematic to 'false' will make it static.

members.name: angle
members.description: The angle of the Body in degrees from its original orientation. Values from 0 to 180 represent clockwise rotation; values from 0 to -180 represent counterclockwise rotation.Values outside this range are added to or subtracted from 360 to obtain a value within the range. For example, the statement Body.angle = 450 is the same as Body.angle = 90.If you wish to work in radians instead of degrees use the property Body.rotation instead. Working in radians is faster as it doesn't have to convert values. The angle of this Body in degrees.

members.name: angularDamping
members.description: Damping is specified as a value between 0 and 1, which is the proportion of velocity lost per second. The angular damping acting acting on the body.

members.name: angularForce
members.description: The angular force acting on the body.

members.name: angularVelocity
members.description: The angular velocity of the body.

members.name: damping
members.description: Damping is specified as a value between 0 and 1, which is the proportion of velocity lost per second. The linear damping acting on the body in the velocity direction.

members.name: inertia
members.description: The inertia of the body around the Z axis..

members.name: mass
members.description: The mass of the body.

members.name: motionState
members.description: The type of motion this body has. Should be one of: Body.STATIC (the body does not move), Body.DYNAMIC (body can move and respond to collisions) and Body.KINEMATIC (only moves according to its .velocity).

members.name: rotation
members.description: The angle of the Body in radians.If you wish to work in degrees instead of radians use the Body.angle property instead. Working in radians is faster as it doesn't have to convert values. The angle of this Body in radians.

members.name: x
members.description: The x coordinate of this Body.

members.name: y
members.description: The y coordinate of this Body.

members.name: id
members.description: The Body ID. Each Body that has been added to the World has a unique ID.

members.name: debug
members.description: Enable or disable debug drawing of this body

members.name: collideWorldBounds
members.description: A Body can be set to collide against the World bounds automatically if this is set to true. Otherwise it will leave the World.Note that this only applies if your World has bounds! The response to the collision should be managed via CollisionMaterials.Also note that when you set this it will only effect Body shapes that already exist. If you then add further shapes to your Bodyafter setting this it will *not* proactively set them to collide with the bounds. Should the Body collide with the World bounds?

classes.name: Phaser.Physics.P2.BodyDebug
classes.description: Draws a P2 Body to a Graphics instance for visual debugging.Needless to say, for every body you enable debug drawing on, you are adding processor and graphical overhead.So use sparingly and rarely (if ever) in production code.Also be aware that the Debug body is only updated when the Sprite it is connected to changes position. If youmanipulate the sprite in any other way (such as moving it to another Group or bringToTop, etc) then you willneed to manually adjust its BodyDebug as well.

constructor.name: BodyDebug
constructor.description: Draws a P2 Body to a Graphics instance for visual debugging.Needless to say, for every body you enable debug drawing on, you are adding processor and graphical overhead.So use sparingly and rarely (if ever) in production code.Also be aware that the Debug body is only updated when the Sprite it is connected to changes position. If youmanipulate the sprite in any other way (such as moving it to another Group or bringToTop, etc) then you willneed to manually adjust its BodyDebug as well.
